name: Crusader Kings II
description: Explore one of the defining periods in world history in an experience crafted by the masters of Grand Strategy.
minimum_requirements: OS: Windows 7 Processor: Intel® Pentium® IV 2.4 GHz or AMD 3500+ Memory: 4 GB RAM Hard Disk Space: 2 GB Video Card: NVIDIA® GeForce 8800 or ATI Radeon® X1900, 512mb graphics memory required. DirectX®: 9.0c Sound: Direct X-compatible sound card Additional: 3-button mouse and keyboard

reviews.review_text: At the age of 16, my character developed a mad crush on a local girl. He crept into her room and banged her, then declared he loved her. 9 months later she gave birth to a child, he decided he didn't like it, smothered this child in its crib, pushed his lover off a balcony and then married a horny Greek princess and did it all over again until he commited suicide at the age of 72 because his son turned gay after coming back from a visit to Constantinople. Brilliant!

Just minding my own business down in the little duchy of Serbia when three royal marriages and two feasts later I get a notification that I have inherited the entire kingdom of Denmark.   This game, with all of its DLCs for its full potential, is absolutely brilliant in that it brings character customisation and character development to a whole new level. Certainly different from the other Paradox Interactive franchises but in the best way possible. Each Paradox Interactive grand strategy has their own unique focus of gameplay which corresponds accurately to the time period and Crusader Kings II has definitely nailed it with their focus on indepth feudal systems and royal relations.   Also I imprisoned all my Danish vassals and watched Denmark plunge into anarchy under my command.   10/10 would usurp title again
so i was legitimizing my ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s and i accidentally clicked Expel Jews  10/10 Game of the Year

At the age of 21 I had lost count at 25 lovers, and I had 16 legitimized ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s (I didn't legitimize the ones with birth defects). This didn't sit well with the cuckolded kings of Christendom however, and I was promptly assassinated. I left my mark in more ways than one though, because now they all have herpes. I live on in the memories of the Frankish and Lombard kings; every time they feel the itch they think of me.
The only game on Earth where you can murder your uncle and the pope while plotting to rebuild the Roman Empire and fight Aztecs. 10/10 would play again

Crusader Kings II is an exceptional game in that no other title will make you feel like a ruler as well as it. You're not just a country, like in other grand strategy games. You are a ruler with qualities, flaws, vices and virtues. You can be a Duke who is a brilliant diplomat with a hunchback, an ugly, stuttering dimwit count, or a mastermind plotter/lesbian queen. (I'm NOT making it up). And you can be all that within in a single playthrough, as you re-incarnate into your heir when you die. You have to be good at managing your realm, but you've got to be even better at managing your dynasty by arranging favourable marriages, assassinate pretenders... It's all very involving and requires a lot of micro-management (which you may or may not like).  It's not without flaws: the interface could see much improvement and the game starts to slow down when you become powerful. By slow down, I don't mean that your computer has a hard time coping, I mean that there are many more events that require your constant attention, making things move at a slower pace. To be honest, after several hundred hours, I think I'm a bit burned with the game. And that, even though there are entire DLCs I haven't really explored yet: I have only really played as a Catholic or Muslim ruler, but DLCs let you play as pagans, Orthodoxes, republics...  And then there are a couple of Mods that are probably worth exploring as well: 'Game of Thrones' and 'Tamriel' (from the Elder scrolls series)  Still, with so much content and the unbeatable feeling of being an actual Middle-Ages ruler, it's hard to rate CKII anything lower than a 9 out of 10.

This game together with Europa Universalis 4 has completely ruined almost all other strategy games for me. I used to enjoy Civ 5 and I used to enjoy Total War. However since learning to play EU4/CK2, all I can think of while playing other strategy games is 'Why isn't this game as good as the ♥♥♥♥ Paradox makes?'. The gameplay is so deep and so enjoying with Grand Strategy Games like CK2 that I almost regret picking it up. I sometimes wish I hadn't open Paradox's box of terrors and maybe I could've lived in ignorance and enjoyed Rome 2, Civ and Beyond Earth. But sadly, I did.  Beware: Buying this game may ruin all other games in the strategy genre for you.  Ignorance is bliss.

I will not talk about how Crusader King II compares to other strategy games on the market because it wouldn't be fair to them. You do not compare a Picasso with children drawings from school. Students have to do quick flashy drawings for good grades, and do them as often as they can, with accent on flashy rather than on detail. Crusader Kings II is a game that puts the accent more on detail, quality rather than quantity.  The game itelf may feel a bit hard to understand at first, but if you give it a moment of your time, it will surprise you. But buyer be warn, if you just wanna play a game where you plug in, then all you do is fancy easy war TW style, or EUIV, then better avoid CK2. Crusader Kings II requires the player to think, quite a bit actually, and consider choices and plan ahead, sometimes for a few decades. It is a real strategy game, and as such it is a gem, since I do not think there is another game on the market that challenges you truly at this level and in such a complex way.  Why is it challenging? Well for one, you need to plan your dynasty, you need to plan your marriages to seek advantages and gains, secure the blood line, be wary of who will you end up playing next, and after that, manage your vassals, manage alliances which can only be made through marriage, manage your holdings so you can have more income and troops, manage your realm to pick laws which will either upset or make your vassals happy, or play nice to your liege if you are not independent, watch over your armies when you raise them, pick terrain carefully as it matters quite a bit, be carefull who you put in charge of your armies, watch over you flanks, be carefull what troops you use when, since the holding they come from gives them bonuses, plan your technological advancements, mind religion, convert, play the cardinal game, expand, go on crusades, plot to murder your enemies, to revoke titles, fabricate claims, and so much more.  You think that list is big? Its small, even more so, get a mod from the Paradox Forums, and you can get 2-3 times more features, some mods even take you to other worlds, use maps from settings you know and love and add a ton of events and new features. The ammount of depth this game and its modding community offer is mind boggling. Crusader Kings 2 is the Skyrim of Strategy Games. Its got depth, its got versatility, its got deep modability, its a gem.  And trust me, nothing compares to the feel you get, when after starting as a Count, you end up an Emperor for the first time...  UPDATE: 2 years and a lot of DLCs later... This game is killing my free time still. To date the most addictive game in my life. I've never spent so much time over so many years on the same game...
My daughter-in-law kept hitting on me until I gave in & took her to my private chambers...  She gave me the offspring that my wife couldn't.  Dynasty saved. Would tap dat a$$ again! 10/10
10/10 would expell Jews again.  EDIT: If you have Sons of Abraham, theres an option to expell the Jews from your realm as a Christian, and It'll give you a tidy sum of $350.
I assassinated my 12 year old brother to take over the kingdom of Portugal.   I love this game.

Fun for a couple of hours.

Quite simply one of the greatest strategy games ever made.  From the outset - Crusader Kings is not for everyone.   It will be best enjoyed by people who are interested in deep systems and the interplay between them. Those seeking a way to crack the 'optimal' way to play, and those seeking to 'win' will be disappointed, whereas those seeking emergent systems and effects will enjoy hundreds of hours of discovery.   It is therein that lies CK2's greatest strength - creating a narrative through emergent systems.  Crusader Kings II relies largely on the player setting their own goals and then working towards them. Be they immediate goals, medium term aspirations, or long term dreams, a large part of CK2's appeal lies in pondering how best to 'exploit the code' to reach your ends. In fact, the best way to play CK2 is not to play to win, but to let the game 'happen'; to let your dynasty's fortune ebb and flow with the passage of time, creating a narrative of a family streching across the centuries.    Crusader Kings 2 is a game that you can sink literally hundreds of hours into and still find out new and exciting things to do. CK2 isn't a perfect game; the learning curve can be steep, particularly for those new to the genre, and the presentation is a little short of the cutting edge. But, with a fantastic level of developer support, continual free and paid content additions, hundreds of mods, and a lively, friendly and supportive community, it is fair to say that CK2 is one of the greatest strategy games of all time and, for strategy fans, possibly one of the greatest games of all time. For this writer with over 30 years of gaming behind him and hundreds of hours on the game (mostly on the Gamersgate version), it's certainly cracked the Top Ten!

'Power tends to corrupt, and absolute power corrupts absolutely.'  - Lord Acton  The Medieval Age wasn't the brightest moment in human history. War, Assassination, Torture, Greed, Betrayal; those are merely some of the words associated with the atrocities committed by the rulers of the realm. Some good and honest men have ruled, but most rulers couldn't resist the temptation from the power they wield; the power to rule. They were tempted to gain more power, and they are willing to use even the most atrocious of acts to gain it.  Crusader Kings II gives players a taste of that power.  Starting at any point from 1066 (Or 769 with a certain DLC enabled) to 1453, players are allowed to choose from a very large amount of historical characters that once ruled over a part of Europe and parts of Asia and Africa.   From the lowliest duke to the highest emperor, the game has no final objective whatsoever, leaving players to create their own story and decide their own goals for their dynasty.   Do you want to be the most prestigious family in the world? To work your way up and create an empire that will last for generations? Or simply to make sure your bloodline survives through all the coming conflict?   Grand strategy games typically put players as an eternal invisible guiding force controlling a single country, viewing the world from above as a map as they manage the country’s Politics, Economy, Military, and Diplomacy through various factors. These games use simple visuals to accommodate the large scale gameplay. There are no fancy Total War-like massive battles or anything of sort. Almost every aspect of the game depends on numbers. In other words, the main part gameplay is to manage those numbers and the various factors affecting it to the player’s benefit.  Crusader Kings II offers a sandbox grand strategy experience into a more personal level; giving players control over a single Catholic ruler (later DLCs adds the options to play as Muslim, Pagan, and Jewish rulers) and continue on as his/her heir after passing away.   Instead of dealing with faceless countries, the more personal approach allows the game to have a large amount of characters, be it a lord or a simple courtier. Every character in the game has their own set of skills, traits, and relations with other characters. A major part of the game is managing the relationship between characters by various interactions. You can cement the loyalty of your vassals by keeping them happy with gifts and inviting them to feasts. You can increase the odds of success of an assassination plot by inviting treacherous people within your target's court. You can declare a war for a title your courtier has a claim on. Be wary as other characters could do it to you as well. The best option is to trust no one, not even your friends and relatives. These interactions increase the depth of Crusader King II's strategic gameplay in a very dynamic way.  The trademark Paradox's grand strategy gameplay is still present, even if somewhat simplified by the time period. Politics are mostly done by the character interactions mentioned above; with the addition of a player-manageable council the players can use accomplish certain tasks. Economy is much more simplified, with very little emphasis on trade. Instead of training units to form standing armies, you form a temporary military force in time of war, then disband them when the war is over. Your military comes from raising levies both from your personally owned holdings and from your vassals. (Retinues were added with a DLC).   Religion plays a major role in the game, with each religion having some unique gameplay mechanic that differ them from the rest; such as the Papacy for Catholics and Decadence for Muslims. While the strategy gameplay itself for most the most part lacks depth compared to other Paradox grand strategy titles, Crusader Kings II still stands on its own as a well-made and unique game.  Crusader Kings II is visuals are simple, yet fitting for the game. The map is fully rendered in 3D, it’s nothing breathtaking, but you can still appreciate the beauty of its landscape; although you'll probably spend most of the time using the political map mode. The character portraits are a great mix of realism and cartoony art style which provides a variety of colorful characters faces.  The musical score for the game is also worth praising. While not all the music in the game is memorable, they rarely distract you from the game, and for the most part they complement your playthrough with a variety of beautiful music fitting for the era.  The game is without its flaws, of course. While the tutorial is an improvement from previous Paradox titles, you will still need to learn most of the game’s mechanics on your own by trial or error. While it could be a part of the fun of playing the game, some people may dislike it. I’ve encountered several minor bugs, but the game is fully playable as of now. Another minor complaint is the lack of naval combat. While historically there wasn’t a lot of naval combat at the era, I wish that navies could be more useful such as for blockading ports. But as for the time this review was written, the only use for navies is for troop transport.  Describing everything about Crusader Kings II’s in detail would take a lot of time and energy. Both of which you could be using right now to purchase and experience Crusader Kings II on your own! (Or at least try the demo) Go and create your own story with your dynasty. Be patient and play as an honest, good natured ruler. Or fall to the temptation of power and spill the blood of anyone who stands in your way. The choice is yours.  Deus Vult.

Crusader Kings II on first look seems like just another game styled after so many other well-known games that use an overhead map and a time period. That’s where things steer into a different direction. This game may well be the best game created by the game smiths at Paradox Development Studio. It’s a huge strategy game with layers. I would suggest running the tutorial in the game. In fact I would also suggest keeping the hints option on, it is full of valuable playing information.Taking place over a 400 year time span the players take on the persona of a character running the realms and struggling to make it in these troublesome times.Throughout the game life, the character deals with the world and other characters of the court, they have stats and traits; they marry, and have children in hopes of conceiving an heir to the throne. That is the main point too, having a legitimate heir to the kingdom. As that first main character grows older and or dies before their time, as long as there is an heir the game goes on to 1452. Hierarchy and the bloodline are of some importance in this game as it was in yee olden days.The game plays in different ways depending on how the player chooses to start. Hierarchy plays a role here. So if the player starts out as a lower rank of the upper class, say a Count, well you have some leveling to do. There is so much information to be had during game play it can be over whelming at times; thankfully Paradox Development Studio has integrated so many buttons and drop downs to assist the player in keeping track of events and information. Plus the game can be paused to take a break or assess the situation. The interface and game play seems polished enough, though the animations took some getting used to.As gaming goes in the grand strategy style, there is some replay ability here, with so much going on, try different playing styles, be aggressive, or less so. See how things turn out, be a tyrant if you like.The graphics of the lands and seas are beautiful to behold, with clouds shadow and weather passing over the lands as you look down from your almost celestial view from above. Sound is pleasing as well, with music and sound bites setting the mood for events appropriately. This is truly one of the better games to come out from Paradox Development Studio, now like most strategy games, things do not progress always at a fast pace. So some patience in gaming is involved here. Crusader Kings II is exactly the sort of game I was hoping it would be. As deep and complex as its predecessor, but more accessible.
10/10 Would murder family again.

It's not that I don't like this game, but the DLC is completely ridiculous. Expansions are alright, but there is no reason that they have to release other DLC with them. They have already released face packs, music packs, dynasty shield packs, and probably something else that I'm forgetting, and in their latest expansion, Charlemagne, Paradox proved that they are experts at squeezing every last dollar out of their customers. Just when I thought they had run out of face and music packs to sell, they added clothing packs. There is absolutely no reason that these cosmetic changes can't come bundled for free or at a reduced price with the expansions. In total, Crusader Kings II DLC now costs over one hundred and seventy-five dollars. While there is nothing wrong with the game by itself, the DLC model that Paradox uses is horrible, and is only defended by a group of people that have a cult-like devotion to the company.

This was my experience: Play a few games but I don't really understand the game. Finally after an hour and a half of going throught the tutorials a second time I figure it out. Start up an empire in Iceland. I don't bother anyone. I marry a Danish girl and help out my father-in-law with a rebelion and a small war but I don't really cause any trubble. The king of Norge (Norway) keeps wanting to start wars though. One day I get a letter, he wants peace as long as I fly his flage. Seeing as my wife was sick and had died a month before and her father was now losing a war I did not have the gold to help him win I had no other choice but to submit and accepted Norge rule. Immediatly the King of Norge invites me to his grand feast. He treats me well and offers me protection and safety. Alpha as ♥♥♥♥ King of Norge fights the Scots who have been bothering me for years. I ask if my son can marry his beautiful daughter who will one day be the Queen of Norge, and without question or hesitation he sends his daughter to Iceland and congradulates me on entering the family. WIth this my son is happy and I can concentrait on my kingdom. Over the next few years I build up a great army and nearly 1000 gold in wealth. However, I am an old man. I fear the fate of my father, I fear that soon I will die. The King of Norge is not a young man either anymore. One day I get another letter. The King of Norge is plaining to invade Scotland. Seeing as my other son married Godwinson (The King of England)'s daughter I was prepared to invade Scotland and claim all of England and thus most of northern Europe for the King of Norge. I constructed a fleet of ships, hired thousands of men from the country side and some extra mecenaries just in case, and set sail. This time I was prepared for battle, I knew what would come. It was minutes laters as I prepaired my assault that I watched a Scotish fleet came from the deep ocean and landed on my shores and slaughter my people. Half of Scotland fought me in Scotland while the other half banded together and invaded my homeland of Iceland.   And that folks is the story of how Crusader Kings II gives you a cookie, lets you eat it and enjoy it before slaping you across the face and wash your mouth out with soap and hot sause. And I'll be god damned if it wasn't the most fun I've ever had. I laughed and I cried. I was filled with joy and then crushed with defeat. I was a king...I was THE KING...and then I was nothing...  11/10 would loose everything again

The first thing I did as the King of England was assassinate the King of Scotland. It wasn’t for any particular reason. I had just started running the game for the first time, and wanted to check out the King of where I actually lived. But then I saw the assassinate button. I pressed the assassinate button. There was suddenly a dead Scottish monarch and a massive civil war. Crusader Kings II is a ‘Grand Strategy Game’ by Paradox Entertainment, a lovingly created, complex board game of Europe, where you play as historical character. Unlike other strategy games, where you’re the godly hand that guides a country or force, here you’re a Count, Duke, King or Emperor, with all the extra complexities and joys that brings. You have to handle your lineage – marry, have children, assassinate children, change succession laws – so that the game continues. It is the only must in CKII: create an heir, or on death without one, it’s game over. The rest is really up to you. You could try and forge the Empire of Hispania as one of the Spanish Catholic kings, unifying the other catholic nations there and driving out the Muslim rulers. You could play peacefully as the King of Scotland in a different game, only stooping to war when vassals rebel for their own claims on your kingdom. With certain DLC, you could play as Muslim rulers in Africa and Saudi Arabia, Pagan rulers, or even as a patrician, vying for control of the sea highways and port to get the most profit possible.  The board deserves some explanation also: unlike many other strategy games, which use hexagonal or square tiles, here real counties are used, such as Gowrie, Cumberland, Middlesex, Badajoz, Leon, and Maine. And they aren’t just bits of land to get to make your Kingdom look bigger: they hold cities, castles and religious buildings that will increase the size of you or your vassal’s levies (army) when annexed and your income, from tax. You can even improve and build new holdings in these counties, to increase both of these. This is one of the many ways you spend your gold, along with creating kingdoms and duchies, hiring mercenaries, bribing the pope (yup!), assassinations, ect.  Though out the game, you will be collecting this gold from the taxes, which is the commodity you will be using most often. Also throughout your characters life, he’ll gain Prestige and Piety: both add to your end game score, which you can use to measure just how well you’ve done after playing all those hundreds of years. Both also act like currencies, with you gaining prestige and piety from certain wars and events, but losing them with other events such as destroying kingdom titles (prestige), creating empire and kingdoms (piety) and reforming pagan religions (piety). Upon your characters death, they add to your score – not, however, a reason to die early.  War is enjoyable in Crusader Kings II, but possibly not as important as in other strategy games. You can’t declare war, willy nilly. You must have a cause for war, the ‘cassus belli’. This at first feels very restrictive, as in some catholic countries, the only clear way to expand into neighbouring catholic nations is through the slow fabrication of a claim on the county. But eventually it blossoms into the complex strategy, as you juggle where to war with, with what cassus belli, to what end. It becomes delightfully full of opportunities. The Catholic Kingdoms can declare Holy Wars against Pagans and Muslims and claim their land, along with participating in the Crusades the Pope occasionally calls. You also have ‘De Jure Claims’, where you can conquer counties and land that belongs to the predefined ‘de jure’ duchies, kingdoms and empires, depending if you are a Duke, King or Emperor. Pagans can conquer any bordering counties, or subjugate entire kingdoms once in a life time. There is a treasure trove of reasons to war. And with your army, you can choose who leads the armies, and whether to engage them in battles against other armies, or to siege enemy provinces in the war. But it isn’t the only way to gain land: ensuring you’re the heir to the kingdom through assassinations and plots; through offering vassalization to the weaker, smaller independent rulers nearby. But wars are one of the more enjoyable points in the game, as long as you know how to handle them. There really is no better feeling than slowly building your independent duchy into a sprawling Empire over the years.  It is important to say that all the rulers on the map are actively acting towards their own goals, with the games superb AI letting hundreds of characters act and change Europe, even in places far from where you are playing. It is sometimes enjoyable to pause the game, and just look around the map, at what’s happening far away. Seeing distant kingdoms fracture, far of empires grow, really gives the game a sense of scale that is great.  And in multiplayer, you can have friends play in any of the Kingdoms, replacing one of the AI rulers. It can be incredible fun, with you playing as different Kingdoms, competing as you expand. You can choose whatever way you want to play with friends – you can assassinate them, declare war on them, or offer to join their wars. If they play as the same culture or religion, you may want to help them, to spread it, or fulfil goals that will help you all. With me and a friend playing Norse Pagans (Old Gods DLC), we started trying to expand my kingdom so that it controlled enough holy sites to reform the religion and grant us much needed security for successions. We’ve also had to aid each other during widespread civil and international war and bail each other out. It’s incredibly satisfying to bail your friends’ kingdom out of an independence war, and know they owe you one when you want to take over a nearby kingdom.  The downsides of the game is the initial bafflement due to the complexities of how to combine all the systems for your own benefit, and the occasionally irritation caused by wars for the kingdom after succession. Multiplayer also requires all other players must download the host save file every time they play, which can be a slow, but is thankfully all handled in game. This game is one for those who wish to carve a story and a kingdom out of Europe, and are willing to learn through all the complexities and systems to do so. Once the game finally clicks and you’re away with it, it really is a magnificent game. Whole heartedly recommended.

WARNING: If you plan to play this game WITHOUT DLC, you're going to have a terrible time. There is no way even in the depths of the underworld should anyone pay ~200 USD for a comeplete set of CK2. It's ludacris to believe that when I buy a game that's 40 dollars I have to suffer being locked out of great amounts of gameplay due to the fact I can't afford to buy dozens of different types of DLC. It's terrible.
This game made me kill my wife.  10/10 Would play again.

I have played this game for over 400 hours. Expanded my Empire from one small Baltic tribe. Expanded real Baltic religion to nearly all north Europe. Then - wham! New patch! Patch which broke all game system. Technology points were all gone, vassal opinions were all gone or of some enourmous amounts. Prestige points, piety points, score points, all gone or of enourmous amounts too. Contacted Paradox, asked for help - got replay that game system changed becouse of the latest patch.  Okey I thought to my self, scew these 400 hours or carefull planning and conquest. I will start anew, better Baltic Empire. Not to mention the pain with Viking leaders/founders of Kiev rus and Novgorod, which are imba, packed with stats like on uber steroids, but they also get a huge packs of army right from the start. So I had to defend from them. Plan my battle carefully. Picking a place and time. I beat them in first battle and made them retreat and then - wham! New mechanic - 'Shattered Retreat'.  'Shattered Retreat' So that imba unber steroid packed doom ball just retreated and I had to chase them all the way to their lands. Till I got to them, they have already recovered in morale and received reinforcements. I nearly lost that other battle. And it happened again - they just made Shattered Retreat again! And again I had to run around threw all the map just to get into same doom ball with full morale and reinforcements! But by that time my vassals were mad at me because I took their armies for too long and my gold account was empty.  I have bought nearly all DLCs for this game. It's roughtly 250 EUROs and I get this, Paradox?! So this is what you developed all this time using your player community money, Paradox?!  I am stating very clearly for the new commers - DONT BUY THIS GAME !!! You will be scewed up time after time and after time.  Shattered Retreat mechanic was a last nail into the coffin that I am putting this game into, Paradox. You failed miserable... just pathetic.   EDIT No.1: Tried to find some solution to this 'Shattered Retreat' crap. Looked all over the internet: Reddit forums, Paradox forums, YouTube, etc. The only working solution I found was on Steam Workshop mod called 'Normal Retreat'.  But guess what?! After activating it, my savefile Ironmode got corrupted. This means I can't do/complete any game achievements! Well done Paradox! I tried a new game, same thing! Well done, Paradox!!! Standing ovations!  Looks like Total War games from now on.
'It's the family name that lives on. It's all that lives on.' - Tywin Lannister

Feels great when you're playing as the King of Abyssinia and Nubia but need the kingdom of Egypt to create the Abyssinian Empire and you set up the proper marriages and your heir inherits the Byzantine Empire from your wife and your heir's heir likewise inherits the French Empire, allowing the expansion of the rightful world Empire of Great Abyssinia, stretching from Iceland to Sri Lanka. I learned a lot of geography from this game and EU IV.  Seriously, come trivia night, my geography is really on point. Capitals, country locations, rivers, I know that stuff.  Which is nice.  This may be the most complete and well rounded historical simulator available, and its mechanics are unique without being gimmicky. You see CK2 is about forging a dynasty, which is a fancy way of saying a rules heavy family. It's technically sandbox and you can have quite a bit of fun with it. You can roleplay as the traits that you have, or just try to make every character into Julius Caesar, or just keep assasinating popes, forever and ever. When your character dies, whether it be at 4 or 88, the play goes to the direct heir, whether he or she be 4 or 88, and you are given control over their decision making process.   As long as your dynasty has not died out in terms of inheritance laws, and someone in your dynasty has a sufficient title the game will continue until it stops after maybe dozens or a hundred hours of game play. You manage titles under your realm. Count is the lowest, than Duchy, than King, than Emperor, with some variety on the names depending on your culture. The key here is feudalism, that is vassalage. The standard is to pledge fealty to someone of the next higher title, who then pledges fealty to the title above them. This standard is never reached unless you conquer the world and make it be reached. In general, there will be sovereign Dukes, Counts pledged directly to Kings, and Emperors often forgo vassal kings.   You have advisers which are assigned from your court, which is a pool of loyal or disloyal followers whom you can consider for various roles, and to accomplish various tasks. These advisers assist you in running the operations of your feifdom, and allow religious, educational, espionage, stewardship, and martial decisions. Each character has an RPG style stat for each of these, and these along with a portion of your wife's stats and your advisers stats creates the stats used in game for you.  Key decisions in this game are marriage, and war. Marriage is the influence you have over your dynasty, and you can get good traits, titles, claims on titles, or political alliances in exchange for the matrimony. Wars allow you to cement alliances and shape the geopolitical landscape. There is much more to the game, as it has surprising complexity, but this is not to be a guide.  The game is visually very appealing, despite largely being a giant map. The music is nice, and even after several hours you may not be bored. There is also a ton of DLC for this, for better or worse. These are largely all expansive on the game, and most will be on for most games. Some like the Sunset Invasion are cheesy alternative history which you likely will not want on at all times. There are an absurd number of starting rulers at any of a number of initial scenarios, and a bit of imagination makes all interactions fun as you write your own story of world history amongst the players who have interesting personalities derived from their traits. This game remains an absolute treasure, and is still updated from time to time.

My wife proceeded to bear me daughter after daughter, which due to the country's male inheritance laws left my vassals unhappy.  Then, her father dies and she is left as his heir - she returns to her home county in England. It emerges that she was sleeping with a local Bishop. I realise I need a new wife if I'm to ever have a male heir, yet I can't divorce her or I'll end up making enemies of the English. So, I start a plot to assassinate her.  The very first person who offers their help with killing her? The bishop she was sleeping with! And he'll be most valuable, having lots of 'access' to her! My plot is in motion!  And then, said Bishop gets royally drunk and blabs about the entire thing to everyone, my wife is ♥♥♥♥♥♥, everyone thinks I'm scum, and I have a troop of daughters at my ankles.  Damn fun game, the emergent gameplay is outstanding.

Crusader Kings 2 is real time/paused strategy game developed by Paradox Interactive. Same developer who made other great games like Europa Universalis 4, Victoria 2, Hearts of Iron 3 and Stellaris. This game is based on Middle Ages to start of renaissance, where EU4 starts. Without DLC starts around 1066, but if you have dlc\'s like Old Gods and Charlemagne you can start it on 700\'s.  However before saying this game is all about invading other lands like Civ and Total War, no. Because this game is unique. You rule your dynasty and lead it through the age. You have to control your family by marrying other people for example Holy Roman Empire\'s princesses. Then you extend your family and realm. Same time there is world map, where you can invade land, like in every strategy game. But only land available is Europe, North Africa and part of Asia.   There are many events in this game. I\'ll explain hordes, rebellions and crusades in this review. There are many hordes. For example Mongols and Abbasids. If you have Sunset Invasion DLC, Aztecs are gonna invade Europe too. Hordes born quickly and rise by invading all neighbor realms. They are hard to defeat but they collapse easily with rebellions. Rebellions are events where claimer of duchy of puppet state declare war on country and try to switch government or get independece. That\'s why you see all rebellions threats on your intrique menu, so you can prepare at threats or plot to kill threats. And last, crusades. If you part of catholic or orthodox religion, pope or archbishop might declare crusade to invade Jerusalem, Anatolia or any lands where real life crusaders were. You don\'t have to join crusade but if you join and get most points you\'ll gain all lands that were invaded in crusade.  Family relations are pretty important as your sons that have bad relation with you might try to kill you or start rebellion. And affairs are just gonna anger your wife and your children. However having family member in countries like Holy Roman Empire might help you make alliance with them, so that is useful. On my game, I just spammed my every daughter on big countries, HRE, England, France and Byzantium.  Combat works really well, but units are pretty hard to make and army levies might rise too big.  Overall this game is great and I had alot more fun with it than with Civ or EU4. I recommend it!

Crusader Kings 2 is probably the most reactionary game ever made. Imagine Game of Thrones without the fantasy stuff. Whether you chose to play as the Holy Roman Emperor or the count of a single back country province you’ll have plenty of court intrigue to keep you occupied. It is ½ grand strategy game, ½ dynastic RPG, and 100% awesome.  With the various DLCs you can play as non Christian religions too. I highly recommend picking up at least the Sword of Islam and Old Gods DLCs so you can play Muslims and Pagans respectively.

Great. Artifical Intelligence may destroy and enslave you. ENSLAAAVEE. It's a good game. You work with a dynasty. Your dynasty. In Europe and Africa. In High and Late Middle Ages. 1066 - 1453, 867 - 1453 with the DLC 'Old Gods'. You rule a country: From a small province to the greatest empire. You have your heirs, inherit laws and everything other, from taxes starting.   There are five levels of authority in the game; the four highest of which are playable at the start:  - Emperor, Kaiser, Basileus, Shahanshah, Khagan (highest ones).    - King, Shah, Despot, Sultan, Serene Doge, King Bishop, Khan, Prince Mayor. The title 'King' is equivalent to the title 'Archduke' if the holder bends the knee to an Emperor or person of equivalent title.    - Duke, Doux, Satrap, Emir, Doge, Grand Prince, High Chief, Prince Archbishop, Grand Mayor, Jarl, Petty King, Caliph.    - The second lowest rank is that of the Count – variations are Earl, Sheikh, Wâli, Marzban, Chief, Lord Mayor, Prince Bishop, Metropolitan (Orthodox).    -The lowest in-game rank of authority is that of the Baron – variations are Timariot, Shaman, Mayor, Bishop, Patrician – of which only Patrician is a playable rank if the player owns the The Republic DLC, as the government of only a single holding with no non-commoner courtiers to command would provide the player with very few or no opportunities for intrigue.    The basic provincial unit of the game is the 'county'. Each county contains a preset number of holdings, with the maximum being seven holdings in a single county, including the comital capital. The holdings can be of three types: castle, city or temple holding. A castle is ruled by a baron, a city is ruled by a Mayor, and a temple is ruled by a bishop (each one having their own cultural and religious variations, such as the Muslim Mosque). Generally, a county has a capital set on a barony, but some counties (most notably in Italy) have city or temples set as the capital (ex: Rome is a temple-capital county and Venice is a city-capital county). As the player incorporates a lay nobleman, it can only exert control adequate over counties with castles as capitals or he'll suffer the 'wrong holding type' penalty in revenue – thus, city and temple holdings must be given to mayors and bishops. Exceptionally, Muslim rulers can control Mosques, which grant piety points. If the player owns The Republic DLC, the player can also take control of a coastal republic, like Venice, Genoa, The Hansa, Gotland or Cherson. In this case city holdings, instead of baronies, can be held without penalty.   Realm Laws There are two kind of laws in the game: the Tax and Levy laws – which determine the taxes your vassals (feudal, burgher and clergymen vassals) must pay, and also the number of levies they must provide – and the Succession Laws – which can be of two types: gender and inheritance laws. Succession laws are of fundamental gameplay importance, as the game over condition is the player's inability of establishing a dynastic heir. As a rule, succession is patrilineal, which means marriage offsprings will always be from the father's dynasty, but there is the option of matrilineal marriages for female characters, which means the offspring will be from the mother's lineage.   Gender Laws are the following:  Agnatic – Only males inheirt  Agnatic-Cognatic – Females can inherit, but only if there are no eligible male heirs.  Absolute Cognatic – Women inheirt on the same grounds as men do. (this type of succession is only available to Basque culture characters and the rulers with Cathar religion)  However, although Paradox added Enatic (males are entirely excluded from succession) and Enatic-Cognatic (females have preference) succession, these are only accessible through modifications to the base game.   Inheritance Laws are:  Gavelkind – The most common law, in which the inheritance is divided among all eligible children, the oldest inheriting the primary title. This succession type allows for a 30% larger demesne, the disadvantage is that it fractures the demesne upon succession.   Feudal Elective – The heir elected by vassals holding elector titles inherits all titles. This type gives an opinion boost to vassals, but it might have an heir not from the players dynasty—therefore ending the game.   Seniority – the oldest dynasty member inherits all titles. The disadvantage is that it usually results in elder characters inheriting, potentially creating a quick succession of short-lived rulerships.   Primogeniture – the firstborn child inherits all titles, in depth-first search descent. Arguably the most advantageous inheritance type, but it incurs in a slight prestige penalty for landless progeny.   Agnatic Open/Turkish Succession – available to every Muslim character (and also the only type of succession available) – the son that holds most titles inherits all his father's titles.   Patrician Elective (With The Republic DLC) – the only succession type for Merchant Republics – the heir is decided upon by a calculation of age, prestige, and a unique campaign fund feature from the 5 patrician families. Only males can inherit.   Investiture - only succesion law for bishoprics where the successor can be appointent by the ruler if under Free Investiture or by the Pope if under Papal Investiture. If there is no appointed heir then the game will chose character from the court of the bishop or create a new character if there is no suitable characters in the bishops court.   Elective Open – the only succession type for Republics (and also some types of holdings under the player level) – the game will chose a character from the republic rulers court or create a new character if there is no suitable characters in the mayors court.   Tanistry – open to Celtic Culture group which, like the Elective system allows vassals to choose the heir but restricts the choice to members of the current holders dynasty.   Ultimogeniture – the default succession type for Ilkhanate, the Golden Horde and the barony of Altenburg, in which the youngest child of the ruler inherits all the rulers titles upon their death.   Appointment - Used by Holy Orders feudal vassals called Commanders. All feudal titles are granted by the Grandmaster and revert back to him after the holder dies.   Papal Succession - Pope's succesion law where elected Cardinal's chose the next Pope among themselves. Only used by the Pope if the player owns the Sons of Abraham DLC.   King and Emperor-level characters also have a special set of available laws, the 'Crown Authority Laws', which simulate the power exerted by the monarch over his vassals. For example, with 'autonomous vassals law', the monarch cannot revoke vassal's titles, and they only provide levies to their liege if they hold him or her in high regard. In 'absolute crown authority law', the vassals are entirely forbidden of waging war against each other and foreign enemies and must provide a sizable amount of levies. After a whole lot of hours on this game, I feel I owe it a more detailed review.  Crusader Kings 2, ultimately, is an experience. This is a good thing and it's most active selling point - It's not a game you win or lose, it's a game you craft stories from - as all the other reviews will likely show!  It is a game that appeals to multiple playstyles. If you want to be the grand overseer, some sort of mini-god surveying all that you have and making incredibly far-sighted decisions about where to conquer, who to ally with and what wars to start, looking at it as a gamer rather than a character? You can.  If you want to look at it as the character you are, say King Eucedis 'The Fat' Salian of England, roleplaying as a man obsessed by excess, greed and pride, while simultaneously ruining future generations of your family tree by seducing all the courtier's wives and having a large pool of illegitemate children? You can  If you want to play it as a complete and total joviality, name your family the 'Megatrons' and rename every single English city after each Sonic the Hedgehog level, because why not? You can.  All of these and many more are games I've had. Sometimes the game hates you and wants you to suffer, such as letting your 25 year old genius, attractive king who has all the claims in the world die from a cough, leaving you to inherit as your 1 year old, dumb, hairlipped son, who immediately gets rebelled on by his better brother, leaving you a peniless and landless wreck. At other times, the game loves you and even though you played as a merciless, heartless father who had a child with his eldest son's wife (who also never had any more children) and then he immediately dies and because of your inheritance said child inherits, but the brother ends up staying loyal and true, which gives you more than enough forces to make the others kow-tow.  All of the above scenarios have happened. More have too. More still will. If you enjoy having fun stories to tell people, or even fun stories to look back on, this game is for you.  The only two downsides - The game has a lot of DLC, which all add a lot to the game. This is somewhat mitigated by them regularly being on sale, but the cost still adds up. I must admit though that even having that, I mostly still play as the Christian rulers that start off accessible, alongside the Norse - The key is to experiment after purchase of the base product with it online, as if the host has the DLC you can use it in an online match. That way you can get a feel for what you want.   The second downside is the game layout. The game is not massive on visuals, aside from the pretty map and such, so most of it is small character portraits and menus. This has the side of making the game complicated because it's not initially easy to understand where you go wrong.  But I promise you - if you put the time into the game, it pays off.

This game is only worth it if you've played other strategy games and gotten bored because there isn't enough detail. You can plot to kill a member of your court, join a war, start a war, arrange marriages, imprison people, execute those people and quell some rebellious villagers while you're at it.  In my game I helped my uncle take over Norway and once he had won using his wealth and considerable armies I had him assassinated and inherited it all at almost no cost to myself. Felt very game of thrones-esque.  The one thing to be warned of is that since I bought this game a couple years ago the developer has removed things from the game and resold them as DLC, they've also added a bunch with DLC and continue to do so but my advice is to be careful with your money because you can easily overspend on this game to have a more 'complete' experience.  *EDIT* I should add that this game is very poorly optimized so even though it's a very fancy 2D game you can easily encounter very significant FPS problems given that the game seems to only utilize one CPU core. It starts off strong but the longer the game the more Ai characters your computer has to manage and that slows it down considerably.

If you ever wanted to play a Christian feudal lord, Muslim or Pagan ruler, or the head of a merchant republic during the Middle Ages and be involved in backstabing and palm-greasing (family) when managing the head of a chosen dynasty, this is your game. Awesome time sink.

A Grand piece of work in the Grand Strategy Genre of Grand Strategy games...Humor aside, the game has a strong focus on managing relationships (especially amongst your vassals) and guiding your dynasty from the Dark Ages to the High Middle Ages. The 'Sandbox' effect and replayability of Crusader Kings II is by far it's most prominent feature, no two play-throughs will ever be similar. The Scope and scale of the game, and it's gameplay depth have been greatly increased since it's launch by many well-priced 'core expansions' (Sword of Islam, Old Gods, The Republic, Way of Life, and Horse Lords). Offering countless hours of replayability, a good level of gameplay depth, and a vibrant modding community, Crusader Kings II is probably (in my opinion) one of the best Strategy Games of all time.

It has a VERY steep learning curve, but for strategy fans, I can't recommend it enough, its a very unique game. Basically, the goal is to last as long as you can, its over when ether you lose your last piece of land, or if your ruler dies without a heir. Its very complex, but so worth it once you get the hang of it. I mean really, how many games come along where you can say you had the Pope assassinated? Unlike a lot of strategy games, its not so much about build this and conqure everyone, its more about surviving and the political intrigue of the times. People will try to fabricate claims on your land, your second wife may try to have a son you had with your first wife assassinated so that her child will become the rightfull heir. You can start in Ireland and work your way up from count, to king, then conqure Scotland and England to form the Empire of Britannia. You can stratigically marry off your daughters to prestigous people of other countrys, then their sons will have claim to those lands. Theres different rules too, which you can change so that daughters can inherit, or that women can even inheret on the same grounds men do. There is a LOT to the game. The DLCs add even more, such as being able to play as pagens and sacrificeing your prisioners, if thats more your thing.
It's the most complicated thing I've ever played and it's spectacular.

Almost 500 hours and I still can't get enough. Grand strategy excellence done superbly by Paradox yet again. Once you have a few children, it's impossible to lose. 'Winning' is a different story. There are a variety of neat mods in the Workshop, and modding the game yourself is surprisingly easy.

I may have only played this during the free week, but once I did, after the week was over I put it on my wishlist. It is a extremely strategically based game and requires your full attention during every moment. It is overwhelming at first, but you get the hang of it really fast. Mastering however takes time and patience. If you like Civilization V, then think of this as a really really in-depth medieval era type game play, with a little less unit building and more economy based.

I have enjoyed this game much more than I anticipated. My favorite aspect is the length of time in which to create a lasting 'family dynasty.' Paradox (the game studio) has offered, for better or worse depending, several downloadable content ('DLC's), not all of which are crucial, but offer different enhancements. 'The Old Gods', my reason for purchasing this particular DLC, allows the player to begin the game in AD867, instead of AD1066. Crusader Kings II, affectionately knowns as 'CK2' which ends with the fall of Constantinople to the Ottoman Turks in AD1435 (I think), has a DLC with allows a 'saved game' to be exported to another Paradox game, Europa Univeralis IV, or 'EU4.' EU4, which is quite different, allows the CK2 game to continue on past 1435. CK2, has more detail when it comes to creating a family dynasty that lasts through hundreds of years and allows a player to play in a dynastic succession. If you have more questions, please ask!

One of the most enjoyable games I've ever played. The amount of depth is amazing, and the text based build allows for very easy modding. Although some parts of the game may be ahistorical, owing the limitations of the game engine (Namely, the portrayal of Byzantium and the Islamic caliphates as decentralised, essentially feudal realms), there's still much fun to be had. With two years of DLC and patches under it's belt, and a further year (At least) to go, I can only see it getting better.

Do you remember the primitive empire building mechanics in Mount and Blade? Ever feel like they weren't able to cover the real breadth of possible political intrigue? Did you ever think you could have solved a standoff by quietly assassinating a regent, marrying off your sister to a mongolian despot, keeping a rival monarchs heir under lock and key by offering to 'educate' them before declaring a surprise war or carefully replacing all your precursors council members with men fiercely loyal to yourself?  Then step right this way my friend, as Crusader Kings 2 is essentially ALL that and a metric tonne more.  On the positive side Crusader Kings 2 is one of those games that benefits from a level of detail that should impress even the most brick-chewing and hardened history buff as the majority of its campaigns are based around the monarchs and clergy of the real middle ages. Paradox has done a laudible job in recreating the insane game of political backsies that these historical figures found themselves living through or dieing in. The fact that it also gives you a quick and easy way to look up more information on particularly interesting characters is a great example of tangential learning used in gaming. Further to this there's a truly dizzying amount of depth to the games mechanics that gives you an idea of just why every ruler had to have a retinue of advisors and counsels to help them manage information and make decisions. The lack of a strong structured narrative also gives the player a lot of freedom in how they tackle problems or exploit oppurtunities. It leads to some rather interesting emergent gameplay scenarios that I suspect people who enjoy the game while love swapping with other players just to compare how they each dealt with unexpected problems. It all adds together to give CS2 a real sense of atmosphere, refreshingly not in the usual 'dark, rainy and miserable' sense that highly atmospheric games often default to. You end up feeling like a man (or woman) with a bit of power under their belt but an order of magnitude more responsibility than you could possibly have been prepared for.  On the other hand...the user interface and tutorial could use a hell of a lot of work. Yes this is fairly par for the course in a Paradox game but it becomes more of a bugbear than usual in CS2 due to the sheer magnitude of information the game is required to communicate to the player. You open a single figure's profile and you're given their nationality, general skills, specific strengths and weaknesses, religion, marriage/betrothal status, claims to land and title, demense makeup, alliances, honourary titles, family tree, dynastic tree, vassals, retainers, your opinion of them, their opinions of you, their hopes and dreams...AGH! STOP! Look I just want to know who his heirs are so I can kidnap one of them!  Compounding this problem is that the number of possible avenues of play is quite large and, while the tutorial does it's level best to introduce us to all of them, it felt like trying to teach the specifics of circuit design to a confused panda: More difficult than nessecary and ultimately kind of pointless. When I sat down to go through the tutorial myself I had already initiated and succesfully resolved two murder plots by the time the game actually introduced me to the plotting and conspiracy system. Yet by the time my neighbours were marching over my home territory and I was running about in a flap trying to route them the game decided that now, after the invasion of my home had already begun, would be a good time to teach me about building static defences...on my island colony several thousand kilometeres away. Thanks CS2, you couldn't have mentioned this whole 'developing technology' thing a little earlier? Perhaps back before my paper thin walls had been breached by a ballistae?  Ultimately though once a player works out the ins and outs of the system, and yes that might take several decades of PHD level research and a small team of interns working around the clock, they'll find themselves immersed in a mechanically deep and highly immersive world that will reward them with... well probbably a poisoned cup of wine carried by your heir apparent but a historically accurate one nonetheless.

If you've ever played Civilization and thought it would be great if the whole game were the middle ages and I actually got to oppress the peasants, then you will enjoy this game. Similarly, if your family reunions make you wish you could speed up time and exert exacting control over who everyone in your family marries, this game will really blow your hair back. And finally, if you like playing The Sims but wish you could invade your neighbor and burn their ugly house down, well, I count myself fortunate to not be your vassal.  The gameplay really nails a humorous historical blend of strategy, simulation and role playing. The user interface is packed with information that can draw you in for hours, once you master the very steep learning cliff. The graphics are fairly minimal, but honestly just right for the game.  Unfortunately, so many of the extras that you wish you had control over are fairly pricey DLC, for what they get you. Want to tell your uppity heir to shave his stupid moustache? $4.99. Tired of everyone looking the same, wearing the same 5 outfits or having historically inaccurate ethnicities? $1.99, $0.99 and more for each part of the globe.  They have expanded the game several times, and the features continue to be added even if you don't by the expansion. From this standpoint, you can get many hours of new gaming experience out of it.  However this makes for an unpredictable experience. I bought the game to enjoy multiplayer with my wife. While the added features are great, the stability of the game has its ups and downs. Recently, the Mac version of the game has been very difficult to enjoy. Crashes to desktop and out-of-sync errors become more and more common as our conquests abound and demense expands. Any more, we can't reliably go for more than hour without one of us suffering a setback and having to fully reload the game.  Another common problem is that the game will protest that we have different versions when setting up the multiplayer server. This requires us to fully reload the game again.  I love the game and wish I could play it more. I'm not opposed to paid or free expansions and feature additions, but given the choice between a rock solid, unchanging game and a buggy, evolving game, I'll choose the former every time.

Such a splendid story generator hasn't been made since King of Dragon Pass, except maybe Dwarf Fortress which this game has plenty in common with too. Mainly the 'Losing is fun' attitude. The game is an endless cavalcade of royal families backstabbing and incest and plotting in courts, but there's no game over as long as you have still some heirs with which to continue the saga. Very much like Game of Thrones. Highly highly recommended.

This game is the most accessible and least buggy game that Paradox has ever released.  You can unify your lands through marriage or mace, conquer Europe, go from Count of Dublin to King of Africa over the course of generations, or merely try to hold your kingdom together in the face of your relatives, who might not be so numerous or so quarrelsome if you didn't feel like having 10 kids a generation or two back.  Ultimately, Crusader Kings 2 is a game of emergent story. I don't remember my conquests as much as I remember the time that a once-favored cousin in Ulster managed to grab a piece of Italy through marriage and immediately defected to the Holy Roman Empire, leading to a massive war as I attempted to bring my wayward vassal to heel and left me managing a motley crew of dissatisfied Italians who now owed fealty to a distant Irish liege.

Over the years I've logged over 1250 hours in this game. To say that it is one of my favorites would be an obvious given. What i like the most about it is that it focuses on the lives of a dynasty that I can create and develop over the annals of medieval European history. With all of the expansions this can also be extended to the mid east and Indian subcontenant. The game continues to evolve with each successive addition to add more and more variety between governing types, religions, cultures, and even lifestyles. I would not call it high action, though it has its moments, but a game that can be paced and simply enjoyed in terms of strategy. If you love strategy and the intrigue of dynasty building this game is for you.  As a bonus; if you're a fan of game of thrones.. the game of thrones mod is amazing.

Best kind of surprise package by Paradox Development Studio. A game which gives you the challenge of trying to keep your dynasty alive and in power whilst also tempting you with expansion and wealth. Take part in holy crusades to re-take holy catholic lands and earn prestige through wars. If war's not your game, use cunning and intrigue with strategic marriages and spies to help fabricate claims on land, call in allies and take the land without lifing a finger.  If you get the DLC's you can play as the muslims in the east, become a caliphate and declare jihads and watch as your fellow believers sweep accross Europe in the name of Allah.   Bring the Byzantine Empire their previous glory and reform the Roman Empire, gaining justifications on all her previous holdings.  Watch in a twist of history as the Aztecs land on European shores bringing with them new and strange diseases. Watch as they cut down kingdoms and forge their own empire.  Play as a Republic, forgeing a dynasty of wealth and power through trade, then use this new wealth and power to cut out your own empire. (Like the Romans did!)  And soon you will be allowed to play as Pagans, like the vikings and plunder gold and wreak havoc in the name of Odin. Each Pagan will have its own unique taste.  You can even create your own Dynasty and play as yourself and your family.  I've got to say, the care they put into this game makes it 100% worth every (now extinct Canadian)penny I paid. Not to mention how open the game is to modding. There are mods that completely change the game. Play the Game of Thrones or Elder Scrolls! There are actually mods that allow it! Not to mention all the other mods out there, it's great.  It's a must buy even if you don't like games like this, it might change your mind.

There's very little to say that the dedicated, vocal and truly helpful CK2 community has not already said. What is Crusader Kings 2? You ask as you boot up the game for the very first time. 6 hours later you are involved in a plot to kill your brother, crusading for the holy land, and your uncle is leading a revolt to lower your crown authority.  Crusader Kings 2 is a grand strategy game developed by Paradox that lets you play as a count, duke, king, or emperor during the timeframe of 1066 to 1453. Instead of most grand strategy games where your ruler lives forever, in Crusader Kings 2 your character will die and then you will continue to play has their heir until your dynasty is killed off or the game ends. In fact the entire game is based around you running your dynasty rather than your country. Good traits, prestige, and wealth are all passed down so it is important that you maintain good bloodlines, even if you need to kill a few family members off. The second part of the game is religion. When a Crusade or Jihad is called, you are expected to join and fight or suffer the consequences. Rulers of the same faith will tend not to go to war with each other while the opposites will. There is a lot more stuff I didn't mention but you are going to just have to play to find out.  The game, unfortunately, has the 'Paradox Plague' meaning that if you want to do anything (custom character/country) you are going to need to pay for the dlc. Even major things like playing as Islamic characters requires a dlc. Granted they are cheap and go on sale quite often, but it is still content that should already be in the game, or at least a free update. Thankfully the game has great mod support so you can play user created content.  Crusader kings 2 is worth your time and you will sink a ton of hours into it. There is a learning curve, but once you get over that you will be ruling with the best of them.   9/10   UPDATE: Get the EUIV converter.

Crusader Kings II doesn't have any plot or main story to go trough. Instead you have only one objective. Make sure your family never falls and try to make your dynasty as prosperous as possible.  This might sound boring at first but in reality it´s extremely addictive. There are many ways to try and climb the ladder. While sometimes brute force is enough, often you need to be way more devious. While marrying your son to someones daughter might seem harmless at first, it gets way more profitable once her brothers have mysteriously fallen. Having good relations is always important unless you want to be cornered against multiple armies or just find your main charracter being stabbed to death leaving your young child on the throne unable to deal with the matters at hand.   As changes can happen very quickly, Crusader Kings II makes you put in your A game or otherwise you will be swept back into nothing or to total extinction. While the suprises can be depressing at times, coping with these problesm is what makes the game so addictive. Prosperous moves aren't always the wise ones. Marry your daugher to the neighboring kingdom to fight your enemies and yes you won. Too bad they decided to invade you during the next generation as they had a rightfull claim to your throne. Expand carefully and make sure you will win both now and in the future.

Finally, a game that does DLC right.  I came into this franchise a little after the Old Gods DLC was released. Intially, I just played the original game, since there's a pretty steep learning curve and the base game alone has tons of hours of gameplay by itself. The great thing about this game is, it a fully complete and deep game no matter if you decide to expand or not. With that said, each expansion has brought a different flavor and experience to the gameplay that I hadn't even known that I wanted until I was playing it. Having played them now, I would not be able to go back to just the original game as is. Even owning this game for as long as I have, I still play it on a consistent basis.  Some people argue about how expensive the game and all of it's DLC are. CK2 goes on sale like, every other month (if not more). Pick up a DLC here and there (theres so much in these that you really will be kept busy by the features in each) for a fraction of the regular price. Half of the DLCs you can ignore, because they are mainly eye candy things - extra skins or shields. I wouldn't worry about those until you have all the gameplay ones in your library.  And if all else fails, there's a great Game of Thrones mod.

Let me tell you some actual things that I've done in that Crusader Kings II:  I was the Queen of Wales, and I saw that the person who was third in line for the duchy of York was an unmarried woman. She had three young children, two boys and a girl. The current Duke of York was a young man, with a single son, and a chaste wife. I invited the woman who might inherit York to my court, and I arranged for her to marry into my family. Meanwhile, I betrothed all of her children to members of my family. Being a member of my court, she had little choice in the matter. Then, I murdered the Duke of York, sending assassins after him. It took a small fortune, but he was eliminated. His young son made a poor feudal lord, being four, and it was quite easy to convince his court to murder him. With that murder, my erstwhile courtier became the Duchess of York. Two generations later, thanks to my long term family planning, the Duchy of York came into the possession of my family.  I was a Scottish Duke, and I served my king loyally for two decades. He was my friend, my cousin, and I served with pride as his chancellor. But he sickened and died, and his young child became king. A wee lad of six, and I was made his regent and tutor. I also discovered that I was his heir. So, I murdered him, and usurped the crown. My new vassals were unhappy with my actions, so I purged them and replaced them with cousins. I betrothed my son to a brilliant, lustful Byzantine princess, and all seemed well. Until my son swore an oath of celibacy. With needs her husband could not fulfil, my daughter in law turned to me. Not so long after, a baby boy was born. I legitimized the child, murdered my son and my wife, and started over with my new family. I was known as Malcolm the Good.  I was the Empress of Cymru (once known as Britannia), and my realm had turned to the Cathar faith. The Cathar faith is a Catholic heresy that believed in reincarnation, that a person might be man or woman in any given life, and which believed in gender equality. Being Cathar, I was able to land a woman with a fine mind for tactics as a countess, and I made her my marshal. When the Caliph declared a Jihad against me, trying to retake Hispania, I gave her command of my armies. At times, all three flanks of my main force were commanded by women. That countess led my armies in every major battle, becoming pregnant twice during the course of the war despite being 39/40 at the time of the births. She was wounded more than once, she led armies into battle while being outnumbered 3:2 or worse, but she never lost a battle. She became the second most famous person in all of Europe at that time, with more prestige than the Pope or Caliph or Byzantine Emperor or the Khans. By all accounts, over three hundred thousand infidels were killed by her forces. After the war, she suffered from depression, she lost her courage, but she was still the best person to lead the fight in a Great Holy War against the Norse tribes, far from her home in Portugal. She died at home, and one of her born-on-a-battlefield sons succeeded her.  I was the head of the Norse faith and Queen of Denmark, and a treacherous family member gathered an army and struck directly at my capital. He destroyed my retinue army, and assaulted my capital. Outnumbered, with no support from my allies, with my other family members choosing to support the usurper, I was forced to surrender. I remained a duchess, but all of the barons and mayors and religious holdings in my territory reported to the usurper. For a decade, I raided Ireland and northern France, carrying off loot and hostages for ransom. Building myself a great hoard, I waited until the right moment. Eventually, the usurper became embroiled in a war in East Francia, fighting most of the still powerful Karling family. With his armies weakened, I hired mercenaries and I struck at his capital, assaulting it and all of his holdings. He tried to bring back his armies, but my own force outnumbered his almost four to one, and he was crushed. He died in battle, and I imprisoned his brother and heir; I banished him from my realm, reclaiming my rightful titles as head of the Norse faith and Queen of Denmark.  I have conquered Europe in Odin's name. I have forced the wives of my defeated foes to become my concubines, and I have shed oceans of blood in the name of women's rights. I have accidentally married my great-granddaughter and deliberately married my sister. I have served Popes and I have murdered Popes. I have been trained in the art of war by a Ronin. I have had misadventures involving a merry band of outlaws in my forests. I have restored the Roman Empire. I have murdered spouses for fun and profit. I have seen battlefields where the dead number in the tens of thousands, and fought wars where neither side could muster five hundred men. I have turned back the Mongol hordes, and I have watched in despair as they annihilated my armies. I have conquered Rome for Islam, and I have retaken Jerusalem for Christ. I have plotted, murdered, schemed, fabricated, built factions, sent bribes, hired mercenaries, raised armies, raised children, murdered children, arranged marriages, taken lovers, banished prisoners, executed prisoners, shown mercy to prisoners, died childless and alone, died with far too many children holding power and claims to the throne, and so much more.  If you approach Crusader Kings II as Risk with an annoying thing about people that you need to deal with every so often, you might have some fun, but you're missing out on the real game: Eugenics and Murder Simulator II. The game is totally not for everyone. It is NOT a game that people pick up quickly. But once you get into it, it's the deepest and most rewarding RPG ever made. It's about guiding a family through history, through the sinners and the saints, through the great kings and the terrible ones, it's about surviving all the multitudes of things that can go tragically wrong, and it's about the joy of crushing your enemies, to see them driven before you, and to hear the lamentation of their women.  As you might guess, I'm a fan. It really isn't for everyone, but if you have the patience to get to the point where you can take control of your own destiny there's really no game like it.

The most accessible of Paradox's flagship 'Grand Strategy Titles' may as well be it's best. Crusader Kings 2 is a Dynastic simulator set in a turbulent medieval Europe. The player takes control of a character and is tasked with creating a dynasty that will endure the test of time, political intrigue and backstabbing family members. Not unlike other Paradox GS games, the systems are quiet hard to grasp but in due course, one begins to appreciate the complexities and the possibilities they entail.   My personal GOTY for the year 2012 and favorite medieval mass murder simulator. Play it!  Latest Update 2016: Game's changed so much since launch. Still spectacular though.

I urge everyone who purchases this game to not throw in the towel after a mere couple of gaming hours. With over 11,000 buttons to click, terms to remember and legalities to learn, it is definitely more complex than your average hack-and-slash, but an extremely rewarding experience when you stick with it.   I would most likely compare this game to chess, especially its tutorial. When my grandfather taught me chess, he showed me all the cute little figurines, showed which way they could move and kept winning for seven years, until I finally mastered the game enough to beat him.   This is exactly how I feel like with CKII. I played through the tutorial, read several different guides and have an extremely helpful friend with over a 1000 hours of this game under his belt - and I still very vaguely grasp what I'm doing. My daughter is the wife of the Kaiser - good stuff - but is it - but who should I kill... That's what a fraction of a second of the game feels like.   All of this is emphasized by the fact that you literally don't know what you are supposed to do - you choose it, there are no built-in goals.   In conclusion, this game has an extensive learning curve. It takes time to master, but is very rewarding once you do.   8/10

WARNING: This game is not for everyone. The first 3 times I attempted to play CKII, I just kept the game paused while I looked through what seemed like hundreds of menus and tooltips for about an hour, then closed the game in exhaustion. You will need to learn many complex game systems, and you may also be inspired to study medieval history just to have a better understanding of a particular region, culture, religion, or style of warfare. If you have the discipline to learn it, this is a pretty fun title.  Once I finally started, I married a cousin for her inheritance, fought off a rebellion by my strongest vassal, then lost the crown when my brothers attacked my kingdom. When characters die, you keep playing as the chosen heir in the dynasty. Ultimately, my descendants went on to be Emperors. Except that feeble one who fell off a balcony. Total accident.
There isn't enough time on earth to play this game. So you just dream about it when you go to sleep.

My only complaint is the battle system. It's often just a frustration - which is why I was glad I didn't have to focus on it as a merchant prince of Venice.  (P.S. I only fell in love with this game when I stopped playing it as a pure strategy game, and played it for the immersive character interactions. Haven't been able to stop playing it since.)

I have now logged 100 hours with this game + countless more on other Paradox titles: from a personal standpoint, this is the best game Paradox has made. This is strange to say because it doesn't really cover my favorite time period - that would be Europa Universalis. But in CK2, playing as an individual ruler and having to deal with all the varied personalities that you encounter in your role gives the game a narrative and role-play element that sets it above the rest of the Paradox series. The struggle to keep up with claims, maintain a strong council, prevent your vassals from starting revolts, arrange politically advantageous marriages, assassinate liabilities in your court - it all feels like you're playing a medieval House of Cards, or perhaps more appropriately the first two seasons of Game of Thrones. You will do horrible things to preserve and advance your family in the world, and you will enjoy it. Kinslayer means little when you're Emperor.
