Similar to all of Paradox's other grand strategy titles, Crusader Kings 2 places you in the boots of one of the rulers of a medieval Duchy, kingdom or empire and playing from 1066 to 1453. The large difference between this grand strategy and Paradox's others, is that you actually play as a character, instead of the embodiment of a nation. Whenever you die, you play as whoever is in your line of succession. If someone who is not part of your dynasty is your heir and you die, it's game over. Along with this feature, you must also manage your family as well as your vassals, keeping them happy. Nothing is more annoying than having to open up the vassal tab, sort them by the lowest opinion and then having to funnel money to 6 people to keep them happy, only to have them send you a message, labeling you a pretender of the throne a few minutes later. Something in the game is still appealing however, and is making me reccomend it.

Where to start? My steam stats aren't helpful, because I originally owned the GamersGate version of it and only recently had it migrated to steam. Nevertheless, I would estimate that this is the single game I've played the most since its release a couple of years ago.  2 important things have been the main contributors. The 'roleplaying' element is strong in this one. Taking the heritage of the original Crusader Kings, where the characters and their family relationships, rivalries and complex courts helped shaped the success of your dynasty in its rush to acquire titles, CK2 has let the concept blossom. You interact with characters - whether those in your own court and demesne or other families and title-holders, plotting against them, marrying them, sending assassins to help a title pass closer to one of your dynasty. There are lots and lots of events, random and semi-random to guide the freeform story taking place.  Secondly, Paradox have a fantastic DLC/update structure in place. Supported by paid DLC of two types, they have improved the game for two years already (and going strong for more), adding new mechanics and refining old ones. Major DLC usually involved adding a category of playable characters (originally only Christian feudal rulers available), but many of the core mechanics have just gone into the patches which have been going strong all this time. Cosmetic DLC has also been good and now well-priced for a quid or so.  It does take a little bit of effort to get into, and a Let's Play from youtube is highly recommend to get started, but if you're up for some personality-laden strategy, I don't know why you haven't already given this a go?!
It has some learning curve - after 18 hours, i'm still learning things and making rookie mistakes - but after you manage to get in it, it can be very satisfying.

One of the best, most addicting games on Steam. Short of Civ V and Skyrim, I think this is the game I have clocked the most hours on on Steam. You can make the game challenging for yourself, or just see what kind of crazy alternative history scenarios you can create.   The expansions (the DLC that cost a bit more than the others) have crazy value and the other dlc you can buy is just nice toppings if you care about what they have. I myself have mostly bought the songpacks, because I love the music they bring, but you can enjoy the game entirely without the packs. The expansions unlock more play options in the game, so I highly recommend you get them at least after you've played the game for a bit, as they are complete gamechangers.  Heck, if there's a deal like I'm seeing right now for winter sales, pay a little extra for the CKII Collection and get most of the stuff cheap. Right now the base game is 9,99€ and the collection, which includes at least four expansions and a lot of content packs is 19,99€. What a deal! That said, the base game is certainly worth the full price too.  What better review for the game than to give some real stories of great moments?  1. One of my earliest crazy alternate history scenarios was this: I started as the King of Scotland. Eventually I ended up (through intrigue and deceit) being married to the Empress of Byzantium (one of the most prestigious positions in the historical setting). This of course resulted in my daughter becoming Queen of Scotland and Empress of Byzantium.  2. With the Legacy of Rome expansions you can achieve one of the most rewarding things you can ever do in gaming. You can start off as a count in the Byzantine Empire and slowly make your way to becoming Emperor. You'd think that'd be enough, but no. You can then proceed to invade Jerusalem, Alexandria and other holy lands thus restoring the Pentarch and making Orthodoxy the de facto form of Christianity, allowing you to outright turn Catholism into a heresy! But wait, there's more. You are Emperor of Byzantium, also known internally as Rome. It's time to make everyone accept you as the Emperor of Rome. How? Reclaim the old areas, invade Rome and recreate the Roman Empire! First Rome, then the world.  3. The Empire of Scandinavia!

I'm a sandboxer, so I like the soft-moddability of the game. Plus, I get to learn a little history and geography along the way. My biggest project that I would love to figure out is to be able to create a 'minor title' like prince, but have it show as the title for vassal kings. My goal is to incorporate the 'missing' noble ranks into the existing ones in the game.  My plan would be to make it so a Baron that holds 2 or more baronies w/o holding a higher title would be Viscount (primary title); Counts that hold 2 or more counties w/0 holding a higher title would be Marquis (primary title), and vassal kings would instead be Grand Duke (if not of your dynasty) or Archduke (if from your dynasty) of (primary kingdom title).   If this could be done in a mod, or better yet incorporated into the regular game, I would be THRILLED.

Hello Steam, here's my short review.  Positive: Very challanging game. Takes quite alot of time to learn it sufficiently just to be able to play properly. Once you learned the game, you can set goals for yourself to strive for. Personally I like to fight for achievements, so that is my goal. This can only be done in hardmode which means you can never go to an earlier save to re-do an earlier mistake or anything. You can only go forward and if it means the end, then your game has ended and you have to start over. You can choose wherever you start so there's always that new feeling about the game.  Negative: The negative points are the amount of DLCs, there's actually too many and 50% of them are so tiny that they should just smack all of those together in one DLC pack (Units and portraits for example). At this point it would be wrong of me not to suggest this game.  PROS  It's a grand strategy that focuses on managing your family, your friends, your acquaintances, your court, and then once you have all that in order you begin expanding your horizons to snooping into the business of your friends, family, enemies, and total strangers whose land you desire.  The graphics are more than what you usually see in games like this.  The sounds have that nice quality where they're not repetitive or annoying, but rather invoke response cues as to what's happening. When a character is born or dies you immediately know before the text telling you. If you'd like something else there are nice workshop mods for it, but base is satisfactory.  The music is pleasing and I would go so far as to describe it as relaxing. It always seems to be the right tempo.  The mechanics of managing the strength of your genepool and family traits are what is so addictive for me personally. I really get a feel for my characters and it allows me to roleplay them more than what I had expected from the genre. It's what will continue adding another couple hundred hours likely for a long time to come.  CONS  The multiplayer is incredibly fussy and most games result in crashing due to networking issues or come out unresolved in my experience, but I still play multiplayer because it's usually a few hours in and we start a new story the next time we play. Saving and reloading that save to continue is feesible, but sometimes too much of a hassle for my lot of friends.  The price tag. It repulses many because they feel as though they may miss out without the DLC and I understand, but here's a real kicker: If your friend has any DLC and hosts a game then you get to experience the DLC without purchasing.  As for the singleplayer aspect of needing DLC I suggest getting it on sale and knowing which DLCS you need to buy to get the most out of the game.  Recommended for gameplay/mechanics:  Sword of Islam - $10 - Adds Muslims as a playable religion.   Legacy of Rome -$5 - Adds many features that I take for granted now.  Old Gods - $15 Improves revolts. Older starting date. Pagans, Zoroastrians, and some nice events.  Sons of Abraham - $10 - Adds Jews. Adds on to Muslims and Christian religions as well.   Charlemagne - $15 - Family chronicle (A history of your gameplay that's really nice.), earlier starting date, adds Zunists, and the ability to create a custom kingdom.  Way of Life - $8 -(Loosely recommended. Changes gameplay a fair bit. Best experienced without first. Adds more roleplay depth and ability to define your character and their actions, but the NPCs use the mechanics as well so it changes the feel of base game, but I like it.)  Total cost including base game: $93.00  Your initial reaction is probably 'Ninety-three dollars!?' and I know. It seems outrageous, but I have five hundred hours and let me break down my rationalization of that.  The average price of a movie ticket is like $8.50 for about one and a half to two hours of entertainment.  The average price of a game of bowling is $10.00 per person roundabout. (It's been a while, so bare with me.)  In comparison I have a very high expectation of how much entertainment I should get from a videogame and I roughly put it at an hour per dollar spent. If I buy a new console or platform game and it is sixty bucks I expect sixty hours of gameplay from the title. The true gems are those that shatter that expectation to pieces.   CKII has given me five times my expectation and investment and continues to rack up more time. My initial one hundred and fifty hours were off the base game alone.  All things considered I owe it to Paradox and to my fellow gamers to strongly recommend this game.

TLDR at bottom  I awake as the King of Kent in 769. My dejure lands are ruled by independent vagabonds who dare rule their lands without bending the knee. I swallow my pride and borrow gold from the Jewish lenders of my realm and hire the saxon mercenary band to retake my rightfull lands. After defeating the lord of Sussex in a six month campaign, the lord of Surrey quickly decides to bend his knee. Unsatisfied, I turn my ire north to the lands of East Anglia. I send my chancellor to prove my claims on these lands and he finds much success. Using what remains of my mercenary forces, I quickly take the lands of the former King of East Anglia, throttling his pitifully small army with my vastly larger forces.  A war of succession breaks out in Mercia and I decide to support the much smaller rebel forces, with just enough support to drain both sides of their levies. My chancellor, a devout vassal and believer in my cause, has seen fit to begin writing documents showing my divine right to the lands of Mercia as well. Ten years of conflict in Mercia, and my claim is now well supported by the people of Mercia. I quickly send my army in to end the war, securing the title for the rebel king. However, his reign does not last long as my armies swiftly return to Mercia to press my own claim. At the age of 56, I have united many of the minor kingdoms of England, but my dream to unify the whole will not be fulfilled. As I lay dying from a terrible illness, my only son, Oswine, ascends to the throne in my stead.  Oswine's first priority is to deal with the troublesome King of Wessex, who has taken the ill belief that the lands he occupies do not belong to the Kingdom of Kent. After a bloody conflict claiming a large portion of both our forces, Oswine emerges the victor, slaying the enemy king on the field of battle and emerging as the sole Anglo-Saxon king in southern England. He is the first king to style himself as the King of England, and sends word to all other lords of England to bend the knee, or face swift retribution. Hwice and Lancaster submit without a fight, but Northumbria persists in its stubborn idea of independence. After gathering support from his vassals, Oswine leads a great host to smash the Northumbrian armies with the help of the Picts and redistributes the lands to the loyal families of his court. Seeing opportunity, he invites the third son of the late King of Cornwall to his court, granting him lands in northern England in exchange for leal service. Soon after, this new lord's claim on Cornwall is pressed, and the newly crowned Duke of Cornwall bends the knee as sworn vassal and defender of the realm.  But trouble is brewing in the north, the Picts are fighting a brutal civil war, and Oswine's allies are on the losing side of things. He gathers his men and leads a host north to assist, but he is ambushed by enemy raiders from distant lands. These raiders have come in great numbers and manage to mortally wound Oswine. His last few months are full of pain and agony at the loss of his hand. King Oswine, first King of England dies a maimed cripple leaving three sons to contend for the throne.   And that is just the first two characters in my campaign. There are many more stories to be had, many playthroughs. No other game has ever inspired me to create stories surrounding the happenings in my game. CK2 is hands down the best game I have ever played. If you are a fan of grand strategy, if you are a fan of roleplaying, if you are a fan of the medieval era, this game is what you have been waiting for.  It will be a challenge at first to learn the mechanics, but once you figure them out you are able to fabricate pretty much any kind of story you like. The AI isn't the smartest but is decent enough at backstabbing and finding weakness that it presents a moderate challenge when you have no idea what you are doing/start pretty powerless. I personally enjoy modding some of the files to make it even harder, increasing disease presence and opinion modifiers for AI, making them hate you even more. This is the kind of game that once you learn the mechanics, if you all you care about is strategical gameplay and your everlasting godlike judgement of what's best for the realm than you will think it isn't all that challenging even at high difficulties. It does take a while to get to that point, but you can still have a lot of fun just trying to role play the character you have. If they are cruel and ambitious, murder everyone on your way to the top. If they are charitable and humble, try giving away more land than you have to. Chaste and zealous? Be celebite. See the game gets a lot harder when you choose to the things the character probably would actually do based on their traits, rather than simply trying to win no matter what. At least, that's where all my hours have gone to, creating stories like the one above.  Very fun game, worth every penny.

My nominee for 'Just five more minutes' award 2016.  This is a dynastic simulation which comes well recommended. It will eat up much of your life, I started one game and lost 70 hours to it. I don't know what will happen if I start another. It is filled with DLC and purchasing a complete version of the game will cost about 150 USD. However, these DLC's drastically expand and change the gameplay into something much different from what it was on release and will continue to do so in the future.  To describe Crusader Kings, you are a dynastic lord, a count, duke, king, or emperor. There is no real win or lose situation other than to keep playing. Your assumed goal is to proliferate your dynasty into other families, marry into wealthy dynasties, and set things up so your successor will be in the best position to inherit the kingdom. Your real goal is to screw around and mess things up in whatever way your hubris takes you, sleep with your lord's wife, sell your daughter to a polish lord, cage one of the great houses of Venice and sell them to the Egyptians, whatever your fancy takes you. Everyone in the game, right down to the courtiers and peasant rebels, are individuals with their own stats, aspirations, goals, and families. Manipulating their desires and maneuvering to get into power will make you personify each of these people, especially when they betray you. You will scream 'You ♥♥♥♥♥! Did you forget who put your ♥♥♥ on that throne!?' at your computer over some plot.  The interface is bare and the map figures are not much to look at, this suits the type of game this is just fine. There is a lot of depth, economy, trade, alliances, holdings, relationships between all the NPC's. It will take time to figure out the many gameplay nuances, what holdings are valuable, who makes a desirable courtier, how to fill out your desmene, and other gameplay nuances. None of these are easy to figure out and usually come over the course of repeated failure and checking guides and faqs. This level of complicated combined with the directionless character of the game will turn people away and I don't blame them too much for doing so.  The largest issue I find with the game is the sheer amount of DLC this game has. It has been released gradually over the years since this game has been released and update several gameplay functions and expand several parts of the map. On release, Crusader Kings II only covered Catholic Christian feudal kingdoms in Western Europe starting from the Middle Ages. Now, it includes Central Africa, India, Asia, their religions, and timelines going as far back as the beginning of Charlemagne along with the different type of governments - nomadic, tribal, Indian, Islamic, and city-state. The down side is that gathering all the things which do this will require you to sink 150 USD or so on a purchase of the game. It's no small matter and were it not for the thousands of hours you can sink into the game and the replayability each of the DLC's add, I wouldn't recommend it. Even without DLC, the core game remains a solid game which will leave you with many, many hours of your life gone. If you find you enjoy what you play, you can add a DLC for a different civilization and replay from there.   This is a solid grand strategy game with a lot of attention to detail and a lot of care put into its mechanics and personality. The detail will be off putting to some and desirable to others. If you are a fan of grand strategy this is definitely one to pick up.

If this ain't helpful for making a decision, i don't know what will be...

Crusader Kings II is a Medieval kill-all-infidels-and-die-from-the-plague-em-up, and it's a pretty solid game by itself although I would strongly reccomend getting the following DLC: The Old Gods (because everyone needs a little human sacrifice in their lives) Way of Life (because you get to seduce your sister and become a crazy fanatic possessed by the devil but that's okay because you're a master boardgamer!) Legacy of Rome (because the pope can go suck on my Byzantine nuts) Sword of Islam (because kebab is stronk (until the pope decides to attack)) and maybe Rajas of India (because who doesn't want control over an IT Tech Support Empire)  With that said, It must be said that this game has an insane learning curve curvier than yo' mama and the tutorial won't teach you anything. The way to learn to play is by checking out some let's plays on YouTube or by simply learning for yourself.  This game's strong point is with it's RPG elements and the way the story of your dynasty plays out. The objective of the game is to make sure your dynasty survives until 1453 and getting as much prestige and piety along the way. You can play as any earl/duke/king/emperor from Europe to the Sahara to the Middle East to India to Eurasia from the mid 8th century (if you have the Charlemagne DLC) to 1453. You play as one person and when said person dies you continue playing as their heir, but if your heir is not of your dynasty or you don't have one, then it's game over. A sure way of getting as many heirs as possible is by being a ♥♥♥♥ and legitamising as many of your ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s as you see fit, however this does lead to bitter rivalries among your children. Despite trying to keep your dynasty alive, there are no real goals and this is where the RPG elements shine through. You can play as an earl and work your way up through the fuedal system to king/emperor, you can expand your lands and become king or emperor, and my favourite is playing as Byzantium and setting my sights on restoring the Roman Empire and mending the great schism (which is why you need Legacy of Rome plus some other features it adds to Byzantium). You can also plot to kill people, ♥♥♥♥ your cousin, care for your family, ♥♥♥♥ your cousin, learn the secrets of the stars, ♥♥♥♥ your cousin, and you can ♥♥♥♥ your sister!  If you're a history nerd like me you will have endless fun with CKII and if you're also into the Renaissance and early Industrial Era then you should also pick up Europa Universallis IV and get a converter so your CKII save can go directly into EUIV, which is nice.  10/10 - would marry my sister again

Fantastic role-playing strategy game which is extremely satisfying and very fun to play. Steep learning curve but totally worth investing the time as when it clicks it is so enjoyable. I recommend watching YouTube videos by the likes of Quill18, Tekkor, Arumba and/or Northernlion to help you find your feet. I'm enjoying it so much because the game creates some great stories and provides a lot of fun role-playing opportunities. I can see myself continuing to put a lot of hours into this amazing game.  CKII is not a typical strategy game as it has heavy role-playing aspects and is about managing a dynasty and acting on behalf of characters rather than countries. The game creates some great scenarios and you can get really involved in the stories that it generates. It might be that you start as some petty little count trying to amass power through whatever cunning and devious means that you can, much like playing out an episode of Blackadder! Or it could be that you are a powerful king ready to destroy those who might attempt to dethrone you. You easily become engrossed in the stories and the petty squabbles with your vassals or your overlords.   It seems worth mentioning the DLC here as it can seem somewhat overwhelming to a new player. I regularly get asked which DLCs I recommend and if any add vital things to the game experience. Ultimately, a great deal of the DLC is cosmetic (portraits, shields, units and extra music) so none of these are needed at all but you might feel it is nice to freshen up the game later on with some new music or portraits after you've been playing for 100s of hours. I must mention the music here, which is absolutely excellent (it is composed by Andreas Waldetoft who has also produced high quality music for EUIV and other Paradox titles). Anyway, regarding these minor DLCs, you can always wait for another sale on Steam for this kind of thing and pick them up at a super cheap price. CKII tends to go on sale a lot.  The DLC that is actually significant in terms of game play is as follows:  - The Old Gods (one of the best DLCs because it adds a new start date in 867 and the opportunity to play various pagan rulers, with an emphasis on the Vikings, which is an absolute blast)  - The Republic (ability to play Merchant Republics such as Venice, Genoa, Pisa etc. so only really needed if you want to do that in the game)  - Legacy of Rome (this is definitely worth picking up as it adds some useful stuff, not least the ability to use retinues to have standing armies. It's one of the cheaper of the main DLCs)  - Sword of Islam (makes Muslim rulers playable and adds a whole bunch of events and mechanics specific to them - so only needed if you want to get into playing a Muslim ruler)  - Sons of Abraham which adds more depth to the Abrahamic religions (Christianity, Islam and Judaism).   - Sunset Invasion (this is a fictional and non-historical add-on that I've never used - bit of a strange release from Paradox for this game - you don't need this at all unless it strikes you as being interesting)  - A smaller DLC worth mentioning is the Ruler Designer, which is quite fun too, allowing you to create your own ruler with traits etc. I mostly play as the historical characters but it can be nice to throw together a custom character for a bit of fun.  - Recently, they have added the Rajas of India (making Indian characters playable), Charlemagne (with a new start date of 769) and Way of Life (a role-play DLC).   Ultimately, you can pick and choose what you are interested in with the DLC. It might be that you have a certain interest in one of the DLCs but ultimately a huge amount of hours can be put into the base game with the vanilla 1066 start. You don't desperately need any of the DLC but I think the only thing that it would be nice (not essential) to have is The Legacy of Rome, in my opinion, for the reasons I outlined above.  My favourite DLCs are Legacy of Rome and The Old Gods. The latter is probably one of the best DLCs I have bought for a game. I've had such a blast with all of The Old Gods content. So much fun!
I don't know whatt happened to my life, but I think it was good.

I strongly recommend this game to everyone. It doesn't matter what your strategy preference is, this game is perfect and will bring at the best and worst in all of you. Look at how much i have played this game, i don't get much time to play games as i am at University but when i do this is the game i go to.   The game is a Grand Strategy game which means you do not take control of battles, instead you are in control of the state, deciding its politics and making sure that you become a pre-eminent power in Europe. Now that doesn't sound that as unique as the other games paradox have made, but as well as a grand strategy this is an RPG.   First of all the RPG elements are not like Mass Effect or Skyrim, they are event based which means you decide how certain events go and see where it takes you. You can become a benevolent ruler who is just and kind, or you can become a intricate web weaver, assassinating rivals and killing siblings. You can even become insane or/and possessed!  Now there is A LOT of DLC for this game and that can put you off. But this has not been pulled from the game (well most of it hasn't), instead they have been developed after the main game came out and add a variety of RPG enhancements and events. They also enable you to play different religions and cultures. The DLCs i would recommend are: Sword of Islam Legacy of Rome Old Gods Sons of Abraham Way of Life Charlemagne  They are all the major expansions except for Raja's of India and Republics which i found were a bit lacking and can be left out without any major changes. All the other Dynasty shield packs and song packs are totally optional (although if you are going to buy one song pack buy the Old Gods one).  This game is worth full price and will give you hundreds of hours of game content and will give you an experience you  will never forget. Also if you are unsure then wait for a steam sale and get the game and the major expansions for an incredibly cheap price!

Okay, this game? Seriously addictive. 59 hours play in a week is a testament to that. If you like strategy games, but Paradox's games seem a little too obtuse, I wholly urge you to play this game to dip your feet into the pool. You won't be disappointed.

What can I say, this game is so good I don't even know where to start to describe it. Even without the huge load of DLCs and workshop items that add infinite customization (whole new maps, for example) this game has enjoyable political and diplomatical systems and goes good with the military side, giving you the feeling of growth as the time goes by and your land becomes larger.  I like how you can screw up with a few bad decision or how the system can screw you up with a random event with no way to prevent it, since it's fun to recover from something bad after all. I like how every character has an opinion on every other character and the intricate system that manages traits and stats making every person unique. I like the hierarchical system with different levels of nobles giving you the real feel of climbing the power ladder, or failing trying. I like how wars are managed, the fact that you wage war to conquer something, then you can take whatever you want during the war but you only keep the something you started the war for. I like the dinasty system, family trees always win for me, and with the possibility to forge alliance by strategical marriages there's no limit on what you can do.  At start you feel like you can do almost nothing. You have a weak army, comparable to the ones of your neighbours, you have low cash, so you can't build anything, you have no vassals (assuming you like starting small and ramping up), but the more you advance, the more possibilities come up. And still you can destroy everything you build by a bad election choice for example, or by timing badly a war, or stuff like that. The fact that the game lasts for a set number of years makes it like there is no actual victory, but only personal achievements to grab during every single game. Of course you can lose, like I'm about to do on my second big game for insulting my liege thinking he was my neighour, silly me!  Totally suggested! And buy DLCs too, when you get the hang of the game, they really add nice stuff to do. And don't forget there is also a demo, I mean, a game with a demo is really good, since you can try it out for free without risking to buy something that then disappoints you. Get it already!
If you have ever wanted to assasinate your children to ensure a perfect lineage, this game is for you.

What can I say? It's hard to get your head around the controls and rules, but after taking time with the game, you get emmersed in such a fascinating world of your own. The only thing I have to say that multiplayer can be kind of a bore if you don't have friends who own the same game or checksum, cause its already hard enough to find a game, only to get kicked by the host because you weren't the friend he ws waiting for.  Otherwise, a great game :D

Great game with intricate strategy. Provides hundreds of hours of replayability and an infinite array of possibilities of gameplay, with an incredible freedom that is characteristic of Paradox games. It is of course not perfect historical-wise but it is really deep when it comes to that aspect with tons of historical events. There are also great mods and some really nice dlcs to add to that content, although the game is pretty complete by its own. For starters in this genre of strategy games or in Paradox games in general, Crusader Kings 2 should prove the best choice. It is not so difficult to get into and has the hole high degree of personalization of the strategy with all the rpg aspects of the game that makes some players praise it as the best game of Paradox. It is in reality a very different game from the other Paradox games such as Europa Universalis or Victoria that provides an unique kind of fun as you control the rulers instead of the nations. I personally think that despite some flaws it emcopasses very well the time spam of the Middle Ages and couldn´t recommend more for any player of strategy that is fond of that period of history and of the presence of rpg elements in games in general. Finally, don´t bother with the original Crusader Kings as this one is far superior - something that is not very common nowadays with all the awful sequels we are seeing.

So... I have finally passed 100 hours spent in this game. I'd say all of it was worth it. Through all of it, I was captivated and engrossed with my several fledgling kingdoms and dominating empires. Combining the depth of an RTS with the addictiveness of an RPG, this game is unique and brilliant. If you are someone who enjoys strategy games such as total war as well as RPGs, you should grab this game when it is on a steam sale. It is 100% worth it at full price, but it is one of the most frequently on-sale games on steam so you wont have to wait long. The learning curve appears steep at first, but after you look around at all the menus it's rather intuitive. My advice is to watch a lets-play on youtube, visit the forums, and don't be afraid to spend 3-4 hours experimenting and not knowing what the hell to do. Thats exactly how I got into the game, and it was worth it.

For me, this game is perhaps the most gripping medieval political simulation I've ever played. I once even had my ideal heir murdered by my second wife so the first son I had with her could be my heir. Plot your way to the top of feudal power and entrench your dynasty in a historical sandbox. The greatest 'Grand Strategy' game ever produced. It doesn't exist a game which achieves this quality, historical reference and complexity.  I played it more than 1'100 hours and I'm far away to get tired of playing Crusader Kings II and I'm very far away of having played all the interesting kingdoms, clans or religions.   Each game differs so much from the last one. The dynasty mustn't die out - to marry the right wife is essential in order of a successor and strategic alliances. Subordinated nobility aspires as much my crown as legitimated successors or relatives. Where is the greatest danger? A rising neighbour, the superior mussulmans, the mongolian horsemen, a more and more powerful subordinate, a second wife, who prefers her son as successor instead of the first ones, maybe an intrigeur who has already started an assassination in order to achiev his political goals? Fortunately I have my counsellors - but can I really trust them or are they already involved in a complot against me?? There exist much more aspects.  It's not always easy to locate the risks - everything can change from one day to the other. This are medieval times. And if I loose my crown I'm the one, among other rivals, who aspires it...

1776/10  Excellent, the historical feels and ability to play as the Emperor of Brittania in 1066 as an Aztec-cultured ethnic Norse Muslim makes it quite the game.

Although the learning curve proved to be slightly steeper than the Europa Universalis games, there is nothing like that feeling of realizing that at any given moment you find out what something actually does, you now have gained a deeper understanding of this game. Though this happens pretty often, it never takes away from the reward factor right up until the day you come to understand the game fully.  It is a versatile and fascinating game with plenty of room for variety and never quite the same playthrough, what with all the geographical and policy-based changes one can adopt during a playthrough. Regardless of difficulty settings, this game can become nightmarishly difficult if you get overeager/greedy and people join forces against you. On terms of realism, you'll find few better simulations than this title. It illustrates the era amazingly and puts you in the mood - if you're a history buff, this needs to be in your collection. Although I'm shamelessly biased when it comes to Paradox Interactive, I still think a round of applause is in order for another historical simulation game triumph by this magnificent company.

My father, the Count of Vermandois, had - through judicious marriage policy - won a Duchy for his only son, upon the death of my mother, the former Duchess. I had been living with my own wife, the Countess of Julich, when my mother passed, and I moved to Luxembourg to take control of my new Duchy. My wife stayed in Julich, keeping my only son at her side. This did not represent a problem until some years later, when I realised the boy was being tutored by a German. My wife was clearly attempting to raise the boy as a German, and not a good Frank. She refused to send the boy to my court, to learn the ways of a proper Frank. What to do? I could leave the boy in her care, and hope that he stayed true to his fathers blood, the blood of Charlemagne - or I could, as her nominal, if not actual overlord - invade her lands, taking my son and her County at the same time. It was my right as both a father and a Duke! Or... or... should I focus on the long game, and win the other Dukes and Counts of the HRE to my side... I was born the son of a Count. Could I die an Emperor?

I enjoy this game. I REALLY want to love it- but honestly, I just find it so difficult! Perhaps it's just because I lack a talent for the more martial/technical aspects of the game, but it seems that, regardless of where I begin to play, it always ends with me getting frustrated and doing something else. I love the politics, the match-making, the cloak-and-dagger aspects of this game- however, no matter what strategy I take or how I try to play the situation, either other kingdoms or my own people turn against me and put me in an impossibly hard-to-win predicament.   If you enjoy a challenge and are relatively good at strategic war games, I would definitely recommend this game. Even if you aren't, I would still tell you to give it a try- just try not to take it too seriously for your first two or three games. That way, if it becomes too difficult, you won't be sitting there, swearing at your computer like I usually am after a few hours!

What more is there to say that hasn't been said already about this game?  CK2 is a game that tells the story of your family while you build your empire. It's got an extremely steep learning curve and when I started it up for the first time I was immediately overwhelmed by the number of features and lack of anyone telling me what to do. But that has also turned out in the long run to be its greatest strength and the reason I have put 560+ hours into this game. You decide what you want to do. Want to restore the Roman Empire? Sure. Take your Norse Viking raiders south and sack Venice? Why not? Mend The Great Schism and see Christianity as the dominant religion across Europe, North Africa and the Middle East? You can do that too.  All those possibilities and more are within the core game itself. Then come the limitless options that the mod community have created for CK2. The ease of modding that Paradox has allowed and nurtured has spawned a great many mods that play like their own full game.   Bottom line is that this game is complex and overwhelming in the beginning (enough so that I didn't pick up the game again until days later after my first attempt) but well worth the learning curve and provides great value and entertainment.

Absolutely fascinating game. You can elaborately plot and scheme because the mechanics allow it, but don't neccesarily lay it out for you. I'll give you an example. I built an empire and installed an antipope in Rome. The previous pope was a personal friend of mine, so after he was displaced I accepted him into my court.  Because he was a celibate, he never sired any heirs. When He died of old age with no survivors, I inherited his fortune of $58,000.  You can dig deep into lineages and claims and carefully orchestrate fruits to fall in your lap. Plans that may take a decade of careful diplomacy and delicate alliance and marriage can all come tumbling down when someone contracts syphilis or falls from a horse. It's definitely a game for people who love to strategise.

If you love strategy games with a rpg touch like I do, then you will love this game! Now I am a little bias, but this game is simply the best stategy game of all time... OF ALL TIME!  You play as an individual, head of a preset house (created house if you get the ruler designer dlc). You ultimate goal is what you want it to be.   Want to start of as a lowly count/countess working his/her way up the social pecking order by getting the nobles of the realm to support your forged claim to your neighbor's title? You can do that! Or say you want a crown on YOUR crown, so you bribe the nobles of the realm to join your faction to force the King to change the inheritance laws of the kingdom from primogenture to elective so you can put your name up for nomination? You can do that too! Or say you want to start of as a King/Sultan/Caliph/Emperor and fight those very vassals who would try such a treasonous act, YOU CAN!  I can go on and on about the multitude of things you can do, from growing your family tree by marrying a wealthy duke's daughter so your son will have a claim to the duke's lands when he finally kicks the bucket. From growing old, dying and passing everything to you son, which as the new head of the house you will now play as. Say, what about your daughter? She is more capable than your current character's son! Change the inheritance laws to give you daughter a claim.  Use diplomacy to normalize relations, marriage to seal alliances, war to conquer you enemies, intrigue to assassinate your rivals, piety to gain the favor of the Pope/Caliph/Grand Priest, it goes on and on.  The rpg element is enhanced by a large and ever growing event system which helps form your current character's personality by gaining new traits, or losing them, based on your decisions. Educate your children yourself or have them assigned to a trusted retainer. Grow your influence and power by inviting talented people to your court and appointing them to your council. Hand out titles to your vassals to keep them loyal, or seize their titles when/if they plot against you. Deliver justice or Cry Havoc, and let slip the dogs of war!  This game has MANY dlcs, all of which expand the cultures, immersion, music, appearance, gameplay, features and possibilities in some way. I highly recommend the culture portrait DLCs, ruler designer, major gameplay DLCs like the Horse Lords, Old Gods, ect. But they are all good and imo modestly priced.  Okay I could say more, but I wanna play Crusader Kings II now! Which brings me to my only real beef with this game... its extremely addicting and you will lose much needed rest and sunlight! Just stick your head out of your room every now and then to let everyone know you are still alive.

My Opinion of Crusader Kings II

As an avid fan of grand strategy games, this is the one i would recommend to get if you are new to the genre.   To me Crusader Kings II is a game about creating  interesting stories . I'll elaborate: The most interesting moments in this game usually are so random and unexpected, that when you tell other people who play CK2 they will be genuinely interested and intrigued by them.  It really feels like anything and everything can happen . It is total chaos. Sometimes EVERYTHING goes wrong, for instance your heir turns out to be an ugly midget homosexual who inherits the Holy Roman Empire and everyone hates him so much that the Holy Roman Empire just falls apart.   Learning curve wise it is a lot simpler than the EU franchise or god frobid, Hearts of Iron, but i feel that speaks more to the complexity of other grand strategies. It will stil take your at least a week to get most of the mechanics down. It might even take longer.   This leads to the final part of my review - the expansions. This game features a plethora of  great expansions  that truly change the pase of the game. They add more interesting mechanics and make the game even more interesting, . I'd recommend getting the entire shebang of major expansions as a bundle when it's on sale. It's definitely worth it.   Overall i think this is a great game and  it gets even better when you play with friends .   If you like complex strategy games and empire management, i think you will love this. :)

After owning this game for a couple of months I believe I can share my opinion with the community.  1. What is the game about? This game contains alot of history from the real world and allows you to control the outcome of. Ofcourse some people will not understand what i am saying so let me give you an example. If you want to play as Any of the leaders your outcome could change from what really happened, Its stratigy game that you need to think as a leader not a player. As a player your aim is to rule your country and stretch your dynasty as long as possable. If you die with no heirs the game will end and you will have a score and a summary of the dynasty you beat in score.  2. What happens if I die in the game? If you die as a ruler for any reason and have no heir the game ends. You need to have an heir to continue playing when you die.  3. Why should i buy this instead of any other game like Civ or Cursadar castle? Well this game is unique because of its features that make the game come alive, you dont die in civ as a leader you get conquered same in Crusadar castle, but in cursader kings your main focus is your right to choose. If you want to conquer people then thats your focus if you want to try and get a heir your focus, the game gives you the freedom to choose what  You  want to choose and thats a feature other games do not have. The game lets you have your freedom to choose, but there is always a backside like in real life you choose and your choice has its effect, Its the same in game. So lets say you attacked england as ireland and you had enough men, but you though that england didnt have an alliance with scotland, but then they got one as soon as you declared then I can assure you you will need to get that pot of gold and give it to enland and scotland so they dont give you the  D .  Summary: If you like history and stratigy like me then this is the game for you. It is really original and very fun and i recommend to Buy it right now.

One of the best and deepest game never played! Not only you have to take care about your state, expanding it and defend it, but also of your dynasty. Be sure to have good marriages and ensure its continuity.  - the game has two main levels of game, on the first you have to take care of your state, reach your aim, defend your state and so on, on the other level you need to care about your dynasty. Not only have an heir, but have a good hair, make marry your heirs to the hairs of other kingdom to acquire them or gove in marriege your doughter to forge new alliances. - Your player is evolving. You need to develp him/her, train to have higher skills that allow you to have access to options in the events (such as persuasion with high diplomacy etc.). - You need to take care of the education of your children to have good heirs and good 'material' for the marriages. - Your vassals are very ambitious and you need to take care of them (both in the positive and negative way) to not face bigrebellions. - Great map with a lof of territories and possibilities to expand your realm. - Good managment of the religion. - You need to spend some times to understand the dynamics of the game, otherwise you cannot enjoy it at all the levels and have a great game experience.  It's the best game of Paradox. Absolutely a must for everyone loves this kind of games and this brand.

Crusader Kings 2 is one of the, if no the, best strategy game i have ever played. At the beginning of the game you are shown an accurate political map of europe for the start date you choose to start in, you then choose a character to play as, you may start as the grand basileus of the Byzantine Empire and fight back the invading Seljuk sultunate in a glorious battle with the varangian guard at your side, or simply a lowly count of devon trying avoid the norman and norwegian armies attacking anglo-saxon England (in the 1066 start date). I have played over 200 hours of this game so I am speaking from experience and I strongly recommend you ignore the reviewers who have played between 1-10 hours of the game as it it NOT long enough to repect the game for what it is. Positive aspects of the game: 1) very historically accurate characters and nations at the start of the game 2) many different events to keep the game interesting 3) many different interactions with your' subjects 4) with no dlc there is 400 years of medieval history to play through, with all dlc there is 700 years! 5) In depth medieval politics and accurate feudal, iqta, tribal and nomadic government systems 6) with all dlc activated you can see more mechanics, subject interactions, alternative history events (sunset invasion) and new eras to play in, however this leads to my first gripe with the game...  1) the DLC, so many DLCs, now first things first i dont mind the dlc in the game thought there is a lot im perfectly fine with the major add ons, however i think it is pure greed that after you pay the £15 for the newest expansion you have another £4 to pay for the new unit sprites and portraits that come with it! 2) not for those who want a complete historic experience, because as the game goes on you will see more and more alternative history events take place, like the norwegians taking england not the Normans in 1066. 3) to get the best experience out of the game i recommend the full game with all dlc, however this is very expensive so i recommend getting it from a discount site or in the sales.  Finally, this game is the most accurate medieval grand strategy game I have come across and I definately recommend it to anyone who likes strategy games, but as previously stated it is very expensive for the full experience so if you are a die hard strategy gamer i fully recommend the game, however if you are new to the strategy genre i would recommend a more welcoming game and a less expensive experience.

Our review begins in The year 1080- The Norman king Bohemund rules over all of Sicily.  Early in his reign, Bohemund falls ill, and it is thought that he will not survive. One fever-sick night, the king is struck by a sudden apparition: a strange man stands before him.   'King Bohemund, my name is David, ruler of England, ♥♥♥♥er of pigs, leader of the Conservative cult and the first of his name. I bring grave news'   Bohemund looked into the darkness through weary eyes, but even his plagued mind could distinguish otherwise. 'Thy mistakes himself sir, a fellow norman, William, rules England.'  David gave Bohemund a smug nod of the head. 'Perhaps in your time, but I rule many centuries from now. I have travelled through time to bring you warning of what's to come.'  Bohemund coughed, his body shook. At first he appeared not to hear, but then he said 'What hath gone so terribly asunder that thee hails me upon my deathbed?'  'You are not to die yet, king Bohemund. It shall be you that saves Christendom itself.'  Bohemund's eyes widened. 'What is this task thou sets before me?'  'The year will be 2016, the moral authority of Christ is failing throughout Europe, and greivious heresy has spread through the kingdoms. Yet the unstoppable tide of Islam advances.' David regarded Bohemund sincerely. 'Once again the Caliphs wage Jihad before us, yet no Christian coalition can muster.'   'Good God.' Muttered Bohemund.  'Instead the defence of the realm is left in the hands of a corrupt and oppressive puppet regime of Islam that goes by the name of: 'The EU.'  'Blasphemy! These be-eth lies thou puts before me!' The king cried.  'Alas, not.' Assured David. 'What's more, a terrible heresy known as 'Socialism' has rooted itself in our lands, and it is the work of Allah to be ascertain.' David paused, Bohemund looked at him with awestruck eyes.  'Together, the scourge of the EU and socialism have led our once great nations to surrender before The Jihad and allow open borders to the heretics.'   'But you, sir. Thy claimeth the king of England, surely you must lead the Crusade if no one else!'  'Not king, no, but I won't go into those details.' Said David. 'I am but a vassal of the tyrannous EU. They subjugated my once great nation near on half a century ago.'  'Alas. Alas.' Bohemund resigned.  'But all is not aloss...' David permitted.  'How so?'  'You, Bohemund. You must lead the Christians, as king of Sicily conquer all of Africa and crush the self proclaimed 'Fatimid Caliphate'. Only through your actions can the Dark Ages of the socialism heresy and tyrannous puppet empire of Islam, 'The EU' , be avoided.' David began to fade before Bohemund's very eyes.  'But David, how do I-'  'Do not fail me Bohemund. Do not fail your Christian brothers. You will know when the time is right.'  'But David, David wait!' But David was gone, and Bohemund was left alone in his chamber.   And king Bohemund followed his call to arms. Great swathes of Africa fell to Sicily, and it seemed that the terrible fate of 2016 was never to be. Alas, Mighty Allah stood by his subjects, and used the vile sorcery known to many as 'War ended inconclusively (Casus Belli no longer valid).'   It would be five years before Sicily's armies be ready to strike again, yet in that time much would change. The wrath of Allah did not end there, the 'Deus Vult' driven Bohemund was struck down by 'natural causes,' and history was doomed to the present which we see before us.

There are some games that age like wine, the patches and expansions and mods all adding up to make a classic game. Crusader Kings is not one of these games, it has aged like milk.  Each DLC delivers less than the one before, and despite the lessening scope of them they each are more buggy than the last. And these are not subtle bugs that only come out when a thousand players are running through every function of the game, these are as basic as tribal revolts being unable to raise their maximum troops because they don't know how to call up vassal allies.  I've heard that CK has only four devs left working on it, I can beleive it. When they try to deal with problems that derive from underlying design flaws like North Korea mode they don't have the resources to change this game from a blobbing simulator so they take the cheaper option on constricting players into a narrower and narrower playstyle so that they can't see that the emperor has no difficulty.  I was promised a dynasty simulator, and now I have given up on ever getting that, and ever giving paradox money again.

Solid medieval strategy game. Offers you the ability to play as both a major player or as a minor noble.  Things to be aware of: 1) The tutorial is not great. You're better off watching a guide on Youtube. 2) You don't need DLC, but several DLCs in particular do greatly expand the game- Way of Life, Legacy of Rome, and Sons of Abraham expand the options available to you in the core game, while other DLCs offer new start dates or the ability to play as a member of a different religion. Cosmetic DLC is mostly unnecassary, although you might want to pick up the Mongol and African Facepack when they're on sale since by default they share the middle eastern appearance which rubs a lot of people the wrong way. 3) The game does not shy away from the more brutal elements of history. Death and Disease are prominent. Religious Intolerance and Xenophobia is the norm. Murdering children who are in the way of your plans is a valid option. Marriage is a political tool, not a matter of love (Although circumstances can lead to a very happy arranged marriage for all parties). Female rulers are at a notable disadvantage because they can't lead armies and many of your vassals don't approve of a woman sitting on the throne. And yes, as the other reviews you see here no doubt mention, Incest is a thing, and even infants can be bethrothed to old men (Although you can't actually marry someone until their sixteenth birthday, so at least the squick factor is toned down). That being said, you can choose to be better than all this, and be a fair and wise ruler. Or you can run around aranging for little children to be somthered with pillows while cuckolding half of England's nobility. It's your choice.

Ah, I do love the peace of England right now, ruling from the county of Kent. Hey look, a small island! Wouldn't hurt to take that over, would it? Nah.... Oh... Wait... I'm not married either - If I don't get married soon I'll die with no heir, and the game will end.... Hm... Ooh, look at that! Norge Princess, she'll do fine. Rejected? Why? Oh and now you're declaring war? ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥. I guess my courtier will have to do. Why does she hate me? Let me gift her 20 gold. Ha! You like me now! Cheeky though. What? If I marry her I lose 200 prestige? There goes my dream of exaltion... Ah, finally, married and she's pregnant. I can foresee her birthing many of my heirs! What? Died in child labour? Oh for God's sake. Well at least my son will rule supreme, he'll lead England to ever victory and riches! Oh, right, the war... Norge soldiers closing in on my land, Islam soldiers retaliating.. Even the Holy Roman Empire? Okay, enough! I have to surrender. Now everything should be just fine. Oh, of course - I've lost all my land. Now I'm merely the Duke of Kent, this won't do! Well at least my vassals will help me reclai- Oh, right, not my vassals anymore... How about my allies? Of course my dearest brother will help? He's been excommunicated? I do hope he doesn't take it personally. What, now you're excommunicating me? How dare you! I shall retaliate! I'll convert to Buddhist. Oh dear, now I'm surrounded by an opposing religion. Hello all! Today I will review Crusader Kings II  Crusader Kings II is a game where you can play from 769 (With the Charlemange DLC) to 1337 This game is all about building the greatest dynasty and make sure you go down in the history books  What can you do in this game?  You can play as the Duke in England in 1066 and try to get the English crown for yourself  You can play as a merchant republic in Italy and try to build a mighty trade empire  You can play as pagan rulers to try and establish your very own religon You can play as a Bysantine Emperor and try to reform the roman empire and reclaim its borders  The Good: Large map to play on (Scotland to India) Many character's to play as Good timeline system Many different religon's to choose  Many ways to play the game  Great modding community  Excellent DLC (well mostly) Historicly accuate   The Bad: Alot of DLC (Over £100 for the best experience) Huge learning curve   Conlusion  Overall i think this is the one of the best games on steam if you can get all the DLC still worth it wothout them but DLC make this game alot better. This is the game I always come back to. While other games might give me a few days of enjoyment, when they're 'new game shine' wears off, this is the game I return to. This is the game that has been holding my interest for years.  Nothing else has the same combination of things to do. It has the war and development of a grand strategy game, but also the personal development and relationships of an RPG.   What's more, there is always something new to experience. A game as a French duke clawing for power in Western Europe has a very different feel from that of a Viking raiding across the North Sea or that of a Armenian king struggling to survive a Muslim onslaught. Depending on my mood, I can set up a slow game of carefully constructing marriage ties and improving my demense or I can set off on a whirlwind game of conquering and plundering.   I came into this as a veteran of other Paradox strategy games, such as Europa Universalis (my previous favorite game, before discovering this one), but if you've never played such a game before, CKII can certainly be a bit overwhelming. However, this is also not a game you need to become an expert in all at once. Picking a minor Irish count, for example, can allow for learning how the game works, while picking a more precarious position can increase the challenge later.  I have played this game for years and I have never finished a game, because 'finishing' is not what CKII is about. It's about enjoying the experience. The people and families in the game truly make this game more engaging than any other strategy game I play.

Thank you all who helped me play the game so that I could write a more meaningful review.  In the sake of not wasting your time I'll keep this short.  Gameplay: Has a very high early learning curve. Sadly I felt like after I got a good hang of the game and played for a bit, I got bored just before uniting Ireland and felt like the game was lacking something. But then I'm not inherently a fan of 'grand strategy' games for that same reason, they tend to feel bland and unfinished to me. If you like other Grand Strategy games, you may like this one.  Graphics: Straitforward, nothing flashy here but it's not going for that.  Music: Solid, a good instrumental track that is probably the best part of this game.  Reason for not reccomending: I find it extremely unethical to charge $40 for a main game like this, which by itself feels very unfinished compared to similar titles I've played like Medieval 2 Total War. However, that would easily be forgiven until I realized that the rest of the game is behind $160 of DLC! This is unacceptable and represents everything wrong with the current gaming market. It sickens me that companies would treat their customers like cash-cows and after purchasing and testing some of the DLC myself... I wasn't impressed with how little you get for what you're paying for and feels like it should have been part of the core game. So ultimately I cannot reccomend this game due to the developer's blatant disrespect for their customers, and because the only way we're going to stop the gaming market from going further down this pit of DLC-heavy, content-light games is to stop paying for it.  And putting my money where my mouth is, I can't return this title but I won't purchase any more games from this developer until they stop doing this rediculous practice. They not only crossed the line, they went 100 miles over it and stepped on the gamers who support their work in the process.  That said, that's my opinion, I thank you for your time. If you found this helpful, I'm glad. If you disagree with me, that's your right.

This game is amazing. The depth of intrigue and the plots are well worth the high, early skill curve. The excellent, tactical diplomacy and finesse required to build and manage a kingdom or empire is incredibly engrossing.  This says nothing, of course, of the immersion. I got the inspiration to write this review due to circumstances I just found myself in during a game.   I had a Chancellor who had been excellent at his job about the same age as my king. He was probably the sole reason I had been able to unify and maintain control over the kingdom of Ireland. He also educated most of the Irish Princes and anyone else I had at court who I thought had potential. As he got older, I replaced him with one of my talented sons but kept an eye on the guy because he was so skilled at diplomacy.  After my first successful invasion of Wales, I decided I needed a trustworthy and very diplomatic person to take over the first Duchy I had conquered over there. It wasn't going to be an easy job as the Welsh hated their conquerors with passion (so yea, I may have been caught successfully assassinating one of their Counts...). So I knew I was sending this old friend into a dangerous position.  But at the same time, I couldn't trust anyone else for the job. This was the only guy I could trust to quell rebellion in Wales and not turn around and attack me years later. So this lowborn peasant-ex-council-member, deservingly, became a Duke overnight.  But as a player, I found myself really hoping he would survive. Hoping that, not only would he manage to turn the Welsh anger away from my Kingdom, but also that he might thrive in his new fief and build his own dynasty.  Any game that can make me feel so part of it is worth its asking price.  Heartily recommend.

Fantasically deep game with loads of intrigue amongst family members. It is one of those games where things of interest keep cropping up all the time - usually just when you are about to pack in for the night. I haven't been a massive fan of some past Paradox games but this one is perfectly made. Anyone with an interest in history and Medieval times should try the demo. But if you do make sure you watch some video tutorials on YouTube before you dive in because this is not a game you can just pick up and play - but is really worth the effort of learning it. The sheer amount of gameplay provided in this game is amazing.  The only issue with this game now is the sheer amount of DLC. I stopped playing it because I just couldnt not keep up with it and now that I am around 30 DLC short it stops me feeling like playing again becaiuse I feel like I am playing an incomplete experience. I know that isnt the case but thats how it feels. So in this case the sheer amount of DLC has put me off playing.  Same with EU4 as well actually. And would have to say I would think twice now about buying any future Paradox games for this very reason. Just cant keep up with all the DLC. If they honestly need to add so much stuff into the game after release then there is something wrong somewhere. And a lot of the DLC coming out is a bit dodgy lately it has to be said.  So this game is recommended for anyone who likes a deep Medieval strategy game and if you dont mind playing a certain faction (like Celtic or English) you can sort of get by on some limited DLC, but if you dont have a lot of money dont even think of getting into this game or any other recently Paradox game.

This game is very in depth and is very difficult for newcomers to the genre to get into. There is a lot of aspects to the game that you will have to learn through experimentation, and ultimately failure.  Overall, the level of replay-ability in this game is almost endless. There are thousands of rulers that you can play as, and tens of thousands of special events that will make your play-through unique and different.  The level of satisfaction that you get from taking over major superpowers, and assassinating kings of nations is nearly indescribable.  There are many things that can be said regarding this game, and I suppose the only downside is that the battles that your troops undergo cannot be experienced in a 3D environment like the 'Total War' series of Grand Strategy games. However, I find myself auto-resolving 90% of those battles anyways, which makes the 3D battle aspect irrelevant in the 'Total War' series of games.

When I wake up I think three things:  1) What's my lucture timetable?  2) Scrambled eggs for breakfast  3) Can I play Crusader Kings II?  For years now Paradox Interactive has been slowly boiling away in the background, making intricate games for nerds to sink hours in to.  But when this thing hit the market, I saw potential. And Jesus did it deliver. It is a sadist's paradise. The point is simple. To send your dynasty to the heights of fame and pulverize your enemies to dust. Along the way you'll have to commit the worst abominations known to man.   Don't have any sons? Wife too old? Murder her! First born son an imbecile? Murder him! Brother trying to overthrow you? Let him. Then when you capture him, have his eyes jabbed out, castrate him and have him rot in a dungeon for twenty years. Then banish him, if you feel like it.  It warms the cockles of my black, dead heart to no end. And you can do it for the good of your religion! No, seriously. Do a blot and you get to sacrifice a dude to pagan gods, for fun! Get it with a sale and for heaven's sake make sure to get the add-ons. There's nothing funnier than invading Rome with super-ultra-mecha-Sweden  Keep your eye out, there's an India DLC coming out soon. And I want to see what the effect on Islam will be of conquering Medina and Mecca with Elephants!

The absolute best thing I can say about this game is this: My roommate once came to my room, to see me staring at the screen with the game paused, a look on intense conflict and concetration on my face as I was mulling something over. I'd been sitting like this for some time, and he offered a Taco Bell, which I agreed to.  As we got into the car, it hit me, and I laughed, 'You know how I know I'm into this? I'm currently stuck on a decision of whether or not to kill this one Caliph. Okay, so I joined the Crusade for Jerusalem, and the Pope granted it to me for my war contribution. Since then, I've been holding the kingdom of Jerusalem for about 20 years, right? So now, I see there's this one boy who has come to power, uniting all of Arabia under him. My only solace is that he hasn't produced an heir yet, nor does he have a wife.  'I can survive his reign, and push this out, but I'll love tens if not hundreds of thousands of troops and people to the wars that would need to be waged. Or, I have an open shot to assassinate him NOW, with no heirs. If he dies before getting a wife and kids, his Caliphate will shatter into a thousand pieces, and the leftovers will fight amongst one another, rather than focus purely on me. I can buy a hundred years to two hundred years, and all it costs me is one single child's life. A child who WILL try to push me out sooner or later.'  Notice I didn't say 'my character'. I said 'I' all the way through, and THAT is the greatness that is Crusader Kings II. I feel like I'm the king, like *I* am personally shaping greater world events, and that *I* am building a dynasty that will change the flow of the ages to come.

Crusader Kings 2 is a behemoth of a game. If you've never played a grand strategy game before (like me, before this) you will be intimidated by it's depth. There are a staggering number of buttons to click, screens to read, information to digest, filters to apply, and characters to interact with. You will likely grope around in the darkness and barely survive, at first. Then the magic starts to happen. You learn how to properly apply your advisors, how to marry for alliance vs. how to marry for stats, how to get those elusive claims on neighboring territory, and so on. You will pillage the English coast as Viking raiders. You will make pilgrimages to Jerusalem, hajjs to Mecca, blood sacrifices to Kali. Feel like taking control of a lowly duke in Sicily and reforming the ancient Roman Empire over hundreds of years? Go for it. Unite the three great empires of ancient India and become Samrat Chakravartin? Do it. Play as William the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, Charlemagne, Alfred the Great, Saladin, Mansa Musa, Genghis Khan - or play, like I first did, as a mere count in Dublin and work your way up to Emperor of Britannia. Or start out in Rus and form the giant Russian/Slavic blob to collide with the Golden Horde. My point is, if you're into history like me, you will be able to live out any scenario from the past and form it to your liking. Assassinate your children, marry your sisters (Zoroastrians I'm looking at you), seduce your Steward's wife, hunt mythical white tigers, launch crusades, throw parties. Conquer territory and cement your family's reputation in the history books. BUY THIS GAME.  A few tips - as big of a game as this is vanilla, the major DLCs are must buys. They are constantly going on sale, so don't buy them at full price - wait for a sale and scoop 'em up then. I'd recommend Sword of Islam, Legacy of Rome, The Old Gods, Rajas of India, and Way of Life first. Charlemagne, Sons of Abraham, and The Republic are also awesome, but not as crucial as, say, The Old Gods. Save Sunset Invasion for last, if at all.  ALSO, bonus points for listening to Dan Carlin's Hardcore History podcasts while playing.

Crusader Kings takes an enormous amount of patience. At first I had the odd experience of both feeling like I had nothing to do and that there was entirely too much stuff in the game. Paradox is not at all shy about putting a lot of numbers on stuff and not really explaining them very well.  But if you can get past the inital learning curve, this is a very interesting sim. I am not sure I can actually explain why I like it.  Don't be put off by all the DLC. Most of it is optional additional music and art for units. The rest are expansions that add additonal options, like playing as Muslims or pagans. You can join a game with expansions enabled even if you don't have them. You simply cannot use the expansion exclusive features. For example, without Sword of Islam you can't be a Muslim, but anyone else in the game who does have it can.

I recommend this game to all who like a challenge when it comes to managing your own nation. I wasn't sure I was going to like it when I first noticed the game's existence, but once I got into the game I found it to be significatly better than its predecessor. I like the challenge of trying to stay in control of a realm while trying to expand that realm and gain prestige and piety at the same time. The addition of baronies makes it harder to take counties (while making it harder for your enemy to take your counties) since each barony must be sieged separately. Overall, five out of five stars.

Spent too much time on this game, but it is a good time spent. This game is one of my stragetic favourites with a great history you can follow and create with the direction of your selected character. While being a part of history is something that has always fascinated me CKII lets you take your House in any direction you prefer. I started as a Baron of Cornwall and soon became the Duke of Wales. My son who continued my legacy then formed the Kingdom of Wales. The Kingdom grew to take over the entire United Kingdom. A brilliant part of this progression is that while one King I controlled did nothing but ♥♥♥♥♥ and drink, the next heir to take the throne would then push on and expand the empire. Each character is different and exciting, some are up to the challenge of leading a country while others can be bumbling idiots.   This game is easily one of my favourites, and I would reccomend it to anyone who used to play risk as a child.

CK2 is an incredible RPG built on a mediocre GSG. If you want a historically accurate grand strategy game, or one in which it is difficult to expand, or a game about painting the map, go play something else. If you want to be the insane black Welsh heretical Holy Roman Emperor, or the ruler who led his dynasty from a tiny pagan Afghan dukedom to become the exemplar of a new major world religion, or the Byzantine Empire who restored the Roman Empire in the eyes of the west only to see it fall to internal strife, or the countess who used her skill with intrigue and plots to become the power behind the throne of France, or the Viking raider who burned and pillaged Rome itself: CK2 is the game for you.

I don't get the popularity of this game. For something rated 'Overwhelmingly Positive', I was not at all impressed.  The game has a horrible, clunky interface for you to manage your kingdom, or duchy, or whatever. Not that I could really tell the difference, because if you're not the king (or cultural equivalent), you don't get a border around your territory; all you can see are kingdom boundaries, so you have to click through all of your titles to look at the Region view and piece together your part of the world.  Once you've actually managed your kingdom and are waiting for things to happen, you... sit patiently and wait for things to happen. Even on 4x speed, once things were relatively settled, I ended up waiting 30 minutes for something of interest to happen - because you can't just declare war for fun, you have to have 'Casus Belli', which requires that you successfully procure a claim to a nearby territory (at a whopping success rate of ~5-10% per year, which takes about 15-20 minutes to power through), or that your neighbors are of a different religion. So if you want to expand, you need to hope that your chancellor can procure a claim for you, or that your plot succeeds (because hey, murdering your brother is cool), but that also involves waiting. So I wound up sitting there, waiting for the game to be interesting, and wondering why people loved this game so much.  Six hours later, having had to restart twice because my very young successor (sucks to not have a male heir immediately) did nothing while the Regent told me I couldn't do all of the things I wanted, like revoking the title some formerly-loyal vassal had when they formed a faction to team up on me and rebel. But, of course, the interface shows you none of this, because people plotting to rebel is apparently a minor notification, not major like some dude teamed up on you in a war you struggled to start. And when you do notice, you can't do anything, because even though the interface shows you the requirements to take certain actions, it reported all requirements met and STILL would not let me do what I wanted. Having to resort to Google to figure out why I can't do anything is bad design.  Not for me. And I don't see what it is about this game that everyone is so interested in.

This game has been hailed as a masterpiece. It offers an incredibly deep experience of medieval politics, intrigue, war and the like.  I, on the other hand, strongly dislike this game. Not because it is genuinely bad, but because its interface and mechanics are unbelievably opaque. 'Just start playing and you will slowly figure everything out', say the veterans. I have played the game for over 15 hours, and I'm just not enjoying it AT ALL. Honestly, I could have had more fun with an Excel sheet.   They game becomes enjoyable after 100-odd hours of gameplay, some say. Sorry, but a game that requires so much time investment BEFORE it becomes enjoyable is not a game but a chore.  I suggest new players think twice before getting CK2, considering its notorious learning curve.

I've played a lot of this game offline.  This game is more of a personal quest for power (and keeping it) than a war-game. There is so much in it to keep tabs on (who likes/dislikes you... who do you want to like/dislike... who do you need to like/dislike?)  Keeping your Dynasty alive is your main goal, expand if you can but if you die without a direct heir, and thats the end of your game.  In one game I played a Saxon chief, and was assassinated in my 3rd year as ruler... no heir. In another game, playing a Serb Count, I married the daughter of a Byzantine Emperor and by some miracle of fate, SHE ended up gaining the throne and my Son became Emperor...  There is so much to keep tack of, its impossible to do so, the AI is great at creating its own goals and methods of getting rid of its adversaries, the game never plays the same twice.  Replay value is huge. The larger DLC's are great addons and each adds much more to the base.  I suggest watching Shen's tutorials on youtube when you get this game. I recommend this to anyone who wants to play something more interesting than 'building armies, biggest wins'... who you place as your generals and who does what in your court, really counts! Out of all the Paradox Clauswitz style games (Victoria/Europa/Hearts of Iron) I recommend this one above all others (I've played the older Crusader Kings 1 as well). This game is complex, but not too hard to figure out, but will take a bit to master... however you can only influence so much, right? If you have a good imagination, you'll love this game.
