Among the numerous Paradox strategy game series', this one certainly isn't lacking in the content department. Character creation allows you to do what you will with any given starting character, from making ugly weak dwarfs to brilliant strong madmen. Count to Emperor, you can take many positions and generally do a great deal from any of them. However, that's about as far as my praise goes.  This game most shortly put is an offense to whatever senses of logic I poses. It confounds me so to no end, as I have struggled to find any enjoyment in this game beyond being a subjugate duke or king below another person in multiplayer and for extremely limited periods of time. The sheer massive lists of persons throughout the world to suffer is only one among many of my problems with this game that exemplify the core problem of this game: tedium.  Your own family will constantly complain or try to kill you if you refuse to give them half of your personal titles. In some parts of the world, random armies of holy warriors from one cult or the other will invade you relentlessly. The passing-on of titles from one heir to the next is completely unintelligible in some systems. Buildings are essentially pointless to invest in, when you could just spend that money on mercenaries that are generally lead by their own badass commanders. Technology is pretty much pointless outside of anything that expands the number of titles you can hold or those that curry the favor of your lessers. War is simply a numbers game, if you have a few thousand more men than your enemy you win; unless you do something incredibly stupid like crossing the Gibraltar or between Ireland & Britain. Generally really, the UI is abysmal and finding or doing anything is a chore on top of all of the above.  One of the most criminal things about this game comes down to its lack of a soul. This game feels like nothing but a series of lists of very temperary persons bound to die in short order. There is no reason at all for me to care about anything and nothing you do is satisfying, not even taking territory on any scale. Everything is so short-lived and fickle in value, there is no way I can find much interest in the aquisition of anything. At best I can find joy in raiding and murder, nothing else lasts so it plainly feels pointless.  If you're attentive and can find entertainment in stabbing the same king of the same country in the face long enough to become emperor of the universe or love navigating one of the thickest poorly constructed UIs I've ever known, you may well like it. You see, where others like some of the people who wrote the highest rated Steam reviews may perplexingly be overjoyed to spend dozens of hours watching lets-plays or reading wikis to undstand a single game, I certainly don't. Any game that takes dozens of hours to gain the most basic understanding to navigate or effectively opperate in is—no matter if I have somewhat figured it out after my own prolonged experience—signifigantly flawed and I cannot in good conscience recommend it to anyone unless they're a masochist.

You think this is a deep game? No, until you play some hours.   You think there is strategy in the game? No, there is only numbers. You got the numbers you win.  You think you can start with a little kingdom and become an emperor? No, the logic of the game is that empires were never been little kingdoms. You have many provinces? You win... You have not? Sorry dude, choose another kingdom.  You need gold? Sorry dude, there is no gold in this game... You can't trade, or build trade posts, but somehow there are someguys that called Venetians.... They build trade posts all over the place, even in your cities.... but you can't... You can't plunder coz you get almost nothing... You can't steal, you can't find a way to make some damn money... Except you own Constantinople, or Venice... or an empire with 50 provinces.  You want to advance your kingdom? You can't!  You want build? Of course you can't! IT needs money!! Want upgrade barracks? Oh tats ok, you need 200K and monthly you get 5-10K? In 400 years you can upgrade you baracks but.... there is a little problem there... Game finishes...   Guys? Up there in Sweden?? Don't do this, go play ball plz, or sims...  By the way, this game reminds me 'Knights of honour', of blacksea studios (sold in Cryteck) but 'Knights of honour' its far away more better, and even it was made in 2006, its deeper, easier to learn, and there is war of course... Strategy, with rivers and forts and mountains that army can't climb and lot of brilliant things...  Tank God i paid only 10 Euro for this thing... I love you steam :)

Warning: RANT  This is one of the worst games I have ever played in my life, the dullness of it's interface and horrible tutorial will only be the beginning of the nightmare you will encounter. The worst part - It is impossible to understand what is happening and why it is happening.   From my experience, you will spend most of your time looking at a map without anything happening, the animations are non-existing and the game seems to not put any effort in trying to entertain you. Most of the time you will just pass through years waiting for something interesting to happen.   Wars are not won by strategy but by having bigger numbers, it is exausting to look at such numbers, and like most part of the game, it will not tell you how to win a battle. I have found that at least in my experience there's no way on customising your army in a way that it can have an advantage over the enemy, if it does, it is hidden on the game like everything else. I must say that Risk has a more emotional and fun battle system than this.   The random events caused by things such as hunting, seem to be few (I encountered the same random event 3 times in a row) and very similar, your decisions have no suspense as the game already tells you what will happen if you choose to do A or B, the great story-making atmosfere I heard about this game is not here and it feels like the game only care about accumulating stats.  Weddings are the worst, I spent 30 minutes trying to find a suitable wife for my son because the game doesn't offer you a list of potential and interesting characters that DO want to marry your son. What happens is that you keep looking over a bunch of random-generated worthless women on a giant list with stats. (which already tell you more about the person's qualities and defects than Facebook, making all the suspense about choosing a good wife non existing as you will already will know who's good and who's bad). After finding one that is of the same hierarchy and unmarried, you will be very happy to know that the person rejected your offer, and you will again go back to the list.   This game seems like a narcissist who only cares about himself, he doesn't appear to want to be played and makes no effort to try to make you entertained or to understand how he works. I warn all people that this game has no meaning on it's own, only if you create your own story, like other players seem to do, and if you try to discover and content yourself with the poor mechanics the game has, you will like it. If you expect a game that gives you something, that will guide you in someway and offer you an interesting strategy challenge, whether it is at a war or a wedding, you will be disappointed.   I must admit that I have played a small amount of time, but it because I am hoping to get a refund to spend on a game that it's more welcoming to newcomers than this. It's not the complexity that makes the game hard, but the fact that it doesn't explain you nothing and will not care to do so, even if you play on very easy you wont know how to play the game and lose.

The Dark Ages might be drawing to a close, but Europe is still in turmoil. Petty lords vie against beleaguered kings who struggle to assert control over their fragmented realms. The Pope calls for a Crusade to protect the Christians in the Holy Land even as he refuses to relinquish control over the investiture of bishops - and their riches. Now is the time for greatness. Expand your demesne and secure the future of your dynasty. Fill your coffers, appoint vassals, root out traitors and heretics, introduce laws and interact with hundreds of nobles, each with their own agenda.   A good lord will always need friends to support him. But beware, as loyal vassals can quickly turn to bitter rivals, and some might not be as reliable as they seem... Stand ready, and increase your prestige until the world whispers your name in awe. Do you have what it takes to become a Crusader King?   Crusader Kings II explores one of the defining periods in world history in an experience crafted by the masters of Grand Strategy. Medieval Europe is brought to life in this epic game of knights, schemes, and thrones...

First off I must say, that I love this game and most Paradox games in general... that said they also have massive DLC issues. While buying the base game in itself is not that expensive Paradox tends to keep making new content about twice a year, while it's very nice and adds replayabiltiy it brings about three major problems and one minor one.  1. Every year you will spend $30 bucks. 2. Not buying it means the version you are playing will introduce features that make the game feel off as new mechanics are built around content that is blocked off to you. 3.As the mechanics change so do a lot of the rules, so suddenly you find yourself in a situation where you go to bed with a stable empire in a game you've been playing 50 plus hours from 860 - 1330 only to find yourself in a massive civil war because the numbers where arbitrarily changed.  The game has a few unbalancing issues, it's really hard at the beginning until you start snowballing. Unfortunately the mechanics to try alleviating the snowball effect (liberation armies, adventurers) will either crush you because you were too small or they will be an annoyance at best (sometimes a too frequent one at that) There is little to no reward for facing these challenges. It does however let you occasionally loose, sometimes you get beaten, sometimes your plans fail and it's not game over (Unless it is however one of those adventurers then your hosed.)  The games positive aspects are pretty amusing and I could spend hours talking about the time my son assassinated me to take the throne or you skillfully killed, manipulated and set up that sweet moment. The AI does occasionally goof but the moments where things come together far outshine it... Unless you're playing small... Never, EVER play small, start small maybe but never stay small. Unfortunately there are often times when you're just sitting there waiting and twiddling your thumbs... it seems to become less of an issue, (With DLC of course) yet if you're playing as a Catholic or Muslim surrounded by others of your same faith you could be spending ages with nothing to really do... The Arch Duke of God let me do something fun before this person dies.   Combat is pretty much a numbers game, although there are times when tactics and troop composition DO matter so it's something to pay attention to.   Finally Multiplayer... is very janky...very very janky.

Crusader Kings 2 isn't fun for a guy that enjoys a conquering-type of wargame. CK2 feels like a medievil relationship game (like Sims almost) instead of a conquest game. The game has too much drama/detail/minutia to be fun and sometimes being complex for the sake of micromanagement is not a good thing. I could not get into this game at all, especially since the map has no option to see your holdings other than diplomacy mode which changes as soon as you click it. I like 'big picture' games with country vs country...this is like a lifetime channel game with only a lite emphasis on warfare and has way too many characters I don't want/need to care about. The depth provided is overwhelming and stupid...simply overkill, boring and uninteresting.  If you are a fan of the HOI2 (DH, AOD) or HOI3 series, I would highly recommend the Europa Universalis 4 (EU4) or even EU3 (Chronicles edition). After playing both EU3 and EU4...CK2 is simply pathetic and a chore. Even on sale, I wasted money on CK2!

Quite possibly one of the most infruiatingly dissapointing games I've ever played. 3 hours I've played this and never again will I ever touch the 'play' button. Heed my warning with great caution, I haven't 'played' for 3 hours, I've sat on my ♥♥♥♥, staring at the game screen wondering what the hell it is that I'm supposed to be doing and what I should be doing for 3 hours.  (My gameplay):  I bought the game under the pretenses that Paradox Interactive (Mount & Blade) where a respectable game company with immersive gameplay and really puts the player's input first. Naturally my first mistake was trusting them. Imagine this, you see yourself as a fan of Checkers, (average stategy game) you've always been a fan of strategy, it's simple, fun and keeps you on your toes, so naturally when someone comes up to you and offers you a game of Chess (Crusader Kings 2) you'll assume from past experienec that you will enjoy it, be capable of playing it and of course be able to understand it. NO. This game is like real life Chess, you're ♥♥♥♥ scared, there's ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s coming at you from all angles without explanation.   Why am I being attacked? Oh yeah that's rigjht, my allies are turning against me because I'm not doing anything because I don't know what the hell it is I'm supposed to be doing because the tutorial explains nothing, for the menus it has 50 million different topics and slides, for economy it only has one slide explaining that making money is good and losing it is bad, BUT HOW DO I MAKE MONEY THEN?!   The practicality of the 'turn' system is another SERIOUS fail, you don't press 'end turn' like any other quintessential strat game, no, you simply press 'play' and the game progresses by itself day by day and of course it takes forever so you speed it up but before you know it by the time you've blinked and inhaled that next bit of oxygen that you've had your eye on for awhile, your being invaded by angry John Doe... you're already dead, I couldn't even finish this sentence.   (Overall):  This game is appaulingly bad, it seduces you in like one of the girls from the James Bond films' makes you ready to go then throws you in the deep end with just your tight spandex underwear with Jaws and Oddjob both whom have digested Viagra and desire your shiny backside. Listen well and listen good. Unless you wish to go home with an odd pain in your butt that you can't quite remember what happened the night before, don't buy this game.  Bad bad bad developers. 0/5 Terrible!

10/10  A real time strategy game that triggers 'one-more-turn' syndrome.  As far as I am concerned, this is the very best grand strategy by Paradox. It is diverse, replayable and accessible - you don't have to be seasoned veteran of grand strategies to enjoy this masterpiece, yet if you want something really challenging, there are lords and countries which present you with stiff competition from the very start of the game. Ironman mode will make the game even more ruthless if that is what you will.  The DLC are well worth their price, you can play the game without them if you want to (the only difference is that non-christian lords, appropriate bookmarks or key mechanics of the DLC are locked away and thus inaccessible by the player), though I strongly recommend to wait for the game being on sale.

Being very well read in medieval history, I was first intrigued by this game as it offered an immersive approach to feudal law and politics. While many rts type games allow city/empire building and detailed battefield control, CKII provides a rewarding experience from the necessity of developing and maintaining dynastic bloodlines.  The necessity of developing technology in order to unlock building progression helps maintain a realistic evolution of your demesne. And while many games allow attrition to become an achilles heel, you will be hard pressed to churn out massive amounts of troops - making your strategies far more consequential. Throwing all your troops into the fray unwisely will result in catostrophic results, as the time required to rebuild levies may take longer than the time your enemy needs to defeat you.  Education, Marriage, Technology, and Councilors become your greatest weapons in acquiring new fiefs and solidifying your dynasties chances of survival. CKII effectively allows expansion through both martial or political means.   I highly reccomend this game to fans of the historical time period and those wishing to master the destiny of dynastic rule.

This is a good grand strategy game. You play as a count, duke, king, or even an emperor, stiving to conquer your neighbors, and place your family on the thrones of Europe and beyond. Just as your on the cusp of victory, you die, and you take the role of your son. Was he raised as Saint, perhaps he was on inbred dwarf, and the Dukes rebel as soon as he takes the throne.  This sandbox game, allows several styles of play from conquering the world, to eradication religion. With a little imagination you can take you cruel leader to spil the blood of the infeidel, or watch you family try to wrestle the throne from you.

Amazing game. CK2 is, at it's core, a grand strategy game. However, there are several things that make it totally unlike any other strategy title I've played. The main difference is that you play as a dynasty rather than as a single person. This means that things like marriage, lines of succession, diplomacy and intrigue become far more relevant. There is still plenty of warfare in there but it does not dominate like in traditional strategy games.  There is a massive amount of replayability here as well. You can start in different time periods, play as different characters and crucially, different levels of character. For example, dealing with inter-county intrigue as a French count gives a very different game to trying to unify Scandinavia as the king of Sweden.  I've sunk over 50 hours into it already and barely scratched the surface. This is one I'll be playing for years to come.

I never was a fan of turn-based strategy games, preferring RTS's, but I tried the 'run-pause' Paradox style in CKII and really, really liked it.  The game is very well designed and it's depth and complexity is amazing! You really have to use your brain to plan your dynasty strategy, but even if you fail (and you will... many times) you still live, or your descendants live, to 'fight' another day. The in-game tutorial doesn't cover all the features so you should check some Youtube tutorials before diving in.  The interface could be more user friendly, but it works. The amount of DLC is a bit over the top, but you only really need some of it for some types of games (like playing as a Maharaja) and the cosmetic and music ones can be ignored. I'd try to get the 'Collection' to start with, because it contains some good DLC, and some others that you find necessary in a sale.

Bad: 1) At times human interaction is a bit too mathy for my taste.  2) Long load times and the amount of detail make it game you can't really take up for just some time. You need a good long session for a good experience. 3) The game was quite hard to learn to play. You can still do it, but certain quirks are surprising still to me at this point.

Great game. This is the first Paradox strategy game I think I've played. Do yourself a favor and skip the tutorial and watch tutorial videos on  youtube.com  to figure out how to play. Even now every once in a while I will still wonder why something happened in the game. It can be a bit complicated. This game is almost like one of the Romance of the Three Kingdoms games. You basically control a character (from a lesser noble all the way up to a king) and try to have your family line gain as much power and prestige until the game ends sometime in the 1300's I believe. Very quirky and funny stories can come out of this game and that's where alot of the appeal is at as well as the memorable character backstabbing and political intrigue. Very fun game, just a little hard to figure out at first. Only complaint is that Paradox nickels and dimes you to death in the DLC department. Wish they would clean up their act on that one. Definitley play now!

Crusader Kings II balances realism and accessibility to create a dynamic, interesting look into this oft-portrayed era. Historical enthusiasts and the 'as-it-was' crowd can get a lot of enjoyment out of this title. While certainly not a page out of history verbatim, Crusader Kings II does an excellent job at keeping itself honest. For those who dig this age of history, look no further.  But this game offers a truly fun experience for everybody else, too. Playing it for the drama-mongering, whether political, carnal, religious, or otherwise, rates quite highly. If one of your vassals is bothering you a whole lot, have them killed. If that is too risky, arrange them to be married to someone with the plague. The level of detail and creative freedom is deceptively high. You're left to create much of the nuance yourself, however. This isn't a title that holds your hand much.  Unfortunately, sometimes the level of detail and micromanagement can be irritating. It would be nice if you could delegate more to your inferior, but it's by no means a game-breaking annoyance. Of course, with any complex game, there are issues within the game here and there, though never enough to break immersion.   So, fellow kings and lords, fulfill your birthright and rule like you've always wanted. Just hope you aren't born disabled.

Seems overly complicated to me, plus the tutorials aren't working correctly. In the Diplomacy tutorial it said to click a button that was non-clickable. Honestly, any tutorial screen that has way over 20 Buttons is more confusing than helpful. Lokks fancy though.

Another game from Paradox Interactive but no less of their trademark massive replayability on a massive map. While this game is limited to Europe, North Africa, India (With DLC's) and everything in between instead of the Europa Universals series world map, they have made the game no less of a massive undertaking to rule over large portions and to wage war, with the provinces being more detailed and the political system more advance that EU you will have a fun time managing your foreign policy while keeping your servant's/vassals in check to make sure they don't betray you. Overall this game is very good choice for a in depth empire game with slight hint of a RPG elements with your family blood line.

I was skeptical about even downloading the demo, as I normally play games like COH2. The tutorial for CKII was a bit underwhelming and I felt like some of the game mechanics for the game was not explained very well. This caused me to suck on my first play through and I barely made it to 50 years. I uninstalled the demo and moved on.   Three days later, I downloaded the demo again. I had realized that this game is a game that makes you think. The tutorial was there to help you get started, not be proficient to play the game all the way through. It took me 4 or 5 play through to make it a full 100 years without struggling. The game forced me to learn to how to play it and play it right. The first time I had to quell an independence revolt, I barely survived. To add to my struggles, my neighbor decided to use a de jure CB on me, right after and took away a duchy. A few years later my Step-Brother killed me...  I would recommend this game to any person that is interested in grand strategy games where just about anything is possible ( even killing a tiger if you have the right DLC). I would suggest to download the demo first and try it. This game is not for everyone, but if you are the right person you will enjoy it. You get to make your on destiny and bring honor to your family.
How to begin? Just buy it. I promise, you could never regret it.

Crusader Kings 2 is probably best medieval grand strategy game (and probably unique dynasty simulation game too). It has so much more depth in comparison with Total War series (which focus is tactical battles). It has complex family relationship system and you can conquer territories in a number of different ways, create numerous strategies to dominate medieval Europe. Constant support and regular updates is another excellent feature of many Paradox games and CK2 in particular (one of the last addons The Old Gods is just amazing and must have). If you want to test your strategy skills, to perfect them you should try this complex and deep strategy game!

I absolutely love the level of detail provided in this historic simulation, but it takes some abnormal strategizing that will only come natural to you if you're a huge fan of political intrigue. Conquest is largely about connecting familial bloodlines and then designing plots to ensure your family house inherits provinces via wars, assassinations and religious ordainment. It's a tough nut to crack, but the treat is well worth the effort.

Crusader Kings II is a great, semi-addictive real time stratagy game with an enjoyable RPG element added into it. It is a great experience to propell your family forward through Medieval nobility. It is challenging, thogh certain characters are much easier than others, but for those ready to overcome the challenge, I would garentee a great experience. Though your character selection is limited at first to only Christians, with the DLCs more characters can become playable like Pagans and Muslims. My only comment on the DLCs is that they are a little pricy to the point where it may not b worth it in certain cases to have it.

9hrs in and I STILL don't know what I'm doing, but it's fun. At first, I was trying to follow a tutorial for beginners, then that guy started to stray into places I couldn't follow. Mostly because the characters were different, I think. Anyway, it started to go wrong when I kept trying to do what he did and then I'm running around my courtyard....  -----------------  'What's a vassal?!? You! I'm your.... lie-guh. What's a vassal??'  'You mean, liege, your liege?'  'Whatever! Something is wrong with my town, I booted out the bishop and now some guy off the street wandered in and is trying to run it. He's ruining my town!'  'Ahh, the bishopric you mean?'  'Whatever! You! You look somewhat holy-ish, c'mere.'  'Sir?'  'Here, does this hat fit?'  'It does sir, who shall I deliver it to?'  'Nobody, you're now the bishop.'  'But, but... sir, but sir...''  'No buts, get to work!'  'Okay, I'm an old man and I got to get married, hand me that book, I'll pick somebody and I'll... and my son too, I need and hair and so will he. We'll start a big family. Okay, here we go, a couple of comely lasses from a large kingdom, I'll ask for their hand in marriage, we'll have a grand wedding! You, send this off by carrier pidgeon or catapulted peasant or whatever you use for communications!'  'Right away, sir! Wait, you should look at this before....'  'Are you telling me, of all people, that you are disobeying me? Right here in front of all my subjects?'  'No sir... I'll.... your liege, please forgive me.'  A WHILE LATER...  'Sir, we have recieved word that your marriages are both agreed upon, congratulations!'  'Excellent! We'll prepare the wedding now! A feast! A party! We'll.... why are you looking at me like that?'  'Well, sir, your wife to be and daughter in law. Your lady is only 4 years old, and your son's lady is only 2.'  'Oh jesus... jesus hell... what the... why didn't anybody tell me!'  And all that was in the first couple hours. I'm an idiot. My dude is broke and in the middle of a war. Lots of people in my court hate my face. My one plot to try and end the war isn't going well, the old bugger just won't die of 'natural causes'.  All in all, it's just going to get worse for me and I can't wait, it's a blast.  TL;DR: STEEP LEARNING CURVE. I still don't know what I'm really doing. But for those who have the patience, I recommend this one.

The only two cons I can think of is that the multiplayer is really janky at times, and that the DLC marketing scheme is pure evil -- they've taken so much of my money! Still, absolutely worth it. A must for any true stratergy gamer. Excellent value for money in that you can replay an almost infinite number of times and it will never get stale. If you find the Total War series overwhelmingly hard or complex this isn't for you though.  A vibrant modding community also exists for this game, so even if it does somehow get stale there are still ways to keep things fresh.  Unfortunatly the cost if rather insane £30 for the basegame and WAY too many costly DLC packs. If you get this game make sure you get it when its on a substantial offer. Also, don't be frivolous in buying the small content packs, especially if they are for parts of the game you don't use often. Never has the expression 'Mind your pennies and the pounds will look after themselves' been more true.  Can you scheme, fight, murder and diplomacise your way to glory? Or will you flail hopelessly? In CKII you decide.

This game... It's hard for me to describe. It's incredibly interesting, fun, but brain smashingly deep and slow paced. I'm just going to be frank with you. This game, isn't for everyone. In fact, it's not for a lot of people. Even HUGE fans of video games who have been playing for decades and love seeing new things are going to be put off by it. So why am I rating it as a must buy? Because if those problems don't bother you and you're willing to give this game a shot it's really rewarding.  First things first: You must, and I can't stress this enough you MUST play through the entire tutorial. The tutorial alone will probably take you an hour or two and by the time you're finished you're still going to be unbelievably horrid at the game. But that's the price you have to pay to get started in this title. Once you've finished the tutorials it's time to head into the game itself.  Second: Choose a smaller nation to start, I'd suggest Denmark. Don't do what I did and go straight to England. Because 10 seconds into the start of the game you're going to be invaded by William the Conqueror, and he's going to smash everything you have and, well, conquer the entire island. (Hence the title, you don't earn a title like that from being a nice 'live and let live' kind of a guy) From Denmark you'll have a chance to really test your hand at the game and expand your influence slowly. Play that nation for a hundred years or so to get a feel for things and then move on to something more interesting and start over with a larger nation and more issues. I'd suggest France, big armies, lots of influence, and no invading Normans (though you'll lose a lot of your Nothern lands because of William. You can take them back later)  Third: Try playing as France for a while. If you're anything like me, you still don't know exactly what your doing and ♥♥♥♥ off the nobles so much that the kingdom splits into 4 different smaller kingdoms in a state of perpetual civil war. Time to start over again.  Fourth: Start again as France. This time, do what you need to do to keep your nobles happy and in line. Maybe take some time off of politics and declare holy war on the Muslims living in Spain. (Pro tip, if you can get away with it send the armies of the nobles who don't like you so much there to conquer everything. Their men will die and if they rebel you can crush them that much easier)  Fifth: Now that you've spent about 13 hours learning how to play the dang game it's time to try to build a lasting legacy. Welcome to Crusader Kings 2!  Pros:  -Holy information dump Batman! I'm not kidding when I say this, but you are going to learn a TON while playing this game if you have the mind to. From wikipedia articles detailing the histories of the nobility to tems like casus belli you will walk away smarter for having played. (I told you video games would make me smarter mom!) -The characters in the game, as they are, actually act according to their stats and traits (perish the thought) -Moral dilemmas all over the place. Do you punish that rival duke by taking his lands and making everyone else hate you for it, or do you just throw him in prison. What do you do with your only son who is an imbecile and your current king doesn't have much time left to live. etc.  Cons:  -There is soooo much to remember and keep track of that the barrier to entry of this game is huge. Imagine attacking a castle wall that is: on fire, covered in poisoned chainsaws, and patrolled by every single boss from the Dark/Demon Souls franchise armed only with a copy of this months Cosmopolitan and a tube sock. This game's barrier to entry is worse than that! -Art style is very basic. It still looks good, but if you don't enjoy staring at old maps for a long time this isn't the game for you.  All in all, you need to give this game serious and careful consideration before you put down one penny on it. For some people (maybe, 15-20% tops of the gaming crowd) they are going to have a great time with this game. For everyone else, move on, nothing to see here.

Really great game in all. But I only recommend it if you have plenty of time to kill because this game is definitely a life ruiner. I spent days playing this at a time playing smallest faction’s imaginable. Turning an Irish county into a sprawling Empire. Not so great if you’re looking for great graphics or blood or any type of instant gratification because there is none like in the total war series. Everything is long and drawn out but all the more satisfying when you finally achieve the new goals you’ve set for yourself. Although it does have loose guidelines you have to abide most of the choices are made for yourself. Very restricted freedom in the best sense of the word. Politics are key and declaring war is a task in itself. This is no cakewalk and you will find yourself wanting to pull your hair out. But if you stick with it you can find a satisfying experience in this game which few games these days can provide.  9/10

Essentially 900h in to the game and I don't even have all DLC's, so there's still tons of content left to get at, and on top of all that, there incredible mods out there that change the game from top to bottom and add an almost infinate amount of replayability to the game making it so that you can easily waste entire weeks just playing this game and still not be done with it in ther slightest.  This is the game you want to play if you want to be able to:  1. Kill all your rivals and enemies  2. Marry your daughter/sister/mother  3. Conquer the world (right now only India, Europe, some of Siberia, North Africa and the Middle East are conquerable, but there are mods for the rest of Asia and Africa)  4. Steal everyones wives (Pagan only)  5. Reform one of the Pagan religions (Norse, Slavic, Romuva (Baltic pagans) and some others)  6. Restore the Zoroastrian faith and become the Sayoshant (Zoroastrian Jesus)  7. Restore the glory of Rome and retake the Imperial lands (only for Greeks)  8. Mend the Catholic Orthodox Schism by kicking the Pope in to the Mediterreanean (Orthodox characthers only, for obvious reasons, also, it's too bad you don't get to kill the Pope afterwards)  9. Play as a Muslim, become the true Caliph and kick the Christhians out of Europe and into the Atlantic by starting the Jihads  10. Be the Mongol Hordes and play as Genghis Khan himself and fulfill his dreams of conquering all of Europe  11. Fight the Mongol Hordes and get your ♥♥♥ kicked by insane doomstacks of Horse Archers  12. Play as a Republic and defeat the other republics and wrest final control of the seas and swim in infinate amounts of gold  13. Play as a Jew, retake Israel and restore the Temple of Solomon  And much more!  Recommended DLC owned by me:  The Old Gods (Needed for playble Pagans and a start date of 867)  Sword of Islam (needed for playable Muslims)  The Republic (Needed for playable republics)  Sons of Abraham (Needed for improved Catholic mechanics and playable Jews)  Legacy of Rome (Needed for all things Roman)  Other recommended DLC:  Charlemagne (Needed for playing in 769)  Rajas of India (Needed for playable Indians of Indian religions (Hindu, Buddhist and Jain))  Way of Life (needed for more RP)  Not recommended DLC:  Sunset Invasion (Unless you really like to get ♥♥♥♥ed by the Mongols I won't recomend it since it essentially creates another Mongol invasion, this time from the West and with boats all the way from the New World)  Other DLC:  All music packs (Pretty inexpensive, but not neccesary for anything really)  All unit packs (Same as music)  CK II-EU IV Converter (Not neccessary unless you really want to make your game span from 1066/867/769-1821 (which would be a little less than 800/1200/1300 years and also buy EU IV) which would take even longer, considering that a single game of CK II from 1066-1456 takes a really long time

As the philandering chief of Slesvig, my ruler seduced and impregnated a high chief's wife, who claimed the b@stard as his own. A generation later, that son went on to become the first king of Svipjod. Meanwhile, one of my ruler's younger sons had come of age and needed to find a wife. An alliance with the king of Svipjod could be cemented through a marriage with the princess, who was admittedly the niece of the would-be groom. The marriage went ahead, and an inbred freak was born of the union.  I thought little of this family shame until through a series of Viking raids gone awry, all of my original ruler's sons died as maimed cripples. The inbred five-year-old inherited the high chiefdom with near-zero stats, survived until adulthood, and then spent his dead uncles' loot on building an army to conquer his neighbors and form the kingdom of 'Danmark.' Later, when two subject houses were embroiled in a blood feud, he called them together in a mead hall and tried to leverage his status as an inbred freak to curry empathy and make peace. The room erupted in violent chaos, and he had to settle for escaping with his life. Eventually, the circumstances of his birth would catch up with him, and he died of genetic failure in his forties, but he passed on as the most prestigious member of his dynasty to date. 10/10 - would wincest again.

CK2 is on the whole great, but it's certainly an acquired taste; even among frequent grand strategy genre players. The game has seen so many updates, bugfixes, rebalances, mechanics removed and added and extensions to the scale of the map that it's important to acknowledge the differences between what it is now and what it was years ago.  What it is now is basically the closest thing to A Song of Fire And Ice: The Video Game that money can buy. Note I'm using the name of GRRM's book ludicrously successful series and not A Game of Thrones, the ludicrously successful TV series. Because if you find an overwhelming amount of detail too much, this isn't going to be a good fit.  In any given situation there's many different, often mundane looking factors that can utterly change what you've planned, and others that can suddenly render them irrelevant or an impending crisis. This is true for a lot of grand strategy, but CK2 seems to take it to a whole other level making it something you'll find appealing or abhorent.  You could spend a long, long time deciding who to marry your heir off to, only for them to die in suspicious circumstances; you could spend years slowly eliminating the unity of a neighbour's alliances only to have another invade his lands before you can, leaving you the prospect of entering a far larger, costlier and probably less decisive war for the same reward. Or that might be the goal all along, and once one looks like they've the upper hand, declare war on both and conquer them whilst they're exhausted and their allies won't have anything to contribute.  The game has weaknesses; in explaining core mechanics like how dynastic succession laws work examples aren't provided and there's no preview of what their far reaching effects would be (making it punishing for a new player to learn the hard way how things work); in late game the performance of the engine drags a bit. Some mechanics, such as the choices offered by the seduction focus from The Way of Life DLC seem imbalanced compared to what the alternatives are, and there's some quality of life overdue.  I recommend the game. The DLCs are generally good; I don't think The Sunset Invasion stands up to repeat gameplay, and I think the EU4 save importer is niche. The Old Gods and Charlesmagne DLCs allow for earlier starting dates but they greatly extend the length of the game and have very slow build-ups outside of a few characters of interest.

I haven't played enough to know if the complexity of the UI is something necessary or if it could be cleaned up but without a doubt it makes the game difficult to learn. You are not going to watch a quick video on this or play the in game tutorial and know everything that is going on, some of this again may be the UI but it is also a complex game with a lot of mechanics, so the learning curve is always gonna be steep. I find its best to watch some basic tutorial videos and switch between that and playing, even if you mess up constantly and have to restart. The only way to learn is to play around and go to a video or wiki resource when you find something you do not understand.   All that said if you are interested in the roleplaying aspect of being a king, or even non-roleplaying aspect of feudal governance you should check this game out, things like balancing the inner workings of your realm as well as requiring a legitimate cause to go to war make this game feel a lot more authentic than games like civ, which is great in it's own ways. You could lose your demense or titles or start off as a count and become king. There are no real objectives, just what you want to do. Every playthrough is different.  It is a very difficult game starting off and I would recommend starting off as a count or duke. Ireland, or newbie Ireland is recommended as the best place to start and it is true. Very little vassals to try and please and you get the idea of how warfare works, and how to get claims as you cannot just invade or attack anyone, you need a valid CB.   If you love this era, and are interested in a different type of strategy game that takes a while to master, hell, I'm still a noob. Then I would definitely recommond this game. I bought crusader kings II because Europa Universalis' extended timeline mod just didn't do the trick for me. what I expected was something quite alike EU, but only slightly different.  now here's the good part, it was a lot different. Crusader Kings II really refines the genre, as it focuses more on you and your land, rather than 'what clay am I gonna take next?', you'd ask yourself 'which underaged family member should I marry off to my uncle?'  Every country, culture and religion has different custums, blind people can not inherit titles in orthodox nations, or underaged marriages for islamic nations.  The game has a very steep learning curve, even more so than EUIV (in my opinion). It will take you quite some time to get used to it, but the game has a lot to offer for an interactive atlas.  Alas, here come the flaws... Though the game has a lot to offer, it locks most of it behind paradox's ridiculous dlc policy. This is no problem if you bought the bundle in the sale for about 30$, but if you bought only the base game, like me, you're gonna regret it. islamic, hindu, jainist, tengri, norse and many more religions and their countries are behind bars, same goes for three of the basic starting dates.  If you're still thinking if you should buy the game, buy it on sale, completely. Otherwise you might be disappointed by the phantom pain of what lies locked behind the bars of dlc.

So gratifying and enjoyable!  Get this game!  ===  The above was my review 4 years ago...  Tons of expansions later and this game is still a go to for me. Every penny has been worth it and I love the amount of work and dedication Paradox has put in, changing and enhancing the game overtime. This has to be one of the best games I have ever played. The scope of it is so enormous, the replayability factor is incredible. You could play exactly the same character every time and never have the same game. There really is only one way to describe this game, EPIC.  The expansions are great, I particularly recommend getting the Old Gods expansion which allows you to play as a Pagan character and pushes the game right back to the 9th Century. I love how all of the religions are modelled and the mechanics of playing as that religion makes gameplay unique for each one.  The things you can do are endless. Fancy playing as the Byzantine Emporer and refounding the Old Roman Empire? How about being Ghengis Khan and leading your Mongol Horde to conquer Europe and the Middle East? Try being the head of a rich merchant family and build trade routes to gain money and political power. Play as a Viking warlord and pillage and raid the coastlines of Europe or simply play as a count and try and build up your families power base through clever politics and intrigue. Some of the best games I have had is when I have started as a lowly count with one territory and slowly but surely, sometimes over hundreds of ingame years become a world conquering Emporer.   The game is incredibly deep and lasts for hours and hours of play time. I feel like I have barely scratched the surface of the possible things I can do. Despite the deepness I think it was relatively easy to learn to play, but that may have been because I already have many Paradox games such as Hearts of Iron 3 and Victoria 2 and found these much harder to get into.  If you enjoy history I heartily recommend this game. It has taught me sooo much about Medieval history whether that is just skimming through the various starting times to look at the politics of the known world at that time or by reading Wikipedia articles about some of the more famous characters in the game. Even if you don't enjoy history, don't be put off, the game is not educational and doesn't ram history down your throat.  Whats more there are some brilliant mods. The Game of Thrones mods is a must for any fan of the series. They have recently expanded the mod to include a whole new continent and the scope, just like the vanilla game, is incredible.  In summary this game is bloody brilliant and well worth every penny I have spent on it.

Continues to get bigger and better. The MAJOR DLC expansions have done much to improve enjoyment and provide further depth to the game. The key points on DLC for this game - WAIT for sales which frequently occur here or on other sites. The game is only playable on steam so you can buy it anywhere, just shop for deals. At full price you would pay around 170 US dollars for everything when not on sale, so I recommend that option only to the player who had to have it all now.  Major DLC (1-5 on sale often, 6 - first sale I've seen was yesterday off-site, 7 - new) 1. Sword of Islam - allows playable Muslim rulers 2. Legacy of Rome - Byzantine Empire and Orthodox church 3. Sunset Invasion - alternative history with invasions by Aztecs 4. The Republic - Merchant Republics 5. The Old Gods - Vikings, Pagans, start year can go back to 867 6. Sons of Abraham - Abrahamic religion upgrades, Judaism added 7. Rajas of India - Indian rules and new provinces  Minor DLC - largely cosmetic and music. You generally don't need these unless your a compleatist. Exceptions are Ruler Designer, Customization Pack and the EU4 Save Game converter to port your CK2 save to EU4. The last three may have more mileage depending upon your needs.

This is one of my favourite games. If you've liked Paradoxe's other games, CK II is much in the same vein. CK II isn't really a strategy game, its a 'dynasty simulator' where your goal isn't necessarily to ensure you control max territory but rather that your family is as powerful. connected and long lasting as possible. 'Conquest' in this game happens as much through strength of arms as it does from clever marriages well placed assasins (think Tywin Lannister from Game Of Thrones).  Overall, the game is complex, deep and micro management free.  Its worth getting at least the old gods and sword of islam expansions however as playing pagan/muslim is more entertaining then the boring european catholics (and also harder, not that the game isn't already very hard).

Another Paradox game for history lovers, this game is very fun but like their other titles very hard to break into. However, Paradox does continue to get better in regards to their tutorial system, which means you might actually figure out how to play just by that for once instead of looking up everything online.

Imprison relatives! Plot against your benefactors! Declare anti-popes!  It's not about battles, but essentially being an unimportant noble plotting so that your grandson will be the king, and then panicing for a Plan B when he dies in a 'hunting accident'. This usually involves a series of plots, murders, and trying to obtain sufficient popularity to change succession laws.  A nice aspect is that in terms of what individual people think of your character, things actually make sense - everything that you think would influence a character's opinion, actually DOES. For instance, you may wonder why, despite your relaxing taxes and granting extra titles, Count Jeremy doesn't like you. But looking at the details, it turns out he's still bitter that you beheaded his father 20 years ago. Things like that.  It's a little harder to get into at first, and you might not have such a sense of what to do next, but this is an ideal game for imagining that you are a plotter in a world full of AI characters who also have sensible plots and ambitions.
This is without a doubt Paradox's finest game ever, as well as their simplest to learn.

This comes hard, as I love this game so much, but at this point with the current 'updates and fixes' the game is nearly broken. In single player almost any small player (county or dutchy) near a muslim AI is pounced upon. Also, if you have the DLC that allows you to start in 867 be aware that Jorvik and several Norse positions start with 5K plus troops that cost them ZERO to maintain, they will steam roll anythng next to them and there is nothing the neighbors can do about it. The other rather glaring problem is the difficulty settings which are next to meaningless. It's one thing getting a hollow victory, or in the case of this game survival, on the lowest setting. It's something else when you have to resort to the command screen via tilda to just survive on the lowest setting. Personally I think the single best thing Paradox could do is fix the difficulty settings so that on the lowest setting the AI is hampered by stupidity.

A wonderfully in-depth mix of RPG, strategy and history. Start with a chosen character, from the lowliest count to the most powerful emperor and choose a time in history from the Dark Ages to Medieval, and build a dynasty whilst you re-write 5 or so centuries of history depending which expansions you own. The game is based on the relationships between thousands of characters, and through marriage, scheming, intrigue and war, you can make your mark. When your first character dies - and there are a vast array of ways to meet your maker - you will continue as your heir. The game plays out as a pausable, real-time system, with events popping up that give you little multiple-choice vignettes to add colour to proceedings. RTS fans will likely find the combat simplistic, but the real beauty of this game is not how good any one of its systems is - it's the way they combine together to make an epic story unfold before you. Your dynasty will have a rollercoaster ride of rising and falling fortunes, but as long as you have at least one province, you're never out of it - in fact, there's nothing more satisfying than clawing your way back from catastrophe and the game does a fantastic job of making failure fun.  There's a wry humour throughout, and CKII is far from a joyless history lesson. Not only that, the level of replayability is astonishing. The choice of rank, culture, size of nation and historical start date gives a vast variety and the expansions, often discounted, widen this even further, as well as adding new rules and scenarios. Mods are also available and even a (rather expensive) save converter that lets you carry a completed CKII game into Europa Universalis IV. The forum community is nice and helpful and the Paradox website also contains a lot of AAR's of people's games - worth a read to get a feel for the gameplay.  I can't recommend this gem enough to anyone who enjoys strategy, RPG or even RTS type games, and wants something different, or to anyone who likes Paradox's other efforts.

For those who are interested in the 'strategy' of strategy gaming, CKII and other Paradox titles such as Europa Universalis and Victoria provide perhaps some of the most in-dept gameplay available on PC. These games aren't for everyone they have a steep learning curve generally and there is a lot of stuff to remember and the game at times can be unforgiving and doesn't hold your hand throughout. CKII in particular is a Medieval strategy and simulation where while it is a real time strategy game it is also a RPG in the sense that you choose not so much a particular nation like you would in other titles but instead an individual and his/her dynasty and you progress through the game as descendents of the character you choose, the management of securing and heir and thus continuing your game is but one of the many features of this fantastic game. 9/10

Great game. Can be frustrating at times but in the end you're always left with a great story. Recently I played as Svithjod (Sweden) and united the kingdom, conquered some of Holland and was ready to take a piece of Norway to be able to reform the norse faith and work towards the empire of Scandinavia. All of a sudden, I died from old age. Now everyone hates me and they form factions and my kingdom is splintered by civil war. Then I die again to assassination. Now my land is strewn across my two uncles and everyone wants to depose me. I call in my allies, somehow win subjugation of Norway, but with new Norwegian independence wars and the ongoing war to install my uncle ( I killed my other one and got some of my stuff back), I surrender to my uncle and let him sort it out, which he does. I try to assassinate him to inherit everything back, but by co-conspirators blabbed and now he hates me. So much, in fact, that he challenges me to a duel. I am at one less martial ability but things are going so poorly I figure why the hell not and somehow I win, kill my uncle, and regain the kingdom of sweden and Norway. Bottom line, if you like strategy games, this is a must buy. You will sometimes get screwed over but the stories created along the way are what make the game. Also if you are a fan of fantasy there are mods to set this game in worlds such as ASOIAF, Elder Scrolls, and Lord of the Rings.

Definitely the most complex strategy game I've player or would care to play. If strategy is your thing and you really like punishing yourself with a learning curve from hell, go for it.

a very good game
'[the most] unexpected fun in a video game since euro truck sim' -david lee roth

This game is my first paradox strategic game. The learning curve was pretty steep, even when you follow everything on the tutorial, I had a hard time figuring everything out, mostly because of trial and error and at first I gave up on the game. I later tried it again feeling positive about it, having seen Game of Thrones I wanted to simulate that experience. After, let's say 15 hours of total gameplay I was already on top of the game, having the time of my life sending bribes, assassinating people, scheming, defending my country, my religion and what else a High King would do, having my shares of problems, my share of bloody uncles wanting the throne for themselves because the liege died too early during the war and the successor was a bloody kid tutored by someone who would later become their worst nemesis. It's not a game about winning, it's a game about telling a story. I don't particularly like the historical stuff, I just enjoy the game as 'myself' and 'my dinasty' or a character that I make up and see how it goes, that's why the ruler designer was a must-have for me, and the mods on the forums are spectacular, there's something for everybody here, for a fan of strategy games that is. There is warfare and a nice system for it, but the game is mostly about how you handle yourself in a Medieval world and among medieval nobles, a brilliant simulation with brilliant mods to top it off.
Very in depth game, well worth it, but be prepared to lose a few hours per game

Amazing, in-depth game for players who like strategy games, wars every five minutes (If you have the Old Gods DLC), killing your relatives who want to take the throne for themselves secretly, and conquesting through Europe with a doomstack that grows with every kingdom you take.

My favourite game of 2012 is a unique combination of court-life simulation, genetic breeding, diplomacy and strategy. Ignore the somewhat deterrent graphics and the steep learning curve and enjoy the best kingdom-tycoon game ever made.

A deep strategy game, with limitless possibilities of manupilating middle-age europe. Get prestige for your family, lands and gold. And After Old Gods DLC, much more fun to play.   TL DR: Best game to be a Lannister.

One of the most amazing Grand Strategy games I've ever played, if not the 'Grandest'. There are also several great mods for the game that either make special circumstances or completely overhaul the game to make it different. The only concerns I can think of is that you will have to sink some more money for all of the DLC to truly 'unlock' all of the aspects of the game, and that sometimes your kingdom can fall and your heirs die out in unexpected ways. Also you will probably need to spend several hours (like I did) learning all of the mechanics and playing around with starter kingdoms/duchies. (Just be sure to pick kingdoms and above for your first playthroughs, playing the duke/count can be fun...but you are VERY likely to be conquered by another much larger kingdom.) Regardless, It is being updated at a steady pace and though most of the content comes in the form of DLC that you must purchase...I can safely say that it was worth the extra five dollars here and there! If you see it on sale, grab it!
Great game. If you like long drawn out strategy games then pick this up/

I just spent an evening trying to kill my wife. But that's okay, she was trying to kill my oldest son from a previous marriage so her son could inherit the throne.  This is a game of soap opera melodrama, backstabbing, plotting, and the rise and inevitable downfall of nations seen through the eyes of a single dysfunctional family - yours. Now if you'll excuse me, my imbecile nephew has managed to drag the family genes through yet another illegitimacy scandal, so I've got to find some way of pruning the family tree a little.
One of the best strategy games I have ever played!
Simply unlimited hours of fun!

The likelihood of genetic traits being passed is a little wonky (come on, there's no way absolutely zero out of my fifteen inbred children get the inbred trait) and it's far too easy to desync while playing multiplayer, but overall it's great. I recommend combining the lunatic and possessed traits for an -interesting- game.
You can murder children and marry your daughter to her uncle, what's not to love?

Great game. No playthrough is exactly the same and there are so many different characters of different nations and religions that you'll never run out of things to do. The expansions add lots of content but aren't really required.  It is definitely confusing at first cause the tutorial is not that good, but if you watch a quick youtube video and do some experimentation you'll grasp the game's concepts fairly quickly!

The game? Fantastic.  It's almost like Medieval: Total War without the battlefield maps, but with the world map politics/trade/alliances/plots on steroids. Seriously near perfect.  If you are a fan of the 'A Song of Ice and Fire' series by George R.R. Martin, the ASoIaF mod for this game is the absolute BEST thing you will probably ever get to play based on the series.  Political alliances, beneficial marriages, assassinations, wars, tournaments, adultary, family feuds, basically anything you could think of that would affect a family dynasty in medieval-type settings comes into play here.  Spend 10 years educating and training your first born son to be a perfect heir to your lands? Sorry, one of your rivals just successfully arranged for a servant to poison him, leaving you with no male heirs to carry on your name. Arrest him, fabricate evidence of treason, or set in motion plans to assassinate him in kind. If you're really feeling devious, send agents to begin making false claims on his lands and titles, give it a few years, then go to war, take his lands, and banish him to the Wall, or even just let him rot in prison or execute him and his family (Lannister vs. Reyne style), and wipe his legacy from the world entirely.  So many things to do. It's insane.  I don't think I've even played more than a few hours of the standard game, the mod is done so well.  They update CONSTANTLY, as well, so any game patches that are released result in at most a few days delay before the next hotfix.  Seriously, if you love the book series, pick up this game and the mod. The sheer number of 'what if' scenarious that you can come up with and play out are mind-boggling.  I give this game a 9.5/10 for that alone.
Very fun game. Worth the money

Truly a fantastic game, one of the best the strategy genre has to offer. The only real downsides are the steep learning curve and the bugs (which have largely been patched). If you can handle the complexity, and you probably can, then you owe it to yourself to take a shot at Crusader Kings 2.

An exceptional game for those with a taste for strategy. Unlike other games that leave you thinking 'if only it had ___', CK2 has everything that it should have, and even a mod that lets you play as famous characters from Game of Thrones. A must for anyone with the patience to learn how to play it.
it is a hard game to get into but when get how it all works it is a epic game

I've never reviewed a computer game before, but felt uttely compelled to with this one. I've been playing games for about 31 years now, since I was 4 years old, so I guess it says a little about how good this really is.   When I first saw the game advertised, it looked like some old board game re-make and I didnt fancy buying it, I've been stung in the past with similar games. It went down to 75% off and my interest peaked, so I took a gamble on it. My lord, what a gamble.   I'm around 115 game years into it and I'm not bored at all. And 115 years will take you a long time to complete, with still around 200 game years left. I also havent achieved very much, I started with a small town in Wales and havent grown that much at all! But this is the beauty of the game. Its hard. In the end I went on youtube and watched some video tutorials on the very basics of the game and these helped me grasp it a bit, and as soon as I did I was hooked. The fact that I'm still learning about the game after so long shows its depth, originality and pure gameplaying focus, as opposed to snazzy graphics and no depth.   If like me you like a challenge, a really deep, beautifully thought out strategy game that is also a lot of fun (I assissinated my mother in law, just because I could, how much more fun can you get?) then you really have to buy this masterpiece.   So many variables, you can start as so many different characters without even buying an expansion and each game would be totally different.   I think my girlfriend left me last week, I should probably stop playing soon and check to see if she left any food in the cupboard.   10/10

This game is a complicated, hard to understand, Midevil grand strategy game. If that sounds boring to you, proaabaly don't bother with it. However, if that does interest you, just know that in my current playthrough I started as a petty king of a small Irish kingdom, and, through carefull use of rebellions, mariages, wars, and more, I now control most of ireland, I am the duke of wessex, and I also control the petty kingdom of cornwall. And that only in the first 75 or so, out off the almost 400 years you have to play in.   Buy this game, buy it now.

One of the best games I have ever played. It can be a little hard to understand at first, but after you figure it out, it become very simple. Watch a video Online of someone playing it, and you'll start to pick up more and more.

Probably the most addictive and engrossing of the many Paradox grand strategy titles. Highly reccomended.

It's Game of Thrones without magic & dragons (but there is a mod for that); It's Shakespeare's play, with more a little more politics thrown in the middle; It's a living history book with all the kinky, violents and... interesting details; It's Europa Universalis with actual persons instead of nations; It's... These Paradox titles are kinda funny. If you've ever played some early DOS games where you're just thrown into the action/UI with amost zero explanation and sent desperately scrambling for a PDF or game manual you'll have a very similar experience with most 'grand strategy' games.  There are SOME popup boxes that explain the basic gameplay using esoteric jargon and often olde English. These, contrary to the claims of user friendliness, are not very helpful.   What it's gonna come down to is one or both of two things: Either watch someone smarter and more experienced than you play the game on YouTube or dive in, click everything, and slam headfirst against brick wall after brick wall for hours on end until something snaps into place and the various mechanics of managing your dynasty become obvious and second nature.  Does this sound like something you'd be interested in playing? Me too.   And it's so much freaking fun.  No really, I swear.

This game has the most interesting and dynamic NPC 'diplomacy' AI I've seen. In single player things can occur that make these characters with random abilities, stats, and dispositions to behave like real adversaries and allies. Here's a case example.  I was the king of Poland, or rather the Piast dynasty ruling over poland. My characters (the succession of kings) had all been known for their piety, for ousting baltic heathens - taking their land in the process - and helping in Crusades. Come the fourth character in this religious dynasty, and I notice my successor is a bishop. How fitting! But then he arrives to me one day with a book he found inspiration in - he's now converted to a heretic faith and wants me to join him. Blasphemy!  Well we can't have that. So I politely and forcefully excuse him of his duties as Chancellor, as well as limit his influence in every way I can. He hates me now, but everyone else likes me. Things stay like this for a number of years. What brought about a change is I realized I could never get him to convert back as long as he hates me, so I looked at his aspirations (to become Chanellor again), gave him a bit of land and so on. This caused outrage in my other vassals beyond any benefit I saw, even for my son, and so I felt I was stuck with him until I die. But what's this!?  The king of Hungary, looking for a prestigious husband for her daughter, asks for my son's hand in marriage (it wasn't weird back then). Of course I'll marry him off and get him out of my court! Make it a matrilineal marriage so their children inherit her name rather than mine. I don't want my dynasty to be known abroad as a bunch of Lollard heathens. What a relief now that that's settled. Or is it...  Years later, I look at what's going on in Hungary after one of their many civil wars. What?! She's the queen! And my son, who still hates me with a passion is now king of Hungary? It can't be! The sneaky (later to be known as 'the cruel') ♥♥♥♥♥ made her way onto the throne, and they are both plotting to kill me! Me! Janislaw the Pious, who walks the path of God!  Hungary being too much of a military power to conquer, I could only wait and hope their assassins didn't find a window of opportunity to kill me, until the Lord took me to heaven himself. So I got the last laugh.

I don't play violent video games. That's why I don't kill people. But I do play Crusader Kings II. That's why I am currently married to my cousin, plotting an assassination of my country's ruler and preparing for an invasion of a neighbour.

I absolutely love CK2. It's a huge, enthralling and intelligent game where nearly everything is an internally-consistent simulation. Its focus on characters and families makes it infinitely more engaging and human than any other grand strategy game; it isn't even fair to describe it as one. Think of it instead as a soap opera for men.  Just be warned. Once you've embraced Crusader Kings II there is no going back to pretenders like Civ or Total War!

One of the singularly best games to come out for PC since 2010, Crusader Kings II is a grand strategy game developed by Paradox. In CK2, you play as head of your dynasty through the ages. The goal of the game, unlike most strategy games where you expand your lands, is to ensure the survival and expansion of your family. Warmongers may find something they like in CK2; however, the heart of the game is in its politics.  Combat has improved since release, with various traits for your generals and the occasional reworking of how levies work, but battles often comes down to who has the bigger stacks. It's not a bad system, but it can be frustrating at times.  What the game lacks in combat, it makes up for it in the raw emotions it can invoke without you realizing until it's too late. You invest money and time mentoring your genius eldest son to a brilliant strategist to ensure that your heir (the future king) is a great leader, only to have the boy die the year after he comes of age, before he has produced a son of his own. Now his younger brother, the detached priest is next in line. Ugh.  The game lacks a good tutorial, but there are plenty of strong tutorial 'Let's Plays' series to be found on Youtube. In the end, however, the best way to learn CK2 is to play it. To suffer, to lose, and to learn from your mistakes. It's a challenging game, but it is immensely rewarding.

Infinite game. You can play it over and over and over again and each time you'll find a different and challenging game. You can start as a small count or as a powerful emperor and you'll find challenges that fit the size of your domain. Totally recommend it.

Don't judge this game straight away, this game is probably the most detailed game I have ever played, with (literally) over 1000's of characters to play as. This game rewards and stresses you for your gameplay in so many ways.

Great game,very hard to get into though so if you're looking to buy I would suggest looking up some youtube channels with guides on how to play. The DLC of this game just adds to the fun for those who stuck with the first hours of game play and have gained a suttle understanding of how to play, and just show that paradox is still able to suport a game that is over a year old.
Think game of thrones but set in medieval Europe (and now, with Vikings)  What more could you want?
good game, have a lot of depth
At first this game is a baseball bat to the head and it hits hard, after a couple of 'failed' starts the game opens up a can of brilliance.
Have you ever wanted to brutally murder your cousin who you just had a child with? No? Neither did I until I played this game! Now it's a common occurence!  But seriously this game is fantastic.

There was a time when i first started playing this game where i couldnt understand why i was fighting countless rebellions and losing all the time. Fast forward a few hundred hours, and i have killed countless brothers, murdered rivals, died on hunting trips, changed religion, won crusades, reformed my religion, risen from count to duke to king to Emperor, done selective breeding to get a genius only to see him die in a tragic accident, formed a Jewish empire then lost it in a rebellion, had inbred children, gained most of western europe through marriage and conquest, and the best part i havent even played Byzantium, any Arab country yet, India, or a Republic. Honestly if you want a game that will make you read about history, become obsessed with your upcoming inheritance and really want to talk about it with people who couldnt care less i.e. your girlfriend then do yourself a favour and buy this game. It really is one of the best games and a must for anyone who loves history, and if you dont you will find yourself loving history. I watched the Vikings TV series and now i have to play a Norse! See ya!

This game in my opinon is one of the best games of all time and hands down the best Strategey game I have ever played it is a bit pricey but it is worth it the only problem is that you need a experenced player to teach you how to play because it has a large learning curve.

Feudal Administrator Simulator 2012.      I never thought I would enjoy a game this tedious.    I've played Total War and Age of Empires my entire life, and would have considered myself a strategy player. However, you cannot be considered a true strategist until you have played Crusader Kings II. This isn't about the long game, it's about the.... very long game? Whatever.   Unlike other RTS's, CKII is not a simple case of 'numbers equal victory' (though numbers always help). This game is about laws, marriage and intrigue at heart. I love the teachings of Machiavelli and this game embodies the friendless nature of Medieval Europe. Armies will give you security, but intellegence and foresight can give you the world. Never in any game have I experienced so much joy from gaining so little land through manipulation and guile. There is also a lot of ejoyment to be had once you put down a massive rebellion and then extract revenge on the lords responsible (heads will roll).  There is also an educational element that people overlook. I honestly couldn't name any regions in Hungary for example. Now I can name loads of places in Europe and Asia Minor I had previously never heard of. It's a nice feeling when you sound intellegent all because you played a video game. You also learn a tonne of new phrases such as 'de jure' or 'casus belli'. These phrases can be incorparated into everyday conversation which makes you look well clever like Steven Hawkings or something.  My only gripe with this game is it is impossible to justify and explain to other people. You cannot convince friends why this game is fun, The game essentially consists of manipulating feudal laws to gain land and accrue power which admittedly sounds boring. It will be boring for some, yes. But if it sounds even the slightest bit interesting to you please give this game a chance. It will change how you view games in general. Video games do not need bells and whistles to be interesting.  Just a warning. This game is not enjoyable for the first 5-10 hours depending on how quickly you pick it up. But once you do the rewards are huge.  You don't have a social life anyway.    89.7/100.   Would highly recommend.

I've been dreaming of a game about dynasty diplomacy in a historical or fantasy setting for a long time, so you can imagine I was pleased when I discovered this game. This is like A Song of Ice and Fire set in the real world, and if you appreciate the kind of diplomacy and backstabbing that this is about, you'll love this.   You know you've really become absorbed in the setting when you find yourself thinking: 'Hmm, I should have someone kill my son's 1 year old daughter so the title she would have inherited falls back to me instead'. ;)

It's prettier than its predicesors (though still not very pretty), full of menus and numbers. This shouldn't be fun. But as I guide the Scots through 400 years of conquest, in-fighting, intrigue and desperate defence against the English, I couldn't think of a game this engrossing or with a fraction of the character. Find the demo, play it. Then play it 3 more times. After that you will start to see past the menus.

I first heard of this game back in the summer of 2012. I really enjoy Classical and Medieval history, so with a name like 'Crusader Kings', this game caught my attention on YouTube. I saw a Let's Play someone had done of it and I was actually caught off guard by the learning curve. It was unlike anything I had seen before. I come from the likes of Sid Meier's Civilization series which doesn't have as much strategy involved with it. Don't get me wrong. Civilization can be tough, but that's for another time. After a couple months of watching Let's Play's of this game, I picked it up in October of 2012 and this quickly became one of my favorite games of all time. The idea of having a family dynasty and playing it out 500, 600 years is incredible (with The Old Gods DLC).   For those not familiar with the game, you play as a ruler of a county, duchy, kingdom and/or empire and basically do what you want. Try to aquire more land buy fabricating claims or pressing someone else's claim. Try to maintain what you control and keep your vasals in line. Play as the Byzantine Empire and mend the Schism between the Catholic and Orthadox Churches as well as restoring the Roman Empire (with the Legacy of Rome DLC). There are many possibilites and many ways to play. It's also worth noting that I consider this game very much character driven as opposed to being country or nation driven. There is so much I can say about this, but I don't want to ramble on about it either. I would say if you like strategy games, enjoy history, or at the very least, enjoy games that make you think, I would at least give this a spin.

The only thing I don't like about this game is the combat, which is a little iffy at times. So even though it's expensive, once you get it it'll be worth a dozen AAA games.
