A lot's been said about this game, so I won't bore you with tales of unintentionally amusing things the game forces you to do ('Ooh, I'll say it's an incest simulator! How funny!').  CK2 is one of those games with a high skill cap. You can be learning how to do new things quite a few hours in, long after you've left the tutorial. Part of the reason for this is that the game has a lot of content (and Paradox keeps adding new things), another more prominent reason is that a lot of it isn't intuitive. The vast majority of tricks to doing well in this game are emphatically 'gamey' and prioritise winning in a fashion that seems at odds with what you'd expect. The game doesn't explain this -why would it?- and so it takes a long time to absorb the information.   Fortunately, learning how to play the game is fun! It's tremendously entertaining to see your profiency expand over the hours of playtime and to watch the map painted in your colour as you get better and better. However, once you feel like you've hit that cap, and at 300+ hours I feel like I'm coming close without having acheived an awful lot, the game stops being nearly as fun.   One other problem with this game is the sheer volume of DLC that essentially creates two versions of the game: the release one, and the DLC one. DLC appears to improve every aspect of the experience: most of the graphics and music, for example, are locked away until you buy it. You are also totally unable to play a large amount of rulers without those upgrades. This is significant, because if you become committed to it, you'll probably find yourself wanting to basically pay as much money as you did for the game, *again*. At the very least, you'd realise that your game will astronomically benefit from it, which in many ways is ridiculous.  With that said, I've definitely found it fun. And with the amount of time, even spending money on DLC, it's been worth the expense. I'd reccomend it to anyone who enjoys a good map-painting experience. And I think that particular jibe is justified, because it covers so many more genres than incest-simulator could do.
There's nothing else to say - this game literally increases your manhood.

So I bought this expecting it to be a Civ-alike. It is on some levels I suppose, but it's WAY more fun to play it like a RPG. The simulating of your family, court, and dynasty is amazingly detailed and I can't think of any other games where my character's crazy wife decided to murder her two 5 year old children and usurp my rule and so I had to stick her in jail and execute her. There's a lot of empire management and expansion stuff and it's complicated enough that you can play the game entirely like that if you want, but really, just manage your family, do some espionage, and learn about the billions of menus when you get an event dealing with said menus. The game is hugely less overwhelming and tons of fun if you play it this way. Also you might have an heir who the nation thinks is posessed who likes murdering people and you might have to DEAL WITH THAT.

Crusader Kings II is a game that focuses on creating and evolving a historical dynasty. The player chooses a lord that can hold a range of titles (baron, duke, king, and so on) across the Old World. This lord can be unknown to history or a famous ruler from a desired era. As the dynastic ruler you will experience random life events that will shape your character’s progression. Spend time managing and maintaining the happiness as well as ambitions of members and vassals of your court. Elect the people of your court to five different council positions that affect the state skill modifiers of your realm. As the old saying goes, surround yourself with people smarter than you and success will follow. Just be careful who you trust...  The dynastic leader you will have the ability to forge alliances through marriage. As well as fabricate claims on other lord’s territories. The game has a robust claims and diplomacy menu for the warlord or plotter of any nation. When your character dies you resume play as the heir to your dynasty.  Crusader Kings II has a good music selection that changes depending on your ruler’s starting zone. There are no cinematics and the storyline is what you make it. In fact the random events and traits your character picks up their their life is what makes this game. Crusader Kings II gameplay features are robust. A few examples are plotting and bribing to commit assassinations. Managing kingdom laws and church opinion. Raising levies and troops to carry out your lord’s wars. Also genetic matching of couples and tutoring of child characters to effect their traits as an adult.   There are so many features to this game I simply can not fit it into a short review. This is the attraction and downfall to Crusader Kings II. A fun political/strategy game that has great mechanics but a bit of a steep learning curve. I find the game to have good but not great playback value even after purchasing a few campaign DLC.  Pick up Crusader Kings II if you have ever dreamed of living the life of a medieval noble. Climb your way up the political ladder and take your crown.  8/10 I recommend this game.

This game is not for the faint of heart of those who lack patience. It has one of the highest learning curves in a Grand Strategy game. This ain't Civilization. You've been warned.  Crusader Kings II is a Grand Strategy game from Paradox Interactive. It was released in 2012 and has been very heavily supported with various expansions via Paradox as well as mod support.  You don't play as a country in this game. You play as a dynasty in the Middle Ages. You choose a person and have to rule over your land as well as make sure you have a successor to your dynasty. You may start of as a minor feudal lord, a petty king, a king of a large country or an emperor. In this game you have to learn how to manipulate the political landscape, as well as engage in large scale wars and run your county/kingdom/empire.   The game is not the most accessible game to those unfamiliar with previous Paradox Grand Strategy titles. Even those who would say they are Civilization experts can find themselves overwhelmed by the sheer amount of info that the game displays. There is a tutorial campaign, but watching lets plays will definately help new players figure out the more advanced tactics that can be accomplished in the game. I personally reccomend watching LPs on YouTube by Northernlion, Arumba, MathasGames and quill18.  To help describe the amount of detail you can influence in this game, there is a genetic system as well as an education system in the game that I'll breifly explain. You're children will gain the genetic traits of yourself as well as your spouse in the game, like a sickness of an affinity for intelligence. This also includes statistics to attributes not unlike a tabletop RPG. The education system allows you to have your child taught different behavioural triats that boost or negate those stats. This is important to be aware of because in the event of your character dying (whether it be by poison in your wine, being killed in battle, or of old age) your child will be your successor. This isn't always the case due to different succession laws that can be enacted, but in the end, your dynasty has to survive.  The game's interface as seen on the store page takes place on a map of mainly Western Europe, the Middle East, and North Africa. (Eastern countries like India are included in DLC). Time can be paused and sped up at any time during the game.  You will have to be wary as factions can cause an uprising if you run your land like a tyrant, or even if a morally ambiguous party who would see to take your throne from you. You can however use ditry tactics as well, such as bribery, assassination, plotting individuals againts one another. Sometimes you get away with these acts, sometimes your involvment gets discovered, harming your reputation.   The game itself has no set campaigns, which works to its advantage as it is a historical sandbox. You can influence the entire world in ways that aren't historically correct but still plausible, like taking over Constantinople causes the Crusades to start hundreds of years before their historical date.  This game will take time to learn, but when you do learn it, Crusader Kings II is one of the most rewarding titles to be on the PC in a very long time.  If you find games like Civ too easy, give this game a shot. It's on sale often as well.

The game mechanics are beautifully implemented so as to produce a puzzle of scheming and diplomacy like no other game I've tried. The multiplayer is a bit glitchy, but well worth the effort. The single player could entertain you for months.

Outstanding. All the depth you expect from Paradox, none of the bafflement. At once a gloriously detailed simulation of medieval Europe and a top-class engine for emergent narrative. Obscure historical figures and their imaginary descendents will become characters you care deeply about (or despise with a cankerous, murderous passion). The map of Europe will be redrawn - and not just by you. In one game I spent 200 years conquering and uniting Britannia, without noticing that my rival had united France and Spain into a terrifying empire of Hispania - what had been a game of petty politics and dynastic diplomacy became a game of grand imperial strategy.

Best. Game. Ever*.  I'm not actually a big gamer, most games fail to interest me at all. Even EU4 seems to lose that special touch for me, it becomes too impersonal. Having personal dramas mix right along side with imperial conquest and dynastic survival... There are ways in which this game could be better and more thorough, but not many, but it comes closer than any other I have ever played.  Your milage may vary, but if conquering persia, arabia, and toppling the byzantines or seducing the king of poland until he grants you a duchy for your son to inherit (and then 200 years later your family rules the holy roman empire while your old rivals in the polish court are all now dead) or squashing those pathetic christ worshipers under your powerful viking boot only to open fire on the muslims who are already defending from the mongols, or to take a dynasty which ruled half of Europe and reduce them to extinction simply because they killed your first heir... If those sorts of games sound fun for you, you will need to find some time in your schedule.  *Ever= So far. if you could manage cities on a level akin to sim city, more soap opera/daily life stuff in the interpersonal area, and a more total war style view of battles, this game would be even better...
One of the best games I have ever played. Crusader Kings II allows for so much tinkering and toying with a game engine that is highly moddable (and for which some great mods have already been made).

So this is probably my most played single player game ever, and it's the one that I always go back to when I get really bored. Its main appeal is probably the ability to rewrite or attempt to recreate history. I have all of the big DLC's and some of the rinky dink ones. The only really bad one is Sunset Invasion (it's just dumb). I'm kind of a history buff, so that's probably why I keep going back to it. Obviously I really like the game, but I also see some issues.  Like most Paradox games, it's got a pretty steep learning curve, but this is definitely one of the more approachable Paradox titles. Very rarely do I find myself in a situation where I'm unable to strengthen my country even as a one province realm (okay, if you get invaded day one by your huge-♥♥♥ neighbor it's gonna be rough, but by-and-large...) unlike in EU and especially Victoria games.  Sometimes they mess things up on patches; I remember one time they changed some math to do with retinues but forgot to update numbers for Merchant Republics so for a while you could get a ridiculously large retinue army. Merchant Republics are still pretty OP for player characters, but that's another story.  One of my favorite features is that many historical characters have links to their wikipedia articles (e.g. Charlemagne, but also most king level characters and above in starting scenarios, and the more notable dukes and counts).  Obviously the revenue format kinda sucks, but it's just the way of the world now, I guess. Sometimes I feel like Paradox should be a bit more rewarding to folks who buy DLCs piecemeal (there were times during sales where I could have bought the entire game with all DLCs for less than the remaining DLCs would cost during the same sale, but I guess they still got me to buy them, so, whatever).  I have some legitimate gameplay criticisms, but I can't remember any specific ones right now. I will probably update this later when I remember them (if that can be done). Overall Paradox has done a pretty good job improving and balancing the game with updates (for free).

What can I say that hasn't been said below(or above) nothing really... this isn't what I'd call a game, it's more like a medieval soap opera out your dreams/perfect kind of eskapisism without the actual 'must' to be a nerd to 'get' - if 'the dark ages' of Europe is of any interest to you, that is.  Anyway... it's highly priced, so either wait for a sale or get it with extreme caution (I got it before the two latest dlc's Charlemagne and the Way of Life came out - so I got it simply because I could live my dream of being a viking: having a great berd, sacrificing to the Old Gods while having a few horns of mead AND raiding the Brittish Isles times and times again (all these things at the same time), then loot some neighbors (like the finno-ugric people, slavs and balts) take over more land form the kingdom of Sweden and, if the Gods will, the Empire of Scandinavia. Take over more land just because I hopefully can. or die trying - but becomming a great Viking dynasty.   On negative aspects the learning curve, THE learning curve and all these dlc's comming out all the time (making it hard to decide whether to buy them or not) but Steam workshop's here for most situations.  The good thing is that you can basically be anyone you want, at any point of the timespan of the game (depending on the dlc's you have bought)   Summa summarum: a fairly great game. about 9+/10, not perfect, but there are quite a few ♥♥♥♥♥♥ games out there, trust me.

I love this game. There is simply not much to complain about. Other then some sketchy DLC choices, and the fact that the EU4 converter hardly works, this game can give you hundreds of hours of enjoyment. The fact that it has one of the most active modding communities kept me going when I couldn't get the nice DLC (Which are very good as well.)  Amazing art style  Interesting campaigns  Amazingly fun  Pretty addicting  A solid 10/10 from me. Even without the DLC.

Play as a dynasty leading one of a great host of states from Ireland to India (DLC is needed for several groups, but even the most basic set of characters is a huge amount of replayability), and see your people rise and fall based on an enormous amount of factors - your skill, that dastardly hand of fate, the insignificant details and allies you forgot about, and the Mongols.  The game takes a bit of time to learn, but not as much as many grand strategy games - and as with most Paradox games there are both easy and hard places to start. Gameplay is exceptionally variable, with events constantly coming up to haunt you (I married my least important son to a countess in Italy for a minor alliance... a decade later and he's my only heir, and she has corrupted him into a monsterous excommunicated idiot), and the future always uncertain*. The events seem very intuitive and reactive, and every aspect of the game feels like it is impacted by your decisions (from the claims that people look to, to the balance of power of religions, to the genetics of your heirs - the game responds to your actions and gives you feedback: your family might even start naming children after your custom names).  If that doesn't interest you... there's still an extremely robust modding community with tons of alternate scenarios and events.  * If you get enough power, or are very good at playing certain aspects of the game, you can pretty much cruise through poor leaders (or make it very unlikely to get poor leaders). Unless you're really good or really powerful (in which case, start over and challenge yourself with harder starts or trickier goals), though, your best plans and hard fought gains can evaporate overnight with rebellion, assassination, disease, and Mongols. The game never gets into a boring plateau, because you are constantly rising and falling (or at least scheming to rise and scrambling to avoid falling).

I recommend getting 'The Old Gods' and 'The Sword of Islam' DLC at least, as some of the features (retinues, etc.) are not unlocked in the vanilla game. The buttons are still present, so if you have the vanilla game and have been trying to earn a retinue and haven't been able to, this is why. (A little annoying when game makers put in buttons for DLC content right next to other regular game functions and don't tell you what's up)  If you're a Game of Thrones fan, there's a mod for that. And it's quite good. Lannister 4 life.  If you don't use console commands, the start of this game may be extremely frustrating. It takes waaaay too long to make any amount of decent money. Meanwhile, everyone else in the world seems to have enough money to wage war on you or hire an assasin to kill you. Even if you don't want to get into altering people's traits via console and whatnot, I highly recommend the 'cash' command at least. It's the only way to quickly get out of the initial slog and on to bigger business... like trying to close that Gate to Hell.   It's unique. It's smart. And it doesn't give me motion sickness. Highly recommend!

So I was Sancho I, King of Castille. I had just killed my brother Garcia II, King of Galicia. And my other brother, Alfonso II, King of Leon, died of illness. As King of (almost) all Jimenas, I did my best to remove the Andalusian kebabs. And so I did. My dynasty was on a tightrope, since my king only could have one child (Gavelkind Succesion). And after Sancho's early death at age 47, and Ferdinand's death at age 41, Sancho 'The Hunter' II was the last of the Castillian Jimenas. Because Ferdinand instated Primogentiture in the kingdoms, Sancho II had 2 sisters. One of them married to the King of Navarra, Luis 'the Fat' I. Queen Blanca (the sister of Sancho II) popped out a child, Alfontso Luis Jimena, Prince of Navarra, Castille, Leon, Galicia, and Portugal (speaking of Portugal, Duchess Urraca of Porto was always plotting against ol' Sancho II). After Sancho II died at the ripe old age of 58 after years being a maimed cripple (His father died after being in a coma, yeesh), Alfontso became Alfontso I of Navarra, Castille, Leon, Galicia, Portugal, and eventually Andalusia. Meanwhile, Aragon, Barcelona, and Denia (yes, a county) were all prominent figures in this Hispanic tumble. After dying of illness at age 38, Alfontso I left the kingdom to his half-Moorish son Luis II of Navarra. After years of negotiating and 'negotiating', Luis II of Navarra because Luis I of Hispania. Next stop, Emperor of Mali. But Luis I died at age 55. Then Alfontso I came along. he got the Kingdom of Mali, but still nothing. Edigo 'the Bold' I was bold enough to conquer Mauritania, but it was Alfontso II who got it. He was the son of Edigo I and Queen Orlaith 'the Wise' I of France. He soon randomly got Aquitane and he was crowned Emperor of Francia. His son, Edigo I, Prince of Asturias, died before being crowned, so at age 21, Alfontso III became Emperor of Spain, Mali, and Francia. Feeling pretty dickish (Alfontso was a cynic to be reckoned with and he almost lost the empire to his many relatives), named his son Charlemagne. After Alfontso III died of poor health at the age of 41, Charlemagne 'the Just' I started the 'Remove Kebab Program' to remove kebabs from Africa. That had to wait, because the Spanish-Scandinavian Civil war started against Empress Thorborg I of Scandinavia and Emperor Charlemagne I. Emperor Charlemagne succesfully installed his 15 year old son as emperor (the war started when he was ~8). He was happy with his wife, Queen Helena 'the Fat' I of Poland, but went insane. He became emperor after my 74 year old emperor died. Rodrigo 'the Usurper' I was emperor rule for a WHOPPING........ 10 months and a day. After that Charlemagne 'the Great' II (yeah, Charles the Great the Great), removed all the kebabs, getting down to Abbyssnia. After dying at the age of 69 ( ͡° ͜ʖ ͡°), Alfontso IV became king. He removed some kebabs, some filthy pagans, but the biggest things he did was make Estifania, his daughter, Queen of England, conquer Ireland, and conquer Scotland. He died at 58 in a comatose state. Now I, Emperor Alfontso V, did 1 thing, I killed my heir to get Hungary and to become Emperor of Carpathia.  Overall I amassed 128,000 prestige, ruled over all of Western Europe except for a tiny piece of France, Never lost a county, made the Seljuks our ♥♥♥♥♥, became the most prestigious dynasty, became related to the all of the last independent Christian kingdoms,and owned 8 empires (not counting 1 mod empire). All out of of a 4 province kingdom.   ∞/10 would be a Jimena again.

Crusader Kings II is an amazing game for the right people. If you like grand strategy, historical fiction and micro-managing this game, and Paradox games in general, are some of the best. I've dumped hundreds of hours into these games (thus not needing to buy other games) and I have enjoyed much of the content created by the loyal community around these games.   However, there is a big catch. If you've gotten this far then you've probably seen there is ALOT of DLC for this game, hundreds of dollars of DLC. You are not going to want to play this game without a lot of this DLC. This makes this game a huge investment and you'll probably not be anywhere close to mastering it at the end of your two hour refund period. Do at least half a playthrough before buying any DLC. The money is worth it if you can see yourself spending more than a 1000 hours on this game but if not then this game might not be worth it. It really pains me to say it but the expenses can't be ignored.

A sweet tale of house Basayev  The house Basayev came to power in central asia in the great steppes. Their land was diverse and rich in culture and heritage. Lord Yusuf was a powerful man, smart, attractive and prone to seducing women, staking prisoners and torturing those he hated.   So he invaded Afghanistan to further grow his lands. And after much ♥♥♥♥♥♥, staking and maiming completed his task. But no, Yusuf was not content, he gazed upon the Seljuks and saw ♥♥♥ he wanted.  Raising his warriors he invaded the Seljuks and slowly ate away at their territory. His sons led the armies while he watched and was pleased with his work.   Soon the House Basayev was feared throughout the Muslim world, a pious, rich family wielding more power than the Sultans themselves.   Then it all went ♥♥♥♥ up.   You see Yusuf soon died and he had sons. Lots of sons. 7 to be exact.   Here is their tale: 2 died in battle against the remnants of the Seljuks.  1 killed himself  2 died from suspicious circumstances.   Which left 2. Alp and Boris.   Boris was strong and stupid. Alp sickly and smart.   Neither could stand the other and so civil war broke out over succession.   By the time it was over the seljuks and afghans had reclaimed lost land and Alp was back to the beginning.   He soon died and left asickly homosexual son.   So ended the Basayev line. All other children were killed to prevent succession or died in war or disease.   10/10 would play again.   This game makes you realise even the nicest person will kill their own brother for power.

I could give you a run down of one of my campaigns. There was the time I played a Norman Count recently installed after the Battle of Hastings. I played it nice with William, was made Duke... then overthrew his son as soon as he died and crowned myself King Edmund (Blackadder). There was the time I rebuilt the Roman Empire, reunified the Christian Church then imported the Save into EU IV and took Rome to the New World. There was the time where I built a great Welsh Empire that emcompassed all of Great Britain then took the fight to the Mongols. Then there was the time that I encountered the Persian Joan of Ark who led my armies to victory in India... but I won't go into details of those, instead I will tell you why you should grab a copy of CKII as well as a few reasons why you might not want to.  The Pros: *CKII is a very complex game that gives you an unparalleled level of freedom to shape your dynasty. Along with the usual diplomacy and warfare your character will encounter all manner of interesting random event and can embark on all manner of interesting personal quest - erect a runestone honouring your mother or seduce the King's wife then convince her to help you murder him... or dump her, seduce her daughter and catch sypholis. *The game is very well supported by Paradox and there is a constant stream of new content (some of which is free and some of which you need to buy). *If you do manage to get bored the Modding Community has created some truly exceptional pieces of work that will completely overhaul the game. *Offer the French King up as a human sacrifice to appease the Norse Gods. *If you like Diplomacy this game models it in a far more satisfying manner than any other game I have played. *Capture the Mongol Khan in battle. Then castrate him and send him back to his people. *This game will run on most PCs. *Claim the throne... then get murdered the very next day.  The Cons: *CKII is a very complex game. It has a steep learning curve. *Getting a complete copy of CKII is not cheap! Paradox has released a lot of DLCs since this game was released. *If you love Total War style cinematic battles, CKII does not do that. You have no direct control over your generals. You can watch them and see what strategies they are employing which is often quite fun but which can also be irritating when you watch your troops massacred through the flagrant incompetence of your commanders. Applaud as your massive longbow volley devastates the enemy ranks, then cringe as your general charges his own skirmishers then hesitates at a crucial moment... and suddenly everyone is running away. *The game will slow down towards the end-game as it follows the lives of the thousands of characters who are living, dying and murdering their way through Eurasia and North Africa. If there are too many it can become a little unstable.

I'm gonna kick this review off with the solid statement that this game is very complicated and if you arne't into sitting down doing the time of actually learning how to play, than this game isn't for you and you shouldn't bother reading this review although I encourage you to change your opinoins.   Crusader Kings II which from now on will be referred to as CK, is a game with a simple objective but a very complicated road to that objective. The main and primary objective is to make your dynasty/family last as long as possible while getting a high score. You can achieve this goal by killing other people and claiming their thrones, conquring more lands, marrying all of your chhildren and yourself, and many more that I would be here for a long time if I listed all of them. There is also the added complication of disease and conqureing countries such as the mongols and the aztecs (provided you have the right DLC).  This game is primarily about diplomatic stratergy that can aid you in further wars which are generally reffered to as the crusades (thus the name). You can make allies by being an alround nice person. You can steal peoples wifes, imprison their children, imprison your own children and alround ruin alot of lives.  Lets get into some pros and cons   Pros: Historical Fun   Cons: Takes you life Takes your money Destroys study life Hard to learn Rediculously annoying Oddly compelling Doesn't support Intel Graphics Cards  Even though the cons severly outway the pros, I still would recommend this game, even though I don't have a huge ammount of experience at the point I write this review (8 Hours), I can thoroughly say that this game is a good expirence and my hours will definatly increase.  The overall verdict is that this is a good game for anyone who enjoys complicated games and has a great time reading everything that pops up on the screen, gets peeved at the little things, and overall has no problem with loosing every two seconds                    #BetterThanEU4

A good game, with a Clauzewitz engine. The real guy is famous for quipping, inter alia, that war is an extension of politics by other means. This game conveys that in an interesting way, sometimes gripping.   Bad points. Can be a time sink. Fem bias.  But they are generally outweighed by lots of fun and laughter. Probably the most stressful element is gavelkind succession rules, which seem to require more time to master than I've put in so far (about 150 hrs). This basically means that if you have more than one kiddie then the goodies you've built up during a reign, or a whole succession of reigns, get divided up into separate states. And you don't get the choice which one to play in the new generation. So you can begin to see why some folk knight this game Sir Infanticide. It can be gut wrenching.  One of my more successful runs came close to unifying all the English duchies into the much sought-after kingdom, but then that awful warning sign bobbed up that there was no successor of my line, so the game will end when my current archduchess character dies. Entirely my fault since I've been artlessly given away in youth into regular patrilinear wedlock. There was a niece of my house and some distant relly with no lands. But when the warning came i already had four or five kids counted as some poxy frankish house. What can you do? Its just destiny. But then one of my sons dies young by arbitrary whim of the presiding Clauzewitz. Hhmm. So I arrested the two other sons. Hhmmer. It's really easy to murder any prisoner. So I did. Meanwhile I'm transferring almost all my lands and titles to the older relly. Preferable to give them to the niece and marry her off matrilinear, but the game won't allow her to receive titles so young. Male bias for sure. However having reduced the reigning family to one daughter, it turns out you can't imprison a daughter. Even if she's all that stands between UK empire under your dynasty and who knows after that (thewhole world ??!) and the game ending, there's a little message insisting she's immune from even a day in prison, where she obviously belongs. WFT in spades after arresting and slaughtering two sons, plus a continental husband tied to some very powerful thrones there. Lots of threats, lots of revolts, all evaded or put down by a massive standing army i don't dare disband. Well eventually my evil duchess persona dies and the game ends well shy of my just deserts. If this doesn't demonstrate fem bias i wouldnt know what would.  Nevertheless I'd recommend this game. You just need to spend some time, and tears, getting to grips with the rules. There's a lot.

So I've owned this game for a couple years and have played it a lot, so I thought it was finally time to write a review.  I love this game. It is complex vivid and colorful, and will keep your attention generation after generation. I have bought several of the dlc as well, and i think that from what i got out of it, it was worth the money. This game needs a couple of the DLC to be its best, which is one of the downsides. When I started playing, there was only europe and north africa, but the map has extended out to mongolia and as far south as India. The world is huge and the options are endless. I will say that the mechanics are hard to master and very confusing at first, but once you learn, not only does this game become awesome, you can basically play any other paradox GS game, because they have similar interfaces and mechanics. This is definitely a game worth buying and learning to play.

This Paradox grand strategy has more depth than any other, at least diplomatically.  Managing a title (whether it be a simple county or a large kingdom) in the dark-medieval ages gives one of the most addicting experiences in the grand strategy genre. You can really invest yourself in your dynasty, expanding it large enough that even your kin become foe. The strategy lies in your court, and how you can cunningly underhand neighboring lords to steal their throne, or how you can assassinate your way into a strategically place succession, or how you can muster your loyal subjects to take lands by force.   This game works amazingly as a casual singleplayer experience, or an engaged multiplayer fiesta.  BONUS FOR FANS OF A SONG OF ICE AND FIRE/GAME OF THRONES: Crusader Kings II has the single best structure of video game to most accurately simulate the world of Ice and Fire. Medieval Total War 2's GoT mod is held back by its lack of political intrigue and depth, as with Mount and Blade: Warband's GoT mod. However, the CK2:AGoT mod gives the most interactive gaming experience for the Game of Thrones series, guaranteed to be enjoyed by fans of the books and show alike.  10/10

Well, where can I start?  Crusader Kings II is probably one of the most addictive Grand Stratergies i've ever played. With over 100 hours on it, I can proudly say i'm addicted.  I came to this game, hoping that Paradox had made a good historical game and they exceeded my expectations.  Here are my positive and negative views on this game:  Pros -----  - Addictive  - Different combinations of gameplay  - DLC Mechanics [I'll come to this later]  - Playing your favorite nations.  - Playing important bookmarks in history  - De Jure Wars  - The Council  Cons ----- - Bad Multiplayer [I'll come to this too] - Assassination Attempts - Not many Cons  The DLC in the game is quite bountiful, it spins the whole mechanics you have learnt in the vanilla and makes you spend more hours on the game trying to get how the game works.  A good example is Conclave DLC, which provides a whole new set of laws for you to toy with and a Council which you have to always please.  The thing that I am disappointed in the most with this game is the bad multiplayer, where your friends go out of sync randomly. My solution for anyone finding this problem is to use LogMeIn Hamachi and go to Documents\Paradox Interactive\Crusader Kings II\Maps then delete the caches there. You will have to do this every multiplayer session you do, have fun!   Verdict: Crusader Kings II is a game that is worth your money when it is on deal or not. It can entertain you for hours on end, wether you get home at 3 oclock in the afternoon and want to unwind on a Friday night sweating on this game, or if you're just going to play an hour or three with your favorite country. There are many ways to toy with this game.   My advice is to purchase the game and any DLC that changes your gameplay in an Autumn Sale or Christmas Sale, it is worth your money.

My hours played should speak for themselves, but this is a fantastic game if you love grand strategy games. Basically, this is a machiavellian simulator: you play as a ruler starting sometime after 769 (with Charlamagne DLC) and plot, murder and war your way to power until your dynasty is extinct or unlanded or until 1452, whichever comes first. If you don't like computer games at all (in which case I'm unsure why you're reading this), but love interactive maps and history, it's just about worth buying the base game (+Charlamagne and the Old Gods DLCs) just to spend hours on end alternating between looking at maps and reading about religions you'd never heard of, famour characters from the period, or historical developments that occurred during the era.  Highly recommended, 10/10.

Crusader Kings II is a brilliant game. It offers you an immense amount of choice and freedom. Do you want to become the king of England, sure. Do you you want to restore Rome to its former glory, can do. Do you want to rule all of India as its Viking overlord, if you want.  Like many Paradox games, though you may start with heroic intentions, you will inevitably become the villain. You are the duke of of York. Your reign will be just and fair. Though you only hold one county and your neighbours are eyeing up your land. If you lose your land your just reign will be over and the people will suffer. You decide to fabricate a claim on your weaker neighbours, for they are surely doing the same. You press your claims through war. War was inevitable you tell yourself. Now you have consolidated your land, you are safe and peace will follow.  Scotland attacks, your incompetent king and his infighting vessels are useless. You fight as best you can, but your meagre duchy can not hope to stand against an entire kingdom. The war is lost and Northumbria is lost to the Scots. Your land can not be safe as long as a weak king rules the kingdom. You use the fact that your grandfather on your mother's side was the king and start a faction to press your claim. With the help of your fellow vessels you place yourself on the throne. Finally their can be peace.  You die and are replaced by your son. Your vessels are less than pleased. They start factions to limit your power and overthrow you. If they succeed all your work will have been for nothing. You blackmail your can and assassinate the ones you can't. Your vessels are split and powerless. With your internal affairs consolidated, you prepare to neutralise the Scottish threat once and for all. Over many wars and decades you chip your way through through Scotland. To prevent a unified Ireland from ever becoming a threat you conquer them as well. Now with your, vast domain, you crown yourself Emperor of Britannia. With your strong and unified empire, no one will invade. No one will threaten your long fought peace.  The Umayyads have conquered southern France. Their empire now stretches across all south western Europe. Christendom is weak and dis unified. Within a generation they will have conquered continental Europe and become unstoppable. You raise taxes and prepare for war. The peasants, distraught at the extortionate methods used by your steward decide to rebel. Though they fight valiantly, they are no match for your well trained army. While Christendom falls the pope calls a crusade for Jerusalem. It fails utterly. You decide to take things into our own hands. You name denounce the papacy and put forward your bishop as the true pope. With a quick and one sided war you conquer Rome and replace the pope with your bishop. Now the papacy is restored, but as a vessel of your empire. The Muslim threat is still ever present and peace is still not secure.  While you focused on the papacy your vessels have grown strong. Though they do not openly challenge you as of yet, it is only a matter of time. You invoke the power of your newly vassalise pope and excommunicate them. With little opposition you imprison them and redistribute their land. You are still to weak to fight the mighty Umayyads and decide to first unite the remaining European Christian kings under your might. With a few fabricated claims and papal sanctioned invasions you conquer Germania northern France. Your new vassals attempt to rebel, but they are replaced with loyal friends. The peasants rebel against their new overlords, but they are quickly put down. Your ready your massive army and call a crusade for Aquitaine. The war is long and brutal, countless people lose their lives, but in the end you are victorious. Though you face much resistance from the common people you gradually conquer the rest of Hispania. Now you are safe, now taxes can be lowered and the people can prosper, now there can be peace, but the Byzantine Empire is growing awfully strong...

CK2 is a great strategy game.Handling your dynasty and/or your kingdom/duchy over hundreds of years. The game has a rather steep learning curve if you're not familiar with Paradox Games.  At times, info and the impact of your decisions are a bit difficult to anticipate. Notably, when you get into tricky succession (ie : usually, when you're about to lose a lot to someone out of your dynasty), it's difficult at first to determine how you can prevent it, even if you can prevent it... or who is going to inherit if your change your law. Succession, being a big part of the game, could be better handled with better interface display. It's better to manage once you get a sense of the succession laws and you handle your dynasty carefully (you have less tricky situations).  War and battles is handled at a basic level. You move your armies, you watch it fighting. You move your army to a county, you watch your troop besieging each castle and town. Your action on the battles themselves is limited to chosing the leaders at the center or the wings. Pick the good leaders, pay attention to their troops and the leader's traits. The game has a snowball effects during wars when, facing a relatively equal enemy, the first battles are often decisive. Once you start winning, the opposition becomes weaker and weaker, so you win constantly and so on.  And then, with the practice, you'll be able to manage your kingdom better and better from the start. Leading often to mid-game where you can dominate all your neighbors easily, if not half Europe (or more, depends who you play). The consequence is the end of the game is really easy. Now, it's not an easy game from the first session you play. It becomes easier the better you are at it. Not a big surprise. But for some players, the game may show its limits  CK2 is still a satisfying game. Replayability lies much more into the many starts you can have. You have all the european dynsaties, minor lords and all, to toy with. Play pagans, christians fighting to defend Iberia, irishmen, try to rebuild the roman empire, play a count and work up to king or emperor, play various counties, duchies, kingdoms, empires, play various cultures, religions. You can play match-making in your court and weave dynastic succession, or conquer everything by the sword and hopefully still hold it after the conqueror death. The game replayability lies in its very sandboxy aspect.  Now the DLCs.. It's a difficult topic. Some of them are offering a real value, some others are cosmetic. Pay attention to player feedback about 'content DLCs'. The more recent DLC have a debatable value in terms of content, relative to their price, or relative to what the game will become.  CK2 is a great game and deserve to become a classic of strategy games. It's going to keep you satisfyingly busy during many many hours.
